description: In this series, Mike and Justin are going to the explore the beginning of JavaScript in the browser. This is going to lay the foundation for the additional work to come in JavaScript. There will be a focus on the ECMAScript 5 features that are found in the browser. If you want to create interactive websites, are new to programming, or just want to know more about JavaScript, then you have come to the right place. They cover topics such a deep dive on the data types found in JavaScript, operating on the data types,  iteration(loops), control flow (decision making), creating  functions for code reuse, and touching on the beginning of object oriented programming.

name: Intro to JavaScript
subtitle: Getting Started

episodes.description: In this series, Mike and Justin are going to the explore the beginning of JavaScript in the browser. This is going to lay the foundation for the additional work to come in JavaScript. There will be a focus on the ECMAScript 5 features that are found in the browser. If you want to create interactive websites, are new to programming, or just want to know more about JavaScript, then you have come to the right place. They cover topics such a deep dive on the data types found in JavaScript, operating on the data types, iteration(loops), control flow (decision making), creating functions for code reuse, and touching on the beginning of object oriented programming.
episodes.title: Overview
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.025 --> 00:00:04.953
[SOUND] Hello, I'm excited to
announce we've got a new series

2
00:00:04.953 --> 00:00:10.273
coming your way here at ITPRO.TV,
Introduction to JavaScript.

3
00:00:10.273 --> 00:00:13.840
Here to tell us all about it and
what we can expect, Mr. Justin Dennison.

4
00:00:13.840 --> 00:00:18.013
>> Thanks Mike, JavaScript, that tiny
interpretive language that makes all those

5
00:00:18.013 --> 00:00:20.442
webpages have those
wonderful interactions.

6
00:00:20.442 --> 00:00:23.108
During this series we're gonna
cover how to create a function.

7
00:00:23.108 --> 00:00:25.187
How to create loops,
how to make decisions.

8
00:00:25.187 --> 00:00:29.670
As well as working with those
fundamental data types, arrays,

9
00:00:29.670 --> 00:00:32.001
objects, strings, and dates.

10
00:00:32.001 --> 00:00:36.360
So if that's something you're interested
in, I can't wait to see you there.

11
00:00:36.360 --> 00:00:39.280
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Mike begin their exploration into the world of JavaScript. They talk about the origins and historyo f JavaScript. They also look at setting up an environment to develop with JavaScript.
episodes.title: Getting Started and History
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.220 --> 00:00:01.396
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.396 --> 00:00:06.884
I'm your host [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.884 --> 00:00:08.500
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.500 --> 00:00:10.808
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:10.808 --> 00:00:12.852
>> Hello.

6
00:00:12.852 --> 00:00:15.460
Welcome to another exciting
episode here at ITProTV.

7
00:00:15.460 --> 00:00:17.516
I'm your host Mike Rodrick and today,

8
00:00:17.516 --> 00:00:20.045
we're doing our
introduction to JavaScript.

9
00:00:20.045 --> 00:00:24.385
And specifically in this episode, we're
gonna take a look at just getting started

10
00:00:24.385 --> 00:00:26.370
with JavaScript, where do we begin?

11
00:00:26.370 --> 00:00:30.630
As well as, take look at a little bit of
history on JavaScript, where it came from?

12
00:00:30.630 --> 00:00:34.531
And here to help us with that is,
our in-house JavaScript expert Mr.

13
00:00:34.531 --> 00:00:35.600
Justin Dennison.

14
00:00:35.600 --> 00:00:36.790
Welcome Justin.

15
00:00:36.790 --> 00:00:37.970
Thanks for having me here, Mike.

16
00:00:37.970 --> 00:00:41.480
I am excited to be there, and
I'm ready to get started.

17
00:00:41.480 --> 00:00:43.030
>> Yeah me too, I'm excited as well.

18
00:00:43.030 --> 00:00:46.070
So let's start off with,
what is JavaScript?

19
00:00:46.070 --> 00:00:47.660
>> So, that's a great question Mike.

20
00:00:47.660 --> 00:00:52.130
I think it's important to have a little
bit of context and history, for

21
00:00:52.130 --> 00:00:55.830
the JavaScript language,
before we worry about really diving in.

22
00:00:55.830 --> 00:01:01.310
So, JavaScript was actually invented by
Brendan Eich, at the Netscape community.

23
00:01:01.310 --> 00:01:04.100
But really, why would we need
something that runs in the browser?

24
00:01:04.100 --> 00:01:05.910
We had HTML and CSS.

25
00:01:05.910 --> 00:01:07.680
But, I don't know if you
remember those wonderful

26
00:01:07.680 --> 00:01:08.502
GeoCities pages-
>> [LAUGH]

27
00:01:08.502 --> 00:01:10.502
>> Or those Angelfire pages.

28
00:01:10.502 --> 00:01:15.680
If there wasn't at least 13 animated GIFs
on those, then we weren't doing it right.

29
00:01:15.680 --> 00:01:17.160
>> With a little MIDI
music in the background?

30
00:01:17.160 --> 00:01:18.676
>> Yeah, yeah, yeah.

31
00:01:18.676 --> 00:01:23.160
Music, one of my favorite
things that loads on a page.

32
00:01:23.160 --> 00:01:25.860
So the purpose of JavaScript
was to add interactivity.

33
00:01:25.860 --> 00:01:29.860
Kind of, point, click,
movements, basic animations.

34
00:01:29.860 --> 00:01:34.380
So Brendan Eich at Netscape,
more or less, made it in ten days.

35
00:01:34.380 --> 00:01:35.900
Now that's what I've heard and

36
00:01:35.900 --> 00:01:40.780
read, but the initial release
was only ten days to produce.

37
00:01:40.780 --> 00:01:44.540
Now, Brendan Eich has actually since
moved on to the Mozilla Project,

38
00:01:44.540 --> 00:01:46.610
which we all know creates Firefox.

39
00:01:46.610 --> 00:01:48.150
So he's still around.

40
00:01:48.150 --> 00:01:53.150
But, JavaScript has went through some
metamorphoses throughout the years.

41
00:01:53.150 --> 00:01:54.940
It started with that basic implementation.

42
00:01:54.940 --> 00:01:57.636
It was originally called Mocha.

43
00:01:57.636 --> 00:01:58.800
>> Hmm!
>> Later changed to LiveScript.

44
00:01:58.800 --> 00:02:00.390
And then there was this other language,

45
00:02:00.390 --> 00:02:04.960
happening at the exact same time,
really getting its market share.

46
00:02:04.960 --> 00:02:06.080
Maybe you've heard of it, Java.

47
00:02:07.360 --> 00:02:12.550
And as a result, they were like
maybe we can capitalize on this.

48
00:02:12.550 --> 00:02:14.410
And through some wheelings and dealings,

49
00:02:14.410 --> 00:02:18.610
change the final name to JavaScript,
just to capitalize on that market.

50
00:02:18.610 --> 00:02:20.820
>> So Java and JavaScript then,
to make sure we're clear,

51
00:02:20.820 --> 00:02:23.590
are different animals, right?

52
00:02:23.590 --> 00:02:24.650
>> Exactly.

53
00:02:24.650 --> 00:02:28.545
So Java and JavaScript, they share a name,
they share a little bit of syntax, but

54
00:02:28.545 --> 00:02:29.620
that's about it.

55
00:02:29.620 --> 00:02:34.210
One runs in the browser, one used to
run in the browser but, has since been

56
00:02:34.210 --> 00:02:38.820
[SOUND] nixed, and then one is scripting,
and one is a compiled language.

57
00:02:38.820 --> 00:02:39.557
>> Very good.

58
00:02:39.557 --> 00:02:41.499
And then so JavaScript came about,

59
00:02:41.499 --> 00:02:44.678
because initially web pages
were very inactive, right?

60
00:02:44.678 --> 00:02:47.462
I mean, they were, as you said,
you had a couple moving GIFs.

61
00:02:47.462 --> 00:02:49.660
That was it though.

62
00:02:49.660 --> 00:02:51.770
There was a lot of static text,

63
00:02:51.770 --> 00:02:56.340
and scripting in Java Script in general,
is what gave us the interactivity.

64
00:02:56.340 --> 00:02:58.840
The buttons that we can click on,
and things like that.

65
00:02:58.840 --> 00:02:59.550
>> Exactly.

66
00:02:59.550 --> 00:03:00.942
So without JavaScript,

67
00:03:00.942 --> 00:03:05.461
those pages that you load that look like
native applications, would not exist.

68
00:03:05.461 --> 00:03:06.210
>> Wow.

69
00:03:06.210 --> 00:03:08.780
>> Now throughout the years,
JavaScript has, like I said,

70
00:03:08.780 --> 00:03:12.930
went through several changes,
has become a better language, I think,

71
00:03:12.930 --> 00:03:15.290
that's a personal opinion,
throughout the ages.

72
00:03:15.290 --> 00:03:17.430
But it's because of,

73
00:03:17.430 --> 00:03:21.340
what is called the European
Computer Manufacturers Association.

74
00:03:21.340 --> 00:03:24.230
They've actually become
the organizing body, for

75
00:03:24.230 --> 00:03:28.650
the standard of JavaScript,
also known as Ecma.

76
00:03:28.650 --> 00:03:33.911
They actually had a hand in C#,
parts of the CD-ROM standardization, C ++.

77
00:03:33.911 --> 00:03:36.660
So, they've had their
fingers in a few things.

78
00:03:36.660 --> 00:03:40.690
But, they are pushing JavaScript forward,

79
00:03:40.690 --> 00:03:44.460
with new language features that
make things so much easier.

80
00:03:44.460 --> 00:03:45.005
>> Nice, very nice.

81
00:03:45.005 --> 00:03:47.734
So, how are we gonna learn JavaScript?

82
00:03:47.734 --> 00:03:51.568
And what's the easiest way,
I guess, to begin our journey,

83
00:03:51.568 --> 00:03:54.905
as we learn about the wonderful
world of JavaScript?

84
00:03:54.905 --> 00:03:56.500
>> Well, I had a time deciding.

85
00:03:56.500 --> 00:03:59.240
Because JavaScript has not only
stayed in the browser, but

86
00:03:59.240 --> 00:04:01.550
it's started to flow into other areas.

87
00:04:01.550 --> 00:04:04.790
But I think it's best to
start where JavaScript began.

88
00:04:04.790 --> 00:04:06.170
And that's in the browser.

89
00:04:06.170 --> 00:04:09.520
And in order to do that, I think we
need to do a little bit of setup.

90
00:04:09.520 --> 00:04:11.680
So, just to make sure we're
all on the same page.

91
00:04:11.680 --> 00:04:13.230
So, everybody can follow along.

92
00:04:13.230 --> 00:04:17.158
We're gonna do a little bit of setup,
with the browser as well as,

93
00:04:17.158 --> 00:04:20.030
basic text editors, and how to run things.

94
00:04:20.030 --> 00:04:24.460
So, I've actually decided to
use the Chrome browser, kind of

95
00:04:24.460 --> 00:04:28.780
a personal preference of mine, because I'm
very familiar with the developer tools.

96
00:04:28.780 --> 00:04:32.910
That's not to say that Opera, Firefox,
Safari do not have comparable tools.

97
00:04:34.130 --> 00:04:38.250
But Chrome is kinda my browser of choice.

98
00:04:38.250 --> 00:04:40.780
>> [LAUGH] Now I notice you
didn't mention Internet Explorer.

99
00:04:40.780 --> 00:04:41.789
Is there a reason for that?

100
00:04:41.789 --> 00:04:43.549
>> That's a great question!

101
00:04:43.549 --> 00:04:46.370
Now, the new Edge browser is not too bad.

102
00:04:46.370 --> 00:04:47.660
It's actually pretty nice.

103
00:04:47.660 --> 00:04:48.700
I've been using it lately.

104
00:04:48.700 --> 00:04:50.170
I enjoy the experience.

105
00:04:50.170 --> 00:04:53.430
I haven't messed around with
the development portion of that.

106
00:04:53.430 --> 00:04:57.490
Like the developer tools,
messing around within the internals.

107
00:04:57.490 --> 00:05:02.602
But in general, I stay away from Internet
Explorer itself, because it has some

108
00:05:02.602 --> 00:05:07.660
interesting implementation details,
that make my life hard as a developer.

109
00:05:07.660 --> 00:05:10.948
>> And as an intro to JavaScript,
we wanna just get in a platform where,

110
00:05:10.948 --> 00:05:14.579
we know things are gonna work, and
it's not my browser's limitations or,

111
00:05:14.579 --> 00:05:16.130
blocking anything.

112
00:05:16.130 --> 00:05:18.620
So Chrome, Firefox, one of those guys.

113
00:05:18.620 --> 00:05:19.600
>> Exactly.

114
00:05:19.600 --> 00:05:21.655
>> Okay.
>> Those will make your life very easy,

115
00:05:21.655 --> 00:05:25.108
lower the frustration, and
let's worry about learning, and not so

116
00:05:25.108 --> 00:05:27.087
much about [SOUND] this isn't working.

117
00:05:27.087 --> 00:05:29.860
>> [LAUGH]
>> So within this,

118
00:05:29.860 --> 00:05:32.352
I would like to just search for
Google Chrome.

119
00:05:32.352 --> 00:05:36.590
If you're one of those that still
use Internet Explorer, that's fine.

120
00:05:36.590 --> 00:05:39.630
Edge, I know a bunch of people who
were just using Edge straight out of

121
00:05:39.630 --> 00:05:40.510
the box on Windows 10.

122
00:05:40.510 --> 00:05:45.760
But, if we go and search for
Chrome, Google Chrome,

123
00:05:45.760 --> 00:05:51.140
it will auto detect, and you can download,
which you have to accept and install.

124
00:05:51.140 --> 00:05:54.980
Now I'm not going to install this,
I just wanted to show you where to get it.

125
00:05:54.980 --> 00:05:56.880
Because I already have Chrome installed.

126
00:05:58.720 --> 00:06:01.980
>> Now, secondly let's go ahead and
open Google Chrome.

127
00:06:04.340 --> 00:06:08.140
We do need to get a text editor,
that will make our life easier.

128
00:06:08.140 --> 00:06:11.480
Text editors are a choice, an opinion,

129
00:06:11.480 --> 00:06:15.190
kind of a very biased opinion,
for developers.

130
00:06:15.190 --> 00:06:18.290
You can use things like
text editor notepad.

131
00:06:18.290 --> 00:06:23.180
However, they will make your life, again,
more difficult than it needs to be.

132
00:06:23.180 --> 00:06:26.310
My preferred text editor of choice is,
ATOM.

133
00:06:26.310 --> 00:06:28.500
Which is put out by
a company called GitHub.

134
00:06:30.150 --> 00:06:33.390
Wonderful company, helps with version
control in very large projects.

135
00:06:33.390 --> 00:06:36.370
But they're building things to
make developers lives easier.

136
00:06:36.370 --> 00:06:39.100
When you go to Atom.io,

137
00:06:39.100 --> 00:06:42.910
then it will automatically detect your
platform, and give you the download link.

138
00:06:42.910 --> 00:06:45.620
Like mine says, download for Mac.

139
00:06:45.620 --> 00:06:48.930
If you have a Windows computer,
it would download for Windows.

140
00:06:48.930 --> 00:06:52.450
You have a Linux computer with a GUI,
it will say download for Linux.

141
00:06:52.450 --> 00:06:57.050
So it's a cross-platform, and
that's another reason that I've chosen it.

142
00:06:57.050 --> 00:07:01.135
Is to unify the experience,
between the platforms.

143
00:07:01.135 --> 00:07:01.783
>> Mm-hm, very good.

144
00:07:01.783 --> 00:07:06.220
>> So I'm not gonna download that either,
because I already have that installed.

145
00:07:06.220 --> 00:07:08.200
But, let's take a look at
the interface real quick.

146
00:07:11.040 --> 00:07:13.210
And so we have Atom open.

147
00:07:13.210 --> 00:07:18.443
And when you open Atom for the first time,
you will see you have a welcome screen.

148
00:07:18.443 --> 00:07:20.690
Typically, it opens an untitled document.

149
00:07:20.690 --> 00:07:23.330
And then,
things that you can do within Atom.

150
00:07:23.330 --> 00:07:24.890
Now I'm gonna stay away from that for

151
00:07:24.890 --> 00:07:30.480
now, just because we wanna get into
JavaScript and see how things work.

152
00:07:30.480 --> 00:07:31.780
So I'm gonna full screen this.

153
00:07:33.390 --> 00:07:40.570
And the question is, how am I gonna
get the browser up and running?

154
00:07:40.570 --> 00:07:42.320
What do I need to do?

155
00:07:42.320 --> 00:07:47.770
Well, I've actually created a starter
project, that is kinda the base level,

156
00:07:47.770 --> 00:07:49.590
as simple as possible.

157
00:07:49.590 --> 00:07:53.960
And within this starter project
you'll notice there are two files.

158
00:07:53.960 --> 00:07:55.290
And kinda hard to see here.

159
00:07:57.492 --> 00:08:00.124
We'll take a look at those here
in just a moment, in Atom.

160
00:08:00.124 --> 00:08:04.610
Let's go ahead and open those.

161
00:08:04.610 --> 00:08:08.200
So I'm gonna go to file,
add project folder.

162
00:08:08.200 --> 00:08:09.640
And I've already got the starter.

163
00:08:09.640 --> 00:08:12.550
I just went to the starter template.

164
00:08:12.550 --> 00:08:16.090
And then I open the folder, and that
will actually open the entire folder and

165
00:08:16.090 --> 00:08:18.230
its contents, within the Atom text editor.

166
00:08:18.230 --> 00:08:23.400
Now that we have our project open in Atom,
I noticed that these are kind of hard

167
00:08:23.400 --> 00:08:29.420
to see but, we have at.js as well as,
index.html here.

168
00:08:29.420 --> 00:08:31.724
Those are both important files.

169
00:08:31.724 --> 00:08:35.922
Index.html, referenceapp.js and
here's app.js.

170
00:08:35.922 --> 00:08:37.740
Now, what does that mean?

171
00:08:37.740 --> 00:08:41.921
Well, in order to execute this in
a browser we need to open index.html in

172
00:08:41.921 --> 00:08:44.542
the browser, to make sure everything runs.

173
00:08:44.542 --> 00:08:47.078
And we will type,
a little bit of JavaScript,

174
00:08:47.078 --> 00:08:51.710
just to make sure everything's good to go,
and look at some of the Chrome dev tools.

175
00:08:53.650 --> 00:08:56.150
So, how do we get that inside of Chrome?

176
00:08:56.150 --> 00:09:01.890
If I open Chrome,
I can actually go to File > Open File, and

177
00:09:01.890 --> 00:09:08.450
navigate to that same folder and
file structure, that I have open in Atom.

178
00:09:08.450 --> 00:09:11.510
So it's on my desktop, and
I'm gonna start with starter template, and

179
00:09:11.510 --> 00:09:13.489
just open index.html.

180
00:09:15.340 --> 00:09:20.866
And you'll notice that, Chrome now
has that little bit of HTML that I

181
00:09:20.866 --> 00:09:26.296
have inside of index.html, but
is actually running the app.js,

182
00:09:26.296 --> 00:09:29.646
immediately, as soon as the page loads.

183
00:09:29.646 --> 00:09:31.090
Now, this is not very interesting.

184
00:09:31.090 --> 00:09:35.790
This is not where JavaScript is happening
for us, during the initial execution.

185
00:09:35.790 --> 00:09:38.013
You come over to the three little dots.

186
00:09:38.013 --> 00:09:40.414
I remember this used to
be the hamburger icon,

187
00:09:40.414 --> 00:09:43.990
if you're running an alternative
version of Chrome.

188
00:09:43.990 --> 00:09:47.900
There's a great deal of options here,
that a lot of people use,

189
00:09:47.900 --> 00:09:51.820
but I tend to go to the more tools,
and developer tools.

190
00:09:53.480 --> 00:09:58.290
Within developer tools,
there's several tabs here.

191
00:09:58.290 --> 00:10:01.632
If I go to elements, it will actually
just show me the HTML as rendered, and

192
00:10:01.632 --> 00:10:02.974
I can inspect through those.

193
00:10:02.974 --> 00:10:04.926
Handy if you need those.

194
00:10:04.926 --> 00:10:07.463
The console, is actually where
the job description output,

195
00:10:07.463 --> 00:10:09.280
if there is any output, would be rendered.

196
00:10:09.280 --> 00:10:14.348
So if I have to print something to
the screen, it will output here.

197
00:10:14.348 --> 00:10:20.746
And for a majority of the time, we will
be just outputting things to the screen,

198
00:10:20.746 --> 00:10:25.522
kind of diving around,
seeing how JavaScript interacts,

199
00:10:25.522 --> 00:10:28.692
within the browser execution engine.

200
00:10:28.692 --> 00:10:31.586
Now, these are the two most
important tabs for us, right now.

201
00:10:31.586 --> 00:10:34.369
There are additional tabs, such as source,

202
00:10:34.369 --> 00:10:38.338
which will show you what is
currently open within your browser.

203
00:10:38.338 --> 00:10:40.722
Give you a standard source tree.

204
00:10:40.722 --> 00:10:43.748
You have Network,
which is network requests.

205
00:10:43.748 --> 00:10:45.358
Timelines.

206
00:10:45.358 --> 00:10:49.873
Those are good to know if you have,

207
00:10:49.873 --> 00:10:55.646
such as a little,
I got a little typo there.

208
00:10:55.646 --> 00:10:56.526
>> Mm-hm.

209
00:10:56.526 --> 00:10:57.063
>> So network.

210
00:11:00.918 --> 00:11:04.558
So that shows that HTML was loaded, but
notice app.js was not loaded, within that.

211
00:11:04.558 --> 00:11:09.396
So if don't see app.js there,
then if I'm looking in the console for

212
00:11:09.396 --> 00:11:11.860
output, I will run into problems.

213
00:11:14.090 --> 00:11:18.116
And I can tell you, from experience,
that's incredibly frustrating.

214
00:11:18.116 --> 00:11:19.924
And you just go, why are you not working?

215
00:11:19.924 --> 00:11:20.884
I don't understand!

216
00:11:20.884 --> 00:11:23.810
And then when you hop
over to the network tab,

217
00:11:23.810 --> 00:11:28.518
you realize that app.js is not
actually loading, within the browser.

218
00:11:28.518 --> 00:11:31.760
So I'm gonna put that back.

219
00:11:31.760 --> 00:11:34.209
And, let's make sure that
this is fully loading, and

220
00:11:34.209 --> 00:11:35.818
there's no other issues going on.

221
00:11:35.818 --> 00:11:38.000
So the first thing I wanna say is, Hello.

222
00:11:38.000 --> 00:11:40.013
So I have console.log.

223
00:11:40.013 --> 00:11:47.400
Now console is in fact, this console here.

224
00:11:47.400 --> 00:11:51.206
And log just means,
log it to the console output.

225
00:11:51.206 --> 00:11:53.382
So kind of a standard in, standard out.

226
00:11:53.382 --> 00:11:59.014
Now within the browser context,
we have the ability for output mostly.

227
00:11:59.014 --> 00:12:03.686
There's a little bit of input, but
they're the really annoying inputs.

228
00:12:03.686 --> 00:12:08.570
You ever have those pop-ups that ask
you questions, and tell you things?

229
00:12:08.570 --> 00:12:12.304
I'm not a big fan of pop-ups,
just in your face all the time.

230
00:12:12.304 --> 00:12:15.711
But we may use them from time to time,
just for some simple user interaction.

231
00:12:17.330 --> 00:12:19.578
So-
>> Only if all coders could be like you.

232
00:12:19.578 --> 00:12:20.961
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah I know.

233
00:12:20.961 --> 00:12:23.831
I have some strong opinions on,
don't, no pop-ups.

234
00:12:23.831 --> 00:12:25.950
Pop-ups are bad.

235
00:12:25.950 --> 00:12:28.545
Now, I've changed this within my Atom.

236
00:12:30.240 --> 00:12:33.110
So in my text editor,
I've added code here.

237
00:12:33.110 --> 00:12:34.930
Notice, there are no blue dots up here.

238
00:12:36.190 --> 00:12:40.590
If I add just a space, that blue dot,

239
00:12:40.590 --> 00:12:44.570
a common issue is,
I've made a change in my JavaScript file.

240
00:12:44.570 --> 00:12:46.790
I forgot to save.

241
00:12:46.790 --> 00:12:49.330
I go back, try to run it.

242
00:12:50.480 --> 00:12:55.160
And, that printed hello, but
if I'd added something else as such.

243
00:13:05.082 --> 00:13:08.378
There it is, but
I'm gonna take this out, and not save.

244
00:13:08.378 --> 00:13:12.205
Notice that blue dot is there.

245
00:13:12.205 --> 00:13:14.220
I'm expecting only hello.

246
00:13:16.846 --> 00:13:22.738
But every time I refresh,
which is again executing that app.js file,

247
00:13:22.738 --> 00:13:25.204
I'm getting Hello, World.

248
00:13:25.204 --> 00:13:30.441
And because of that nature,
it's incredibly frustrating at times,

249
00:13:30.441 --> 00:13:33.648
and frankly, you gotta take small steps.

250
00:13:33.648 --> 00:13:35.488
Preventative measures to make sure,

251
00:13:35.488 --> 00:13:38.368
you lessen the amount of
frustration that you experience.

252
00:13:38.368 --> 00:13:42.832
So I'm gonna save here, and refresh.

253
00:13:42.832 --> 00:13:45.626
So if you see this, we're all set up and

254
00:13:45.626 --> 00:13:50.650
ready to start diving into JavaScript,
within the browser context.

255
00:13:52.070 --> 00:13:52.730
A couple of other things,

256
00:13:52.730 --> 00:13:57.330
because JavaScript is an interpreted
language, it runs from top to bottom.

257
00:13:59.380 --> 00:14:07.800
That means if I have an error, such as
this, this is not valid within JavaScript.

258
00:14:07.800 --> 00:14:12.452
And I go and refresh,
I will see errors such as this.

259
00:14:12.452 --> 00:14:15.470
This is the dreaded uncaught syntax error.

260
00:14:15.470 --> 00:14:18.390
I will highlight common
places that this will occur,

261
00:14:18.390 --> 00:14:22.570
as we go through the additional
concepts within JavaScript.

262
00:14:22.570 --> 00:14:29.600
This is a number one frustration point,
for beginning JavaScript programmers.

263
00:14:29.600 --> 00:14:30.990
Unexpected token.

264
00:14:30.990 --> 00:14:32.569
Where?
Who knows?

265
00:14:32.569 --> 00:14:34.729
>> [LAUGH]
>> However,

266
00:14:34.729 --> 00:14:39.088
I do wanna show you that another reason I
like Chrome, is over here there's a link.

267
00:14:39.088 --> 00:14:44.376
If I click the link,
Chrome will try its best to let you know,

268
00:14:44.376 --> 00:14:47.190
where that error has occurred.

269
00:14:47.190 --> 00:14:51.026
So console dot and there is the error.

270
00:14:51.026 --> 00:14:55.056
That's where it's occurred.

271
00:14:55.056 --> 00:14:59.750
So I can go fix that and, Don't do that.

272
00:15:04.272 --> 00:15:08.070
And now if I refresh,
notice that error has gone away.

273
00:15:08.070 --> 00:15:11.018
Notice we're in the sources tab.

274
00:15:11.018 --> 00:15:14.522
I have to go back to console,
and I now have no errors.

275
00:15:14.522 --> 00:15:17.434
>> So Justin,
I noticed when you did have that error,

276
00:15:17.434 --> 00:15:20.000
it did not fire the first line, the Hello.

277
00:15:20.000 --> 00:15:22.756
So when you say it runs top to bottom,
are you saying that,

278
00:15:22.756 --> 00:15:26.610
either the entire thing executes without
error, or it doesn't execute at all?

279
00:15:26.610 --> 00:15:27.930
It's not gonna do part?

280
00:15:27.930 --> 00:15:29.282
Or some of it sometimes?

281
00:15:29.282 --> 00:15:31.270
>> Yeah it's very odd.

282
00:15:31.270 --> 00:15:33.910
So again, that's based on context.

283
00:15:33.910 --> 00:15:36.950
We have a very flat JavaScript file.

284
00:15:36.950 --> 00:15:39.630
And what I mean is,
there's no nested functions,

285
00:15:39.630 --> 00:15:43.320
there's no nested calls
to other functions.

286
00:15:43.320 --> 00:15:47.690
So what it will actually do,
is try to slurp in all of that, and

287
00:15:47.690 --> 00:15:49.888
do something called parsing.

288
00:15:49.888 --> 00:15:51.138
Make sure that the syntax is correct.

289
00:15:51.138 --> 00:15:54.800
Form the pragmatic abstractions
that it needs, in order to execute.

290
00:15:54.800 --> 00:15:59.280
So because of that,
since there's an error at the top level.

291
00:15:59.280 --> 00:16:04.073
And, what I mean by top level is this
file, is there's nothing nested in

292
00:16:04.073 --> 00:16:09.198
functions, or nested inside of other
files, because it's very top level.

293
00:16:09.198 --> 00:16:13.188
As it tries to slurp this in, and
interpret it, that error causes,

294
00:16:13.188 --> 00:16:14.734
[SOUND] execution to stop.

295
00:16:14.734 --> 00:16:17.454
>> But if that error had been
nested a few levels deep,

296
00:16:17.454 --> 00:16:21.198
we might have seen part of the page
execute, and then the error occur?

297
00:16:21.198 --> 00:16:22.046
>> Exactly.

298
00:16:22.046 --> 00:16:26.169
A common place that these errors can,
kinda wreck your life a little bit,

299
00:16:26.169 --> 00:16:30.360
are when you're dealing with button
clicks, or when you're dealing with

300
00:16:30.360 --> 00:16:35.530
functions, that are only called at certain
times, JavaScript will run through.

301
00:16:35.530 --> 00:16:39.416
Not always, it's kind of this
dynamism that makes it so powerful,

302
00:16:39.416 --> 00:16:41.710
but incredibly frustrating.

303
00:16:41.710 --> 00:16:44.188
There are times where, the portions
nested within those functions,

304
00:16:44.188 --> 00:16:45.282
they're kinda disregarded.

305
00:16:45.282 --> 00:16:50.416
It only knows about the function itself.

306
00:16:50.416 --> 00:16:55.384
And then when you click that button,
stuff is broke.

307
00:16:55.384 --> 00:16:56.472
And that's called a runtime error.

308
00:16:56.472 --> 00:16:58.700
But it will immediately show you,
hey, something is broke.

309
00:16:59.930 --> 00:17:02.584
Now, I will say this.
Chrome and current JavaScript

310
00:17:02.584 --> 00:17:08.570
interpreters, are a great deal better at
that these days, than they used to be.

311
00:17:08.570 --> 00:17:12.930
And for the most part,
it catches errors like that, fairly well.

312
00:17:12.930 --> 00:17:15.288
>> All right, and
then just another question for you.

313
00:17:15.288 --> 00:17:19.940
We've been talking about JavaScript, and
we've said that it's a scripting language.

314
00:17:19.940 --> 00:17:27.190
Different from say, a programming
language, like C# or something like that?

315
00:17:27.190 --> 00:17:31.302
>> So, when I say scripting language,
it was originally meant for

316
00:17:31.302 --> 00:17:36.344
tiny little snippets, small pieces of
functionality to be added to the page.

317
00:17:36.344 --> 00:17:42.000
It is, in this context, this day and age,
a full-fledged programming language.

318
00:17:42.000 --> 00:17:46.194
With the advent of, as we'll talk
about some other time, NodeJS,

319
00:17:46.194 --> 00:17:50.538
which will actually allow you to
write JavaScript-based programs,

320
00:17:50.538 --> 00:17:54.832
as desktop applications, or
even as server-based applications.

321
00:17:54.832 --> 00:17:56.794
>> All right Justin,
great look there at JavaScript, and

322
00:17:56.794 --> 00:17:59.790
what we're getting ourselves into, over
the course of these next few episodes.

323
00:17:59.790 --> 00:18:00.970
We appreciate that.

324
00:18:00.970 --> 00:18:03.180
We hope everybody out there
enjoyed watching this one.

325
00:18:03.180 --> 00:18:06.270
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Mike Rodrick.

326
00:18:06.270 --> 00:18:07.260
>> And I'm Justin Dennison.

327
00:18:07.260 --> 00:18:14.224
>> And we'll see you next time.

328
00:18:14.224 --> 00:18:16.202
[MUSIC]

329
00:18:16.202 --> 00:18:20.249
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Mike discuss values and operators. They demonstrate using single and multi-line comments within JavaScript. They also look at binary, unary, comparison and logical operators.
episodes.title: Values and Operators
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.280 --> 00:00:02.460
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.460 --> 00:00:04.460
>> We're creating vector graphics.

3
00:00:04.460 --> 00:00:06.665
>> Live from San Francisco.

4
00:00:06.665 --> 00:00:08.469
>> [CROSSTALK]
>> Photoshop can show you-

5
00:00:08.469 --> 00:00:12.640
>> You're watching ITProTV.

6
00:00:12.640 --> 00:00:16.330
>> Hello, welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

7
00:00:16.330 --> 00:00:17.560
I'm your host, Mike Rodrick.

8
00:00:17.560 --> 00:00:19.552
And today we're doing our
introduction to JavaScript.

9
00:00:19.552 --> 00:00:22.803
And in this episode,
we're gonna be focusing in on values,

10
00:00:22.803 --> 00:00:26.779
what the heck they are, and operators
that we can use within JavaScript.

11
00:00:26.779 --> 00:00:30.019
And here to guide us through
the process is Mr. Justin Dennison.

12
00:00:30.019 --> 00:00:31.864
Welcome back, Justin.

13
00:00:31.864 --> 00:00:32.448
>> Thanks for having me back, Mike.

14
00:00:32.448 --> 00:00:36.250
I'm excited to talk about
JavaScript values and operators.

15
00:00:36.250 --> 00:00:38.560
But it kinda sounds
a little bit like math.

16
00:00:38.560 --> 00:00:41.662
And I know that scares some people.

17
00:00:41.662 --> 00:00:42.172
It makes me happy.
>> [LAUGH]

18
00:00:42.172 --> 00:00:44.700
>> But some people are like, no.

19
00:00:44.700 --> 00:00:47.880
So I think the best way
is just to kinda dive in.

20
00:00:47.880 --> 00:00:52.970
But just remember, sometimes this will
be kind of off-putting, a little odd.

21
00:00:52.970 --> 00:00:56.630
Keep persisting, and
things will slowly come around.

22
00:00:56.630 --> 00:01:00.620
I know there are times where I'm like,
that doesn't make any sense.

23
00:01:00.620 --> 00:01:04.820
And if I just keep poking away at it,
it will eventually kind of just, bing.

24
00:01:04.820 --> 00:01:06.360
>> Nice.
>> Light on for me.

25
00:01:06.360 --> 00:01:10.940
So in order to get started, we're
gonna go back to our starter project,

26
00:01:10.940 --> 00:01:12.830
our starter template.

27
00:01:12.830 --> 00:01:17.910
And so within Atom,
I'm going to File > Add Project Folder.

28
00:01:17.910 --> 00:01:20.580
And I've actually renamed
the starter template to Values and

29
00:01:20.580 --> 00:01:22.815
Operators, how appropriate.

30
00:01:22.815 --> 00:01:25.813
>> [LAUGH]
>> And it's just an exact copy of

31
00:01:25.813 --> 00:01:31.556
the previous project,
an empty app.js and an empty index.html,

32
00:01:31.556 --> 00:01:35.500
other than this very
basic boilerplate code.

33
00:01:36.600 --> 00:01:41.150
Also, I'm gonna go ahead and
open that index.html within Chrome.

34
00:01:41.150 --> 00:01:46.526
So Open File, and
navigate to the appropriate index.html.

35
00:01:46.526 --> 00:01:49.950
Now, the index.html is
a file convention name.

36
00:01:49.950 --> 00:01:51.800
This kinda persisted throughout the years.

37
00:01:51.800 --> 00:01:56.755
So be very careful that you're actually
opening the correct index.html for

38
00:01:56.755 --> 00:02:01.690
the project that you're working on,
the sandbox that you're playing around in.

39
00:02:01.690 --> 00:02:04.830
Because there's nothing worse than,
I'm writing.

40
00:02:04.830 --> 00:02:07.650
And then you go to refresh and
nothing happens,

41
00:02:07.650 --> 00:02:09.910
because you've been
changing the wrong thing.

42
00:02:09.910 --> 00:02:10.830
>> Been there, done that.

43
00:02:10.830 --> 00:02:11.910
It's like, okay, at this point,

44
00:02:11.910 --> 00:02:15.650
I'm just gonna make the background of this
page blue, just to make something obvious.

45
00:02:15.650 --> 00:02:16.670
And it still doesn't change.

46
00:02:16.670 --> 00:02:17.300
And you realize,

47
00:02:18.350 --> 00:02:22.160
I'm on an index page that's in a subfolder
that's not being used, and yeah.

48
00:02:22.160 --> 00:02:24.130
>> Yeah, I've done it several times.

49
00:02:24.130 --> 00:02:29.550
And it's happened to me so many times
that I'm almost obsessive about it now.

50
00:02:29.550 --> 00:02:30.435
So it's a little crazy.

51
00:02:30.435 --> 00:02:34.150
And then, finally, we wanna go ahead and
open our Chrome DevTools.

52
00:02:35.160 --> 00:02:39.120
If you're on a different platform,
these DevTools can sometimes be

53
00:02:39.120 --> 00:02:42.730
nested a little different, like these
menu options can be a little different.

54
00:02:42.730 --> 00:02:44.360
So just watch out for that.

55
00:02:44.360 --> 00:02:46.080
But I'm gonna open the developer tools.

56
00:02:46.080 --> 00:02:48.230
And I wanna make sure
that the console's open.

57
00:02:48.230 --> 00:02:51.900
This page kinda just
hangs out on the side.

58
00:02:51.900 --> 00:02:54.300
Most of our action will
be going on within here.

59
00:02:55.700 --> 00:02:58.990
So within JavaScript,

60
00:02:58.990 --> 00:03:03.280
I want to start with something before
we get into the values and operators.

61
00:03:03.280 --> 00:03:05.910
And that's the concept of comments.

62
00:03:05.910 --> 00:03:07.270
And comments are there for

63
00:03:07.270 --> 00:03:12.000
you, for me, for anyone who's coming
to read your code, or is notes for

64
00:03:12.000 --> 00:03:16.460
you when you come back six months
later and go, wonder what that does.

65
00:03:16.460 --> 00:03:17.920
And I've done that.

66
00:03:17.920 --> 00:03:21.360
So it's really important to have
at least some basic comment.

67
00:03:21.360 --> 00:03:24.570
Within JavaScript,
comments can happen two ways.

68
00:03:24.570 --> 00:03:32.540
I can have a block-level comment,
as such, which is a /** and then a /.

69
00:03:32.540 --> 00:03:37.920
And then I can have either this * here,
or I cannot.

70
00:03:37.920 --> 00:03:39.370
Now, I think I misspoke there.

71
00:03:39.370 --> 00:03:42.870
There's actually another
closing * here at the bottom.

72
00:03:42.870 --> 00:03:47.660
So an open /* and a close */.

73
00:03:47.660 --> 00:03:51.133
>> [LAUGH]
>> Now, I can type whatever I want to,

74
00:03:51.133 --> 00:03:55.210
including valid JavaScript,
as we've seen before.

75
00:03:57.380 --> 00:04:00.350
So we looked at this in
the previous episode.

76
00:04:01.460 --> 00:04:04.106
But if I go and refresh, nothing happens.

77
00:04:04.106 --> 00:04:07.380
And that's because comments are not for
the interpreter.

78
00:04:07.380 --> 00:04:10.290
It's not for
the JavaScript execution environment.

79
00:04:10.290 --> 00:04:12.010
It's for me, it's for you.

80
00:04:12.010 --> 00:04:13.490
It's for
anybody that needs to look at your code.

81
00:04:13.490 --> 00:04:21.080
In addition to, I can type for
days within these block comments.

82
00:04:21.080 --> 00:04:22.630
Obviously, that's a horrible comment.

83
00:04:22.630 --> 00:04:23.825
Don't comment like that.

84
00:04:23.825 --> 00:04:27.765
>> [LAUGH]
>> But these are handy if I need to give

85
00:04:27.765 --> 00:04:32.783
a lengthy description of what's going
on below or some block of code.

86
00:04:35.138 --> 00:04:36.540
So this is a block comment.

87
00:04:36.540 --> 00:04:38.820
There's also single-line comments.

88
00:04:38.820 --> 00:04:41.200
Might help if I spell that correctly.

89
00:04:41.200 --> 00:04:42.610
So this is a single-line comment.

90
00:04:45.851 --> 00:04:49.360
Now, this comment works very
similar to the block comment.

91
00:04:49.360 --> 00:04:51.970
However, with the //, no *,

92
00:04:51.970 --> 00:04:56.630
I only get that single line to
type my note or my comment on.

93
00:04:56.630 --> 00:05:02.240
If I hit Enter, I have my Atom set up
to autocomplete additional comments.

94
00:05:02.240 --> 00:05:05.570
But most of the time, when you hit Enter,
it'll just come to the next line.

95
00:05:06.670 --> 00:05:10.980
But this is actually gonna be seen by
the interpreter and not commented out.

96
00:05:10.980 --> 00:05:11.901
So this will actually cause errors.

97
00:05:11.901 --> 00:05:16.680
So be very careful about block
level versus single line.

98
00:05:16.680 --> 00:05:21.360
For very short snippets, like little
block headings, I'll use single line.

99
00:05:21.360 --> 00:05:24.067
If I need additional descriptions
about what's going on,

100
00:05:24.067 --> 00:05:25.806
I'll use the block-level comment.

101
00:05:25.806 --> 00:05:29.888
>> All right, so I've seen these being
used, those block-level comments,

102
00:05:29.888 --> 00:05:33.968
at the beginning of a page, where it's
talking about maybe who created it,

103
00:05:33.968 --> 00:05:36.493
distribution rights, and things like that.

104
00:05:36.493 --> 00:05:39.243
Could you also use this
to troubleshoot code,

105
00:05:39.243 --> 00:05:44.179
like occasionally blocking out a section
of code to see if it works any better?

106
00:05:44.179 --> 00:05:49.210
>> That's kinda the very first thing you
learn, is, well, what if I take this out?

107
00:05:49.210 --> 00:05:50.280
Is it still broken?

108
00:05:50.280 --> 00:05:52.528
And yes, I'll do that.

109
00:05:52.528 --> 00:05:57.330
And these rich-text editors, whether it
be Atom or some other one that you found,

110

337
00:21:36.906 --> 00:21:40.995
There's only one way to find out and
that's what I like.

338
00:21:40.995 --> 00:21:46.701
So notice these are kind of loose in
their definition of what is less than,

339
00:21:46.701 --> 00:21:52.240
and you have to be careful because
that can run into some issues for you.

340
00:21:52.240 --> 00:21:58.380
Likewise, I'm just using some
keyboard shortcuts there.

341
00:21:58.380 --> 00:22:03.360
If you're using Adam, the command d or
the control d on Windows will

342
00:22:03.360 --> 00:22:06.030
actually duplicates the line and
puts it right under there.

343
00:22:06.030 --> 00:22:09.060
It's handy for things of this nature.

344
00:22:10.190 --> 00:22:12.430
And notice this is less than or
equal to and

345
00:22:12.430 --> 00:22:15.570
I'm going to change this
to three just to see.

346
00:22:17.420 --> 00:22:21.214
And notice those are less than or
equal too.

347
00:22:21.214 --> 00:22:26.700
So, shouldn't these both evaluate to true,
right?

348
00:22:26.700 --> 00:22:28.860
These evaluate to true so
everything's good.

349
00:22:30.010 --> 00:22:35.361
But, if I take this sign and
flip it around,

350
00:22:38.168 --> 00:22:40.560
So now I have x is greater than 5.

351
00:22:40.560 --> 00:22:41.439
Is 3 greater than 5?

352
00:22:41.439 --> 00:22:42.183
Is 3 greater than 5?

353
00:22:42.183 --> 00:22:46.110
This is where I'm getting
kind of interested.

354
00:22:46.110 --> 00:22:50.800
Is that data gonna be
pushed to the same type?

355
00:22:51.850 --> 00:22:52.965
Is x greater than or equal to 3?

356
00:22:52.965 --> 00:22:56.728
Is x greater than or
equal to the string 3.

357
00:22:56.728 --> 00:23:03.560
So if we look at the output,
is x greater than 5 either time?

358
00:23:03.560 --> 00:23:05.060
The answer is false, which means no.

359
00:23:06.160 --> 00:23:10.620
Is it greater than or equal to 3,
both times it is true.

360
00:23:10.620 --> 00:23:14.350
So these are wonderful
comparison operators.

361
00:23:14.350 --> 00:23:19.150
And notice that we have are they equal,
are they not equal?

362
00:23:19.150 --> 00:23:20.650
Are there less than, less than or

363
00:23:20.650 --> 00:23:23.160
equal to, greater than,
greater than or equal to.

364
00:23:24.190 --> 00:23:26.764
Now, these always return this true, false.

365
00:23:26.764 --> 00:23:32.890
And, up until this point, we've only
had these blue and black characters.

366
00:23:32.890 --> 00:23:38.435
Notice these true or
false is in kind of a purplish red colour.

367
00:23:38.435 --> 00:23:42.880
And that's because it's true and
false are reserved, they are special, they

368
00:23:42.880 --> 00:23:47.590
mean something to JavaScript themselves
and that's how questions are answered.

369
00:23:47.590 --> 00:23:51.022
True would be the answer yes,
false would be the answer no.

370
00:23:51.022 --> 00:23:56.401
So, I have these comparison types,
if I have true and false,

371
00:23:56.401 --> 00:24:02.308
I want to know sometimes can I ask
a question is, X and Y, both true.

372
00:24:02.308 --> 00:24:05.690
So is it going to rain and is it cold?

373
00:24:06.690 --> 00:24:09.700
Do I have a ham sandwich and this it good?

374
00:24:09.700 --> 00:24:13.990
Or are we going to the movies or
are we going to the go kart track?

375
00:24:13.990 --> 00:24:18.460
So I have these logical
operations that I can make,

376
00:24:20.130 --> 00:24:24.330
and those are great for
future decision making that we would need.

377
00:24:24.330 --> 00:24:26.570
So the two types of logical operators, and

378
00:24:26.570 --> 00:24:29.590
I'm gonna use that reserved word true and
false.

379
00:24:29.590 --> 00:24:35.640
The literals here and
we'll see how that works in this context.

380
00:24:35.640 --> 00:24:41.500
And you'll have to excuse me there's
always cuts away the bottom white space.

381
00:24:41.500 --> 00:24:43.730
So I'll try to keep this up here for
everyone.

382
00:24:43.730 --> 00:24:49.840
So if I say true and then if I type
the ampersand twice, that means and.

383
00:24:51.120 --> 00:24:52.440
So true and true.

384
00:24:52.440 --> 00:24:55.430
You gotta watch it.

385
00:24:55.430 --> 00:24:56.640
True and true.

386
00:24:56.640 --> 00:25:00.080
So if the first statement is true, for

387
00:25:00.080 --> 00:25:03.470
instance, is X greater than or
equal to three?

388
00:25:03.470 --> 00:25:05.038
Is three greater than or equal to three?

389
00:25:05.038 --> 00:25:06.536
True.

390
00:25:06.536 --> 00:25:11.090
Is X less than or equal to three,
that would also be true.

391
00:25:11.090 --> 00:25:13.560
So those could both be statements there.

392
00:25:13.560 --> 00:25:19.160
So true and true,
this will always evaluate to true.

393
00:25:19.160 --> 00:25:20.950
So, two trues so then double n percent.

394
00:25:22.030 --> 00:25:26.130
And if I want to check that out and
we're gonna roll on in the console here.

395
00:25:26.130 --> 00:25:30.990
So, I'll show you that block
commenting you were talking about Mike.

396
00:25:30.990 --> 00:25:36.821
So, if you highlight the portion that you
want to comment out and hold command/,

397
00:25:36.821 --> 00:25:42.580
or control/ on Windows, then it will
actually block comment out all of that.

398
00:25:42.580 --> 00:25:45.433
And then if you do it again,
it will un-comment it.

399
00:25:45.433 --> 00:25:48.425
So those are handy
operations to know about.

400
00:25:49.790 --> 00:25:55.062
So I have true && true, and we'll see
what these outputs are in just a moment.

401
00:25:55.062 --> 00:25:58.065
true && false.

402
00:26:01.885 --> 00:26:07.200
False && true and false && false.

403
00:26:07.200 --> 00:26:11.470
These are all the possible combinations
with again this is technically

404
00:26:11.470 --> 00:26:15.900
a binary operator but it's a different
type cuz it takes two operands.

405
00:26:15.900 --> 00:26:17.830
A beginning and an end.

406
00:26:17.830 --> 00:26:19.280
A one and a two so to speak.

407
00:26:20.310 --> 00:26:23.365
These are all the possible combinations
that I can have with a single

408
00:26:23.365 --> 00:26:24.110
end statement.

409
00:26:25.570 --> 00:26:27.880
So true && true,
true && false, false && true.

410
00:26:27.880 --> 00:26:29.420
And if I refresh,

411
00:26:29.420 --> 00:26:34.290
notice the only time ends are true
is when both of them are true.

412
00:26:34.290 --> 00:26:37.160
So that's kind of a way to safeguard.

413
00:26:37.160 --> 00:26:39.030
Both of these things have to be true.

414
00:26:40.428 --> 00:26:45.050
And when I'm doing more complex
programming in order for

415
00:26:45.050 --> 00:26:47.920
this statement to occur.

416
00:26:47.920 --> 00:26:54.623
Now, within the true statement,
we have kind of a change in true,

417
00:26:54.623 --> 00:27:00.383
and I just noticed that I have
this commented wrong here.

418
00:27:05.744 --> 00:27:10.090
This && can also be double vertical pipes.

419
00:27:10.090 --> 00:27:12.750
Now this is kind of a weird key.

420
00:27:12.750 --> 00:27:16.000
On my Mac it actually looks like a solid,
vertical pipe.

421
00:27:16.000 --> 00:27:21.300
However on some Windows computers, it's
right above the enter, or the return key,

422
00:27:21.300 --> 00:27:26.150
it'll look like a vertical pipe
with a space missing in the middle.

423
00:27:26.150 --> 00:27:29.360
It looks like a weird equal sign or
something like that.

424
00:27:29.360 --> 00:27:32.010
>> Yes, or
like a colon using vertical dashes.

425
00:27:32.010 --> 00:27:34.125
>> Yeah, yeah so
be very careful about that.

426
00:27:34.125 --> 00:27:37.370
That usually located right
above the enter return and

427
00:27:37.370 --> 00:27:39.980
will take a shift in order to get that.

428
00:27:39.980 --> 00:27:45.280
Now I use some keyboard short-cutting
magic just to replace all of the

429
00:27:45.280 --> 00:27:46.270
>> I saw that.

430
00:27:46.270 --> 00:27:46.970
>> You saw.

431
00:27:46.970 --> 00:27:51.800
So knowing your tools is a very
important part of being a developer.

432
00:27:51.800 --> 00:27:53.600
It'll make your life a great deal easier.

433
00:27:55.010 --> 00:27:59.160
So this, this actually means or.

434
00:27:59.160 --> 00:28:02.800
Are we going to the go-kart track or
are we going bowling?

435
00:28:02.800 --> 00:28:07.900
So true or true, true or false,
false or true, false or false.

436
00:28:07.900 --> 00:28:12.040
If we look at the output
there the only time that or

437
00:28:12.040 --> 00:28:16.930
is false is when I have both falses.

438
00:28:16.930 --> 00:28:20.252
So this is false, and

439
00:28:20.252 --> 00:28:24.590
otherwise This is true.

440
00:28:25.990 --> 00:28:29.989
So this is a way to make sure
that either one works and

441
00:28:29.989 --> 00:28:32.873
I don't really care which one it is.

442
00:28:32.873 --> 00:28:36.928
It can be x > 3 or x < 5.

443
00:28:36.928 --> 00:28:39.100
It doesn't matter to me which one is true.

444
00:28:40.290 --> 00:28:41.510
I can safeguard against that.

445
00:28:42.930 --> 00:28:46.950
Now finally, there's some additional,
they're not operators.

446
00:28:46.950 --> 00:28:52.680
It's a way to interact with
numbers if you need to make some

447
00:28:52.680 --> 00:28:58.310
calculations that are not quite as
common like plus, divide, multiply.

448
00:28:58.310 --> 00:29:00.390
This is the built-in math module.

449
00:29:00.390 --> 00:29:02.830
This is within the browser mostly.

450
00:29:02.830 --> 00:29:05.180
And they're adding features
to this all the time.

451
00:29:06.230 --> 00:29:14.030
Some common operations within
the math module are as follows.

452
00:29:14.030 --> 00:29:17.240
And these come in, I do a little
bit of scientific programming,

453
00:29:17.240 --> 00:29:21.840
so I need these for
data visualization from time to time.

454
00:29:21.840 --> 00:29:25.759
We have seal, which if I take 1.3.

455
00:29:25.759 --> 00:29:29.820
Let's see what that does and
don't forget the semi colon.

456
00:29:29.820 --> 00:29:32.255
In a browser you forget the semi colon,
it'll wreck your day.

457
00:29:32.255 --> 00:29:32.980
>> [LAUGH]
>> And

458
00:29:34.700 --> 00:29:37.702
notice the seal is actually
called the sealing.

459
00:29:37.702 --> 00:29:39.650
I'm gonna go to the next
largest whole number.

460
00:29:41.400 --> 00:29:45.130
And if there's a seal,
>> Gotta be a floor.

461
00:29:45.130 --> 00:29:45.820
>> I like it, Mike.

462
00:29:45.820 --> 00:29:46.395
You're catching on.

463
00:29:46.395 --> 00:29:48.290
>> [LAUGH]
>> It's making me happy.

464
00:29:48.290 --> 00:29:54.458
So the floor actually more or less just
chops off the decimal place of the number.

465
00:29:54.458 --> 00:29:59.840
And there is an abs,

466
00:29:59.840 --> 00:30:04.620
which is if I take a negative
number I get the positive,

467
00:30:04.620 --> 00:30:08.900
I get the positive regardless of what
I get in there the absolute value.

468
00:30:08.900 --> 00:30:11.646
And finally a common one that I will use.

469
00:30:15.696 --> 00:30:19.226
Is square root.

470
00:30:19.226 --> 00:30:21.781
I like to think of it as Math.sqrt.

471
00:30:21.781 --> 00:30:23.927
>> [LAUGH]
>> But helps me remember what it is,

472
00:30:23.927 --> 00:30:26.305
that the square root of 16 is in fact 4.

473
00:30:27.760 --> 00:30:33.150
Now, the math module has a plethora
of built in functions beyond that.

474
00:30:33.150 --> 00:30:37.280
I tend to just look
those up as I need them.

475
00:30:37.280 --> 00:30:38.820
But these are very useful.

476
00:30:39.880 --> 00:30:42.170
All right fantastic look there.

477
00:30:42.170 --> 00:30:44.130
A lot of information
make sure you go back and

478
00:30:44.130 --> 00:30:47.700
watch this one a couple times cuz this is
that foundational knowledge that we really

479
00:30:47.700 --> 00:30:50.120
need to be successful with our JavaScript.

480
00:30:50.120 --> 00:30:56.310
We're talking about the values that we
can store, as well as the operators and

481
00:30:56.310 --> 00:31:00.720
that is incredibly powerful cuz we
start being able to manipulate data and

482
00:31:00.720 --> 00:31:04.535
compare data that maybe we're storing or
retrieving from users.

483
00:31:04.535 --> 00:31:07.800
So powerful stuff there really
make sure you pay attention.

484
00:31:07.800 --> 00:31:11.900
We appreciate that great explanations,
great demonstrations from you Justin.

485
00:31:11.900 --> 00:31:13.860
Hope everyone out there
enjoyed watching this one.

486
00:31:13.860 --> 00:31:17.060
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Mike Rodrick.

487
00:31:17.060 --> 00:31:18.220
>> And I'm Justin Dennison.

488
00:31:18.220 --> 00:31:20.811
>> And we'll see you next time.

489
00:31:20.811 --> 00:31:26.656
[MUSIC]

490
00:31:26.656 --> 00:31:28.630
>> Thank you for watching ITPro TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Mike cover the fundamental data types in JavaScript. They use the typeof command to verify data types and look at explicit and implicit type conversion.
episodes.title: Types of Data
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:01.991
Welcome to ITPro TV, I'm your host.

2
00:00:01.991 --> 00:00:06.358
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.358 --> 00:00:08.811
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.811 --> 00:00:10.685
>> You're watching ITPro TV.

5
00:00:10.685 --> 00:00:12.135
[MUSIC]

6
00:00:12.135 --> 00:00:16.119
>> Hello, welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITPro TV.

7
00:00:16.119 --> 00:00:20.161
I'm your host Mike Rodrick and today we're
doing our Introduction to JavaScript.

8
00:00:20.161 --> 00:00:23.605
And in this episode we're gonna be
taking a look at types of data.

9
00:00:23.605 --> 00:00:27.031
And here to walk us through and
help us with that is Mr. Justin Dennison.

10
00:00:27.031 --> 00:00:28.080
How you doing, Justin?

11
00:00:28.080 --> 00:00:29.260
>> I'm doing well today, Mike.

12
00:00:29.260 --> 00:00:31.314
Thanks for having me back, I'm excited.

13
00:00:31.314 --> 00:00:33.018
Now, in the last few episodes,

14
00:00:33.018 --> 00:00:36.252
we've been kind of skirting over
the issue of types of data.

15
00:00:36.252 --> 00:00:38.750
I've been waving my hands a little bit.

16
00:00:38.750 --> 00:00:42.970
But I wanna start that deep dive,
it's gonna be kind of a layered dive.

17
00:00:42.970 --> 00:00:45.510
We're getting to those middle grounds.

18
00:00:46.760 --> 00:00:52.600
JavaScript is very lax on how it
assigns data types to variables.

19
00:00:52.600 --> 00:00:56.490
However the values that
are contained within them do have

20
00:00:56.490 --> 00:00:59.090
a specific type associated with them.

21
00:00:59.090 --> 00:01:04.530
And actually JavaScript, I have a list to
make sure I don't miss any, has several

22
00:01:04.530 --> 00:01:08.870
distinct fundamental data types and that
is string and number which we have seen.

23
00:01:08.870 --> 00:01:12.550
Boolean, which we've actually seen,
but I haven't said these are booleans.

24
00:01:12.550 --> 00:01:15.835
Booleans are those true or
false values that will evaluate,

25
00:01:15.835 --> 00:01:20.940
they're special for JavaScript and
then we have null and undefined which

26
00:01:20.940 --> 00:01:24.150
I'll come back to in just a moment and
then the concept of an object.

27
00:01:25.660 --> 00:01:31.200
Those null and undefined,
those are about having absence of value.

28
00:01:31.200 --> 00:01:34.310
If I declare a variable without
setting it equal to something

29
00:01:34.310 --> 00:01:36.450
then it's like an empty cup.

30
00:01:36.450 --> 00:01:37.360
It has nothing in it.

31
00:01:37.360 --> 00:01:39.940
If I go to the cupboards and
I haven't been grocery shopping, and

32
00:01:39.940 --> 00:01:42.740
I open up all the cupboards,
there's nothing there.

33
00:01:42.740 --> 00:01:44.650
I have undefined food.

34
00:01:44.650 --> 00:01:50.010
Likewise, null's kind of the result
of operations that don't play out.

35
00:01:50.010 --> 00:01:53.350
If I try to log or
do some manipulation and

36
00:01:53.350 --> 00:01:56.850
they don't quite play out,
I sometimes get a null value.

37
00:01:56.850 --> 00:01:58.700
Now an object's very interesting.

38
00:01:58.700 --> 00:02:02.890
And we'll do an additional analysis
later on of what an object is.

39
00:02:02.890 --> 00:02:04.220
But for all intents and

40
00:02:04.220 --> 00:02:08.510
purposes, I like to think of objects
initially as things around us.

41
00:02:08.510 --> 00:02:11.910
The cup, the computers that we have,
those are all objects,

42
00:02:11.910 --> 00:02:13.645
they have properties and behaviors.

43
00:02:13.645 --> 00:02:18.370
[COUGH] I think the best way to see how

44
00:02:18.370 --> 00:02:22.800
data is presented within JavaScript
is learning how to utilize

45
00:02:22.800 --> 00:02:27.545
some of the JavaScript tools within
the browser to test those data types.

46
00:02:27.545 --> 00:02:30.605
If we take a look, I have Atom and
Chrome open on my computer.

47
00:02:30.605 --> 00:02:32.325
Currently have nothing within them, but

48
00:02:32.325 --> 00:02:36.195
we're going to quickly open one
of those projects within Atom.

49
00:02:36.195 --> 00:02:39.185
They're very similar to the starter
template projects from the previous

50
00:02:39.185 --> 00:02:39.955
episodes.

51
00:02:39.955 --> 00:02:42.565
They're just blank, but
I have them named accordingly.

52
00:02:43.635 --> 00:02:47.020
I put mine on my desktop
as everyone tends to do

53
00:02:47.020 --> 00:02:48.690
to if they need to find something easily.

54
00:02:48.690 --> 00:02:51.428
I don't, crazy stuff when we do that.

55
00:02:51.428 --> 00:02:55.790
But [COUGH] I have types of data here and
I'm gonna open that folder.

56
00:02:55.790 --> 00:03:00.010
Likewise I'm gonna quickly go into
Chrome just as a reminder, and

57
00:03:00.010 --> 00:03:04.520
open the file within Chrome that
corresponds to type of data.

58
00:03:04.520 --> 00:03:10.560
Now, remember you have to be careful about
which index.html you're opening if you

59
00:03:10.560 --> 00:03:15.579
have multiple ones of these available
to you because you'll fight and

60
00:03:15.579 --> 00:03:19.593
fight and fight with it, and
nothing will ever happen.

61
00:03:19.593 --> 00:03:24.194
Now additionally,
I'm going to open the tools and

62
00:03:24.194 --> 00:03:30.729
go to developer tools so I can actually
see all of my JavaScript running.

63
00:03:33.033 --> 00:03:36.300
Make that a little bit larger for
you, and we should be good to go.

64
00:03:36.300 --> 00:03:39.830
Now, within JavaScript, as I said,
we have those data types.

65
00:03:39.830 --> 00:03:44.570
String, object, boolean,
null, undefined and number.

66
00:03:44.570 --> 00:03:47.950
But, how would I know
if I have a variable?

67
00:03:49.160 --> 00:03:51.930
This variable is available
to me somewhere else.

68
00:03:51.930 --> 00:03:55.490
I know, because I've declared
this variable that it's a number.

69
00:03:55.490 --> 00:04:00.390
But, if this is part of a larger program,
I have no idea what this is or if it's

70
00:04:00.390 --> 00:04:04.440
being passed around from function to
function, which we will talk about later.

71
00:04:04.440 --> 00:04:07.280
Then its really hard to keep track of

72
00:04:07.280 --> 00:04:09.660
what kind of information
is this represented.

73
00:04:09.660 --> 00:04:13.420
Now intrinsically
the information is the same.

74
00:04:13.420 --> 00:04:16.290
If I think of it as a recipe,
if I add eggs, flour,

75
00:04:16.290 --> 00:04:20.818
sugar a little bit of chocolate,
well separately they're just eggs,

76
00:04:20.818 --> 00:04:22.940
flour and a little bit of chocolate but

77
00:04:22.940 --> 00:04:28.440
if I put them together with a little bit
of magic sometimes it gets a little wonky.

Now this is kind of a wierd syntax.

00:19:25.120 --> 00:19:31.810
We'll get to that later, but
these are all explicit type conversions.

314
00:19:31.810 --> 00:19:35.350
Now, in comparison,
we have implicit type conversions.

315
00:19:39.198 --> 00:19:40.580
And we've seen those.

316
00:19:42.882 --> 00:19:46.758
In things such as is 3 equal to 3 and

317
00:19:46.758 --> 00:19:50.520
compare that with triple equals.

318
00:19:52.750 --> 00:19:58.140
Well if we look the first one with
the two equal signs, excuse me,

319
00:19:58.140 --> 00:20:03.054
evaluates to true, but
the second one evaluates to false.

320
00:20:03.054 --> 00:20:06.054
This one will do that type conversion, or

321
00:20:06.054 --> 00:20:12.490
it will coerce one to the other as best
it can, and then compare their values.

322
00:20:12.490 --> 00:20:17.472
So, there's the letter, excuse me, the
string representation, in between quotes.

323
00:20:17.472 --> 00:20:22.972
If I make that kinda look like this other
thing or vice versa are they then equal?

324
00:20:22.972 --> 00:20:31.200
So this is an example of implicit,
Conversion between data types.

325
00:20:32.440 --> 00:20:36.530
Now again this is handy to know,
what you need to keep track of.

326
00:20:36.530 --> 00:20:40.735
Because something may evaluate to true,
when in fact,

327
00:20:40.735 --> 00:20:43.959
you wanted the triple equals evaluation.

328
00:20:43.959 --> 00:20:48.753
Likewise, if we change this 1=

329
00:20:48.753 --> 00:20:54.800
sign to an !, this one is implicit.

330
00:20:54.800 --> 00:20:59.506
This one does not do type conversion,
it compares the values as is.

331
00:20:59.506 --> 00:21:00.860
Including the type.

332
00:21:00.860 --> 00:21:03.210
So, this one is checking,
are they the same type?

333
00:21:03.210 --> 00:21:04.982
Is a string equal to a number?

334
00:21:04.982 --> 00:21:06.650
No, they're not the same type.

335
00:21:09.482 --> 00:21:12.712
But, since this is not,
it's the opposite of that.

336
00:21:12.712 --> 00:21:15.930
You have to be careful of that.

337
00:21:15.930 --> 00:21:19.880
Now, there's a plethora of other ones.

338
00:21:19.880 --> 00:21:23.100
But we're gonna lightly
touch on a few more.

339
00:21:25.876 --> 00:21:29.008
And if we look here, remember,

340
00:21:29.008 --> 00:21:33.590
up here this is number
equals number of false.

341
00:21:33.590 --> 00:21:37.430
So converting false to
a number gives us 0.

342
00:21:37.430 --> 00:21:42.909
Well, If I

343
00:21:42.909 --> 00:21:47.104
compare this with == or ===, again,

344
00:21:47.104 --> 00:21:53.640
implicit type conversion versus
no type conversion whatsoever.

345
00:21:53.640 --> 00:22:01.420
I in fact see that a string with nothing
in it is roughly equal to false.

346
00:22:01.420 --> 00:22:04.422
Likewise, I'm sure you know what this is,
Mike.

347
00:22:04.422 --> 00:22:10.490
>> [LAUGH]
>> If I say, is zero equal to false.

348
00:22:12.928 --> 00:22:17.610
Well, with double equals it is,
with triple equals, it is not.

349
00:22:17.610 --> 00:22:19.200
Because z number and

350
00:22:19.200 --> 00:22:22.940
the z boolean in triple equals,
so they do not equal themselves.

351
00:22:22.940 --> 00:22:24.666
>> Starting to remind me of politics.

352
00:22:24.666 --> 00:22:26.263
I mean, [LAUGH] as long as I change,

353
00:22:26.263 --> 00:22:29.710
I can get the answer I want just by
changing the operators I'm using.

354
00:22:29.710 --> 00:22:34.182
Yeah, yeah, and it's very, very tricky.

355
00:22:34.182 --> 00:22:36.685
But something to know, there are,

356
00:22:36.685 --> 00:22:41.410
within the JavaScript community,
there's kind of two sides.

357
00:22:41.410 --> 00:22:46.296
Some people say always use ===, or
the exclamation point with == so

358
00:22:46.296 --> 00:22:49.192
you know exactly what you're comparing.

359
00:22:49.192 --> 00:22:51.777
>> Basically preventing JavaScript
from doing any type of conversion

360
00:22:51.777 --> 00:22:53.485
in the background without your knowledge.

361
00:22:53.485 --> 00:22:58.425
>> Yea, and I think it helps people who
are beginning to track what's going on,

362
00:22:58.425 --> 00:23:01.242
because what you're reading is explicit.

363
00:23:01.242 --> 00:23:03.940
These things have to be exactly the same.

364
00:23:03.940 --> 00:23:09.634
But there are times where the ==, it does
help you keep your code a little cleaner.

365
00:23:09.634 --> 00:23:14.425
Like if i slurp in a bunch of text from
a source, you know, off the web or

366
00:23:14.425 --> 00:23:20.410
something, and I wanna see if the ticker
price for a given stock is within a range.

367
00:23:20.410 --> 00:23:25.183
I can use these kind of lax comparisons
to see, without doing all of

368
00:23:25.183 --> 00:23:29.542
this explicit conversion that
I would otherwise have to do.

369
00:23:29.542 --> 00:23:34.082
So, now that does lead us into that, but

370
00:23:34.082 --> 00:23:39.910
I think that might be best
seen in another episode.

371
00:23:39.910 --> 00:23:41.640
>> Yep, that sound good to me Justin.

372
00:23:41.640 --> 00:23:44.020
We are running a little
short of time on this one.

373
00:23:44.020 --> 00:23:45.860
Fantastic information though, love it.

374
00:23:45.860 --> 00:23:51.054
We've gotta understand our data types
as we get further on into JavaScript.

375
00:23:51.054 --> 00:23:52.330
Working with that data, storing that data.

376
00:23:52.330 --> 00:23:54.112
When we start to manipulate that data,

377
00:23:54.112 --> 00:23:57.848
understanding what data type we're dealing
with is gonna make a big difference.

378
00:23:57.848 --> 00:23:59.710
So, we appreciate that,
great examples there.

379
00:23:59.710 --> 00:24:00.542
We hope everybody enjoyed
watching this one.

380
00:24:00.542 --> 00:24:04.238
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Mike Roderick.

381
00:24:04.238 --> 00:24:06.302
>> And I'm Justin Demson.

382
00:24:06.302 --> 00:24:07.780
>> And we'll see you next time.

383
00:24:07.780 --> 00:24:11.228
[MUSIC]

384
00:24:11.228 --> 00:24:18.163
>> Thank you for watching ITPro.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Mike cover the fundamental data types in JavaScript. They use the console.log to show various types of data output such as Date, Error, RegExp and others.
episodes.title: Types of Data Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.880 --> 00:00:02.421
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.421 --> 00:00:05.789
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:05.789 --> 00:00:08.274
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.274 --> 00:00:11.558
You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:11.558 --> 00:00:15.074
>> Hello, welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

6
00:00:15.074 --> 00:00:16.904
I'm your host, Mike Rodrick, and

7
00:00:16.904 --> 00:00:19.649
today we're doing our
introduction to JavaScript.

8
00:00:19.649 --> 00:00:22.060
And in this episode,
we're actually doing a part two.

9
00:00:22.060 --> 00:00:25.940
We're continuing our thought
process on types of data.

10
00:00:25.940 --> 00:00:29.180
And here to continue the conversation
with us is Mr. Justin Dennison.

11
00:00:29.180 --> 00:00:30.130
Welcome back, Justin.

12
00:00:30.130 --> 00:00:31.439
>> Thanks for having me back, Mike.

13
00:00:31.439 --> 00:00:32.170
I'm excited.

14
00:00:32.170 --> 00:00:36.500
Data is dear and
truly dear to my heart, and

15
00:00:36.500 --> 00:00:39.610
I wanted to make sure we hit
all of those fine nuances.

16
00:00:39.610 --> 00:00:43.940
Now where we left off was talking
about implicit type conversions.

17
00:00:45.370 --> 00:00:50.357
Those implicit inversions like zero is
equal to false, and those operators triple

18
00:00:50.357 --> 00:00:55.148
equals versus double equals, kind of
allow that lax kind of melding together.

19
00:00:55.148 --> 00:01:00.788
But that's not quite all of the implicit
conversions that can occur.

20
00:01:00.788 --> 00:01:01.900
And I won't cover all of them, but

21
00:01:01.900 --> 00:01:04.370
there are some ones that you
should definitely be aware of.

22
00:01:04.370 --> 00:01:07.690
We saw that an empty string is
equal to false with double equals,

23
00:01:07.690 --> 00:01:11.510
we also saw that it is not equal
to false with triple equals.

24
00:01:11.510 --> 00:01:13.840
But let us take a look at
a couple of other ones,

25
00:01:13.840 --> 00:01:17.940
and I have up where we left off.

26
00:01:17.940 --> 00:01:19.500
And let's see.

27
00:01:19.500 --> 00:01:21.830
What is an object?

28
00:01:25.250 --> 00:01:28.880
So if I have console.log, and
those weird curly braces, remember,

29
00:01:28.880 --> 00:01:30.035
it's like pairs of shoes.

30
00:01:30.035 --> 00:01:34.860
>> [LAUGH]
>> If I say, is that false, and

31
00:01:34.860 --> 00:01:39.670
I have my triple equals,
those are both false.

32
00:01:39.670 --> 00:01:43.260
And that's because an object, well,

33
00:01:43.260 --> 00:01:46.650
it evaluates to true regardless
of whether it's empty or not.

34
00:01:46.650 --> 00:01:50.020
This is empty,
which is different than this behavior.

35
00:01:50.020 --> 00:01:52.100
So you have to be careful about that.

36
00:01:52.100 --> 00:01:53.890
So this is, is it equal to false?

37
00:01:53.890 --> 00:01:55.020
No?
Is it equal to true?

38
00:01:55.020 --> 00:01:57.040
Well, if my assertion is correct,

39
00:01:58.470 --> 00:02:00.680
let's see what happens when
I change that to true.

40
00:02:00.680 --> 00:02:03.279
Well, it's also not equal to true and

41
00:02:03.279 --> 00:02:05.716
that's kinda weird because-
>> All right,

42
00:02:05.716 --> 00:02:06.793
now you're just messing with our mind.

43
00:02:06.793 --> 00:02:08.970
>> Yeah, yeah, I'm messing with you.

44
00:02:08.970 --> 00:02:13.560
That actually leads us into
the idea of truthy and falsey.

45
00:02:13.560 --> 00:02:15.760
Now it's crazy stuff.

46
00:02:15.760 --> 00:02:20.560
In other programming languages you have
a definitive true and false value.

47
00:02:20.560 --> 00:02:22.310
It is or is not.

48
00:02:22.310 --> 00:02:27.070
But in JavaScript, we have kind of
this gray area that molds over.

49
00:02:27.070 --> 00:02:32.205
And we've seen some of the results
of that with this 0 == false.

50
00:02:32.205 --> 00:02:34.620
Well, these are both falsey values.

51
00:02:35.700 --> 00:02:39.810
Empty string and so an empty
string is no characters in quotes.

52
00:02:39.810 --> 00:02:40.812
That is a falsey value.

53
00:02:40.812 --> 00:02:44.070
And there are a series of falsey values.

54
00:02:44.070 --> 00:02:47.305
0, empty string, as we've seen,

55
00:02:47.305 --> 00:02:51.740
null.

56
00:02:51.740 --> 00:02:55.660
And what's really weird is
sometimes this doesn't always play

57
00:02:57.610 --> 00:03:01.510
out as you expect, so
is null equal to false?

58
00:03:01.510 --> 00:03:02.270
Well, it's not.

59
00:03:02.270 --> 00:03:04.640
Remember null is a special type of object.

60
00:03:04.640 --> 00:03:07.900
So now it's not able to
do that type conversion.

61
00:03:07.900 --> 00:03:12.960
But because of this implicit conversion,
we do lead into this truthy falsey,

62
00:03:12.960 --> 00:03:18.810
and null is the absence of value
which can be construed as 0, nothing.

63
00:03:18.810 --> 00:03:20.920
It's really hard to wrap your mind around,
but

64
00:03:20.920 --> 00:03:23.240
do keep in mind that these values exist.

65
00:03:23.240 --> 00:03:29.287
And we will use them later in some of our
larger applications or larger scripts.

66
00:03:29.287 --> 00:03:32.874
So 0, null, empty string, undefined,

67
00:03:32.874 --> 00:03:37.710
false is obviously falsey,
and then not a number.

68
00:03:37.710 --> 00:03:44.790
So those will, in context, sometimes give
you a false-like appearance or behavior.

69
00:03:44.790 --> 00:03:46.310
Not always, though.

70
00:03:46.310 --> 00:03:50.870
So you need to commit those
few types to memory and

71
00:03:50.870 --> 00:03:57.330
know that those can behave falsey,
but do not necessarily equal false.

72
00:03:57.330 --> 00:03:58.940
And that's where it gets crazy.

73
00:03:58.940 --> 00:04:03.870
I wanna harp on this for a little
bit at the beginning because we will

74
00:04:03.870 --> 00:04:08.690
use these and it's kind of an accepted
best practice, as we've seen.

75
00:04:08.690 --> 00:04:10.650
Now what are truthy values?

76
00:04:10.650 --> 00:04:11.874
Anything that are not those.

77
00:04:11.874 --> 00:04:13.820
>> [LAUGH]
>> And that's an easy way.

78
00:04:13.820 --> 00:04:17.760
So I only have to remember a few,
and then say is it any of those?

79
00:04:17.760 --> 00:04:20.450
No, then its truthy.

80
00:04:20.450 --> 00:04:25.250
And thats where we get this empty object.

81
00:04:25.250 --> 00:04:29.500
Well, even though it's empty,
it still has breadth.

82
00:04:29.500 --> 00:04:32.440
Like if I have an empty cup,
its still a cup.

83
00:04:32.440 --> 00:04:36.370
So its still there,
it doesn't behave in a falsey manner.

84
00:04:36.370 --> 00:04:40.670
Now we've seen from these
datatype conversions from,

85
00:04:40.670 --> 00:04:45.160
you know, boolean to number,
from number to boolean.

86
00:04:45.160 --> 00:04:49.570
All of those, I've used a couple of these
JavaScript, what are called builtins.

87
00:04:51.390 --> 00:04:56.110
Now these are predominant in the browser,
other places that JavaScript has occurred,

88
00:04:56.110 --> 00:05:02.510
or older browser implementations that may
be a little iffy on how well these behave.

89
00:05:02.510 --> 00:05:07.910
But you've seen the string built in and

90
00:05:07.910 --> 00:05:12.100
this is going to make those explicit
conversions from one type to another.

91
00:05:12.100 --> 00:05:18.739
So if I say string of three, I will in
fact get a string representation of three.

92
00:05:20.220 --> 00:05:25.538
But there are also, I should
definitely start using that shortcut.

93
00:05:25.538 --> 00:05:28.657
>> [LAUGH]
>> Instead of the typey, typey.

94
00:05:28.657 --> 00:05:34.624
So there is number and theres 33.

95
00:05:34.624 --> 00:05:38.830
Notice its in blue, so
that means that I now have a number.

96
00:05:38.830 --> 00:05:44.770
There are a few other built-ins
that will either convert or

97
00:05:44.770 --> 00:05:50.890
they also play other roles at creating
some of these additional objects or

98
00:05:50.890 --> 00:05:52.950
types of information.

99
00:05:52.950 --> 00:05:57.190
If I look at an object,
notice I have nothing in the parentheses,

100
00:05:57.190 --> 00:05:58.049
it's just object.

101
00:05:59.460 --> 00:06:03.060
If I refresh, it actually says hey,
this is an object.

102
00:06:03.060 --> 00:06:05.040
And there's some weird drop downs here.

103
00:06:05.040 --> 00:06:07.320
But this is one of those
fundamental data types.

104
00:06:07.320 --> 00:06:09.342
This is one way to create one of those.

105
00:06:09.342 --> 00:06:14.142
In the future, we will also see
kind of a derived data type,

106
00:06:14.142 --> 00:06:20.770
like a special type of object as we've
seen, like null, called an array.

107
00:06:20.770 --> 00:06:24.330
If I use array,
notice I get square brackets.

108
00:06:24.330 --> 00:06:26.690
And when I drop it down
it actually says array.

109
00:06:27.790 --> 00:06:33.441
Now there's a couple other ones,
RegExp, or RegExp.

110
00:06:33.441 --> 00:06:40.570
It's kinda hard to say, R-E-G-E-X-P,
an error and a date object.

111
00:06:40.570 --> 00:06:44.910
As well as a capital F Function built in

112
00:06:47.090 --> 00:06:53.250
that will allow you to write
JavaScript functions as strings.

113
00:06:54.410 --> 00:06:59.810
But it's considered kind of an iffy
security practice, because you may end up

114
00:06:59.810 --> 00:07:04.800
with people being able to inject malicious
function constructions within that.

115
00:07:04.800 --> 00:07:08.160
So do know that those are available.

116
00:07:08.160 --> 00:07:11.193
I would not use
the Function capital F one.

117
00:07:11.193 --> 00:07:16.420
And I, for now, not always,
but for now, this is bad.

118
00:07:16.420 --> 00:07:21.150
Don't do that, because you can end up
with things like crawl site scripting,

119
00:07:21.150 --> 00:07:22.410
where people can take over your page,

120
00:07:22.410 --> 00:07:25.570
inject malicious code within it,
depending on how you use it.

121
00:07:25.570 --> 00:07:30.760
But those last few, and there's that
silly plugin doing crazy stuff.

122
00:07:31.790 --> 00:07:36.736
I do have Date, And

123
00:07:36.736 --> 00:07:41.756
Error, And RegExp,

124
00:07:41.756 --> 00:07:48.350
and those are constructing
regular expressions.

125
00:07:48.350 --> 00:07:51.050
Those are handy if you're trying to
search through a large string for

126
00:07:51.050 --> 00:07:54.770
certain patterns.

127
00:07:54.770 --> 00:07:56.030
Error will kind of come up.

128
00:07:56.030 --> 00:08:00.210
We've already seen a couple of those
syntax error, type error, reference error.

129
00:08:00.210 --> 00:08:03.650
Those are what are thrown to the console,
that'll give you that red output.

130
00:08:03.650 --> 00:08:07.990
There are times where you may want
to construct a custom error for

131
00:08:07.990 --> 00:08:09.280
your application.

132
00:08:09.280 --> 00:08:11.050
We may not see as many of these.

133
00:08:11.050 --> 00:08:16.100
RegExp also has a definite smaller
use case, a very particular use case.

134
00:08:16.100 --> 00:08:19.380
May not see as many of these
in this kind of introduction.

135
00:08:19.380 --> 00:08:22.560
But date, well, dates are very handy.

136
00:08:24.460 --> 00:08:27.270
They will actually
output a bunch of stuff.

137
00:08:27.270 --> 00:08:31.630
And what I don't like about JavaScript
is the date is actually a date, time, so

138
00:08:31.630 --> 00:08:37.460
it's a combination of the date, which is
month, day, year, even day of the week,

139
00:08:37.460 --> 00:08:43.340
as well as, hour, minute, second, and
local offset from what is the UTC,

140
00:08:43.340 --> 00:08:46.300
or kind of the-
>> Universal time.

141
00:08:46.300 --> 00:08:47.940
>> Yeah, universal time code.

142
00:08:47.940 --> 00:08:52.480
So notice we are in the Eastern time
zone and we're offset by five hours.

143
00:08:52.480 --> 00:08:55.480
So date combines a bunch
of information and

144
00:08:55.480 --> 00:08:57.840
are not the easiest things to work with.

145
00:08:57.840 --> 00:09:00.120
However, this is in black text.

146
00:09:00.120 --> 00:09:05.200
That's actually a string representation
of the date as well as this error.

147
00:09:05.200 --> 00:09:08.090
So some of these built-ins
behave a little differently.

148
00:09:08.090 --> 00:09:10.430
As you'll notice,
the number actually gives you a number.

149
00:09:10.430 --> 00:09:12.940
Object gives you an object,
array gives you an array.

150
00:09:12.940 --> 00:09:18.310
Whereas Date and Error give you string
representations of those things.

151
00:09:18.310 --> 00:09:20.500
So you have to be wary of those.

152
00:09:20.500 --> 00:09:24.774
Well, if I wanted to look those up, and
we haven't talked about this until now.

153
00:09:24.774 --> 00:09:28.208
If I wanted to know how can I
get more information about this

154
00:09:28.208 --> 00:09:33.280
one particular built in there,
this one particular aspect of Java Script?

155
00:09:33.280 --> 00:09:34.880
There's a wonderful resource.

156
00:09:34.880 --> 00:09:40.440
Remember that Brandon Ike guy who started
that Netscape and then went on to Mozilla?

157
00:09:40.440 --> 00:09:46.960
Well, if you look at Mozilla Developer
Network, this is like a one stop shop.

158
00:09:46.960 --> 00:09:49.940
And I'm gonna type JavaScript
because it has a bunch of stuff.

159
00:09:49.940 --> 00:09:51.970
Let me zoom in here for you.

160

This has a just plethora,

arc of the covenant feel for

JavaScript as well as other

You gotta to be careful.

Part of being a programmer is knowing

And then very simple examples, well,

sometimes they get a little convoluted.

It was starting to look a little small,

>> So

it just gives you some basic

This is kind of my first stop for

just to familiarize myself with hey,

what does this array function or
