192
00:11:47.610 --> 00:11:52.550
So that gets us all of
this type conversion,

this explicit, implicit,

194

Again, that is number, boolean,

195

And then I've also shown

An array, an error,
that originate in that object and

Great way to round out our

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Mike look at working with strings in JavaScript. They demonstrate creating strings using string literals and built-in functions. They also explore string properties and methods.
episodes.title: Working with Strings
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.260 --> 00:00:07.678
Well come back to ITPro TV [CROSSTALK]
>> You're watching ITPro TV.

2
00:00:12.570 --> 00:00:15.680
>> Hello, welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITPro TV.

3
00:00:15.680 --> 00:00:17.720
I am your host Mike Rodrick and

4
00:00:17.720 --> 00:00:20.650
today we're doing our
introduction to JavaScript.

5

In this episode we're gonna learn
how to work with strings and

7

So here to help us with this is Mr.
Justin Dennerson.

9

>> Thanks for having me back, Mike.

I'm excited.

11

Well I'm not glad we're doing any
crocheting because these giant hands for

We've hit a little deeper and

19

now we're We're gonna go for that final

20
00:00:56.535 --> 00:01:00.915
Again, this is not everything there

21

We're getting close.

22
00:01:01.716 --> 00:01:02.805
>> Here we go.

23
00:01:02.805 --> 00:01:03.415
>> So.

24

25
00:01:04.225 --> 00:01:05.535
>> Yeah, dive, dive, dive.

26

I float really well.

27
00:01:06.950 --> 00:01:09.045
>> [LAUGH]
>> Can't dive, need lots of weight.

28
00:01:09.045 --> 00:01:09.710
Crazy stuff.

29
00:01:09.710 --> 00:01:10.405
>> [LAUGH]
>> Now

30
00:01:11.730 --> 00:01:12.650
>> Before we worry

31
00:01:12.650 --> 00:01:16.410
about working with strings within
the context of the JavaScript interpreter.

32
00:01:16.410 --> 00:01:18.760
The console thats happening in Chrome.

33
00:01:18.760 --> 00:01:22.680
Lets take a step back and
think about what is a string actually,

34
00:01:22.680 --> 00:01:24.030
I've been saying its text.

35
00:01:24.030 --> 00:01:29.590
It's like text on a page, but to the
computer, it's kinda a collection, right?

36
00:01:29.590 --> 00:01:35.240
I imagine it as like a clothes line,
or even the balls

37
00:01:35.240 --> 00:01:40.640
of popcorn that they put around ornamental
decorations at certain times of year.

38
00:01:40.640 --> 00:01:43.120
So, we clip those along, and

39
00:01:43.120 --> 00:01:47.290
a string is kinda strung together
of individual letters, right?

40
00:01:47.290 --> 00:01:52.350
If I ask you how to spell your name,
you don't just say your name back at me.

41
00:01:52.350 --> 00:01:54.940
You tell me the individual letters, and

42
00:01:54.940 --> 00:01:58.630
that's how it's interpreted
as a data type of strings.

43
00:01:58.630 --> 00:02:02.330
It is a collection of letters that
are arranged in a particular order.

44
00:02:03.360 --> 00:02:06.760
In addition to,
we say the first letter of my name.

45
00:02:06.760 --> 00:02:09.920
And my name, for instance, is Jay.

46
00:02:09.920 --> 00:02:14.420
But in computers, because of some
behind the scenes machinations,

47
00:02:14.420 --> 00:02:18.900
a lot of times those collections are,
in fact, zero indexed.

48
00:02:18.900 --> 00:02:22.700
And let's take a look at just not
programming, but I'm gonna use comments

49
00:02:22.700 --> 00:02:28.030
here with an atom just to illustrate
what I mean by this zero based indexing.

50
00:02:28.030 --> 00:02:28.980
And I'm gonna use one of those

51
00:02:28.980 --> 00:02:31.039
block comments that we haven't seen for
a little while.

52
00:02:32.060 --> 00:02:34.910
So if I have the string abc

53
00:02:37.960 --> 00:02:43.780
that is in fact kind of
the first letter strung together

54
00:02:43.780 --> 00:02:46.780
with the second letter strung
together with the third letter.

55
00:02:46.780 --> 00:02:51.930
So I would have a collection of a then
b then c, of individual characters.

56
00:02:51.930 --> 00:02:54.740
But all together they
make up the word ABC.

57
00:02:54.740 --> 00:02:58.380
Now there's another truer word, but

58
00:02:58.380 --> 00:03:01.640
we would say that A is the first
letter in this collection.

59
00:03:01.640 --> 00:03:06.200
And talking to any other
person if I were to tell

60
00:03:06.200 --> 00:03:09.430
Mike this was the first letter he'd
be like yeah that's the first letter.

61
00:03:09.430 --> 00:03:12.290
However, to the computer,
this is the zeroth letter.

62
00:03:12.290 --> 00:03:14.220
It's the zeroth index letter.

63
00:03:14.220 --> 00:03:18.040
And you'll see how those
indexes come into play shortly.

64
00:03:18.040 --> 00:03:23.390
And likewise,
we then discount forward as we always had.

65
00:03:23.390 --> 00:03:26.140
We just have to remember
that we start at zero, and

66
00:03:26.140 --> 00:03:30.350
it's really an odd thing as people
because we don't start counting at zero.

67
00:03:30.350 --> 00:03:36.650
I have zero, one, two, three sheep,
or popsicles, or candy bars.

68
00:03:36.650 --> 00:03:40.050
Well, if you have zero you don't have any,
so we don't think to count them.

69
00:03:40.050 --> 00:03:42.030
So kind of an odd paradigm.

70
00:03:42.030 --> 00:03:46.200
But because of how data's represented at
the machine level, at the programmatic

71
00:03:46.200 --> 00:03:50.480
level, for things we don't really care
about at this point, we start at zero.

72
00:03:51.500 --> 00:03:53.630
All right, Justin we've been
spending a lot of time on strings.

73
00:03:53.630 --> 00:03:56.390
Obviously they have some importance.

74
00:03:56.390 --> 00:03:57.780
>> That they do Mike.

75
00:03:57.780 --> 00:04:01.940
Strings why are they an important data
type for transferring information?

76
00:04:01.940 --> 00:04:06.510
Well, we actually interact with the string
data type in a variety of contexts

77
00:04:06.510 --> 00:04:08.680
without even thinking about it.

78
00:04:08.680 --> 00:04:12.340
I sit down at my Word document or
Google Docs and I'm typing away.

79
00:04:12.340 --> 00:04:14.910
Those are in fact string representations.

80
00:04:14.910 --> 00:04:17.440
Of that information,
as far as the computer is concerned.

81
00:04:17.440 --> 00:04:20.700
Now there's additional attributes
associated with those,

82
00:04:20.700 --> 00:04:25.390
such as bold, italicized,
how big the text is.

83
00:04:25.390 --> 00:04:29.790
But, at the core,
it is a string representation.It is text.

84
00:04:29.790 --> 00:04:35.080
In addition to all the webpages that you
navigate to our specially formated strings

85
00:04:35.080 --> 00:04:41.030
because they're very easy to kind of chunk
apart, send across data, save, manipulate.

86
00:04:41.030 --> 00:04:45.330
So strings allow us this
data transfer layer

87
00:04:45.330 --> 00:04:48.350
that otherwise be
difficult to interact with.

88
00:04:49.350 --> 00:04:53.933
So how do we play with rally strings,
well lets, lets go back just for

89
00:04:53.933 --> 00:04:58.452
a moment about the creation of
strings because i've glossed over.

90
00:05:01.598 --> 00:05:03.150
How I've been making these strings.

91
00:05:03.150 --> 00:05:07.330
So my favorite color, right, is blue.

92
00:05:07.330 --> 00:05:09.440
Now, I'm gonna take a step back,

93
00:05:09.440 --> 00:05:14.420
notice this is the first multi
worded variable that I've had and

94
00:05:14.420 --> 00:05:17.200
it has a very particular format and
you will see this from time to time.

95
00:05:17.200 --> 00:05:19.789
This is a convention within JavaScript.

96
00:05:20.950 --> 00:05:23.130
And other C style languages.

97
00:05:23.130 --> 00:05:26.870
But also notice that I have
single quotes here and

98
00:05:26.870 --> 00:05:29.300
single quotes are purely because I'm lazy.

99
00:05:29.300 --> 00:05:32.830
I don't have to hold the shift key with
my left hand while I hit the quotes

100
00:05:32.830 --> 00:05:34.200
with my right hand.

101
00:05:34.200 --> 00:05:38.520
And if you type a lot and
you do this six-eight hours a day

102
00:05:38.520 --> 00:05:42.170
holding shift with your left finger,
with your left pinky, can actually

103
00:05:42.170 --> 00:05:45.740
bring a fair amount of fatigue if
you're typing a bunch of strings.

104
00:05:45.740 --> 00:05:50.250
So because JavaScript doesn't care whether
it's double quotes or single quotes

105
00:05:50.250 --> 00:05:54.600
as long as they're paired, just like
your shoes or your mittens if it's cold.

106
00:05:54.600 --> 00:05:58.400
It doesn't really matter to JavaScript.

107
00:05:58.400 --> 00:06:04.930
So if I say my favorite food is steak,

108
00:06:04.930 --> 00:06:10.410
but instead I put double
quotes around this.

109
00:06:10.410 --> 00:06:15.440
I end up with strings in other place.

110
00:06:15.440 --> 00:06:19.530
Notice however if I have a mismatch,
a single on one end and

111
00:06:19.530 --> 00:06:24.520
a double on the other then my editor and
this wouldn't happen in normal text

112
00:06:24.520 --> 00:06:27.410
editors, will actually say, hey,
there's something wrong here.

113
00:06:27.410 --> 00:06:28.080
This isn't valid.

114
00:06:28.080 --> 00:06:30.230
You shouldn't be doing this.

115
00:06:30.230 --> 00:06:35.530
So I always like to make sure they're
paired and then type what I need to

116
00:06:35.530 --> 00:06:41.350
These are, in fact,
called string literals.

117
00:06:41.350 --> 00:06:45.240
That's because these are literally
strings right here, I've defined them.

118
00:06:45.240 --> 00:06:49.990
I have a variable called my favorite
color, it has the value of a string with

119
00:06:49.990 --> 00:06:55.750
blue as the text and then my favorite
food is double quoted steak but

120
00:06:55.750 --> 00:06:58.780
in java script, completely the same.

121
00:06:58.780 --> 00:07:01.870
That is not true for
some other programming languages.

122
00:07:01.870 --> 00:07:07.070
So be careful if you're kind of exploring
other realms of programming languages.

123
00:07:07.070 --> 00:07:10.380
Now in addition to,
we've seen other ways to create strings.

124
00:07:11.680 --> 00:07:14.670
And that's using the string built-ins.

125
00:07:14.670 --> 00:07:22.933
So if we take a look at how to
use those my favourite number and

126
00:07:22.933 --> 00:07:27.066
42 national reference, so

127
00:07:27.066 --> 00:07:32.521
my favourite number if I take the string

128
00:07:32.521 --> 00:07:37.175
42 and also my favourite object

129
00:07:40.552 --> 00:07:44.160
And I'm just gonna, remember paired curly
braces, it's important, gotta pair stuff.

130
00:07:45.170 --> 00:07:47.020
You always need pairs.

131
00:07:47.020 --> 00:07:48.970
Open, close, left, right.

132
00:07:50.260 --> 00:07:51.940
So I have all of these.

133
00:07:51.940 --> 00:07:54.458
Let's see how these print out.

134
00:07:54.458 --> 00:08:00.059
So my favorite color, and
then my favorite food.

135
00:08:02.077 --> 00:08:08.920
And my favorite number and
my favorite object.

136
00:08:08.920 --> 00:08:14.674
Now, I know because these
are using the string built-ins.

137
00:08:14.674 --> 00:08:17.802
Built-in, not built-ins.

138
00:08:17.802 --> 00:08:19.392
There's one.

139
00:08:19.392 --> 00:08:22.150
That all of these should
be of type string.

140
00:08:22.150 --> 00:08:24.710
So, I'm not gonna use the type
of operator to confirm that.

141
00:08:24.710 --> 00:08:26.610
I know that I'm using quotes here.

142
00:08:26.610 --> 00:08:27.570
These are string literals.

143
00:08:27.570 --> 00:08:28.470
I have a string.

144
00:08:28.470 --> 00:08:33.890
I'm also using the string function built
into JavaScript, in order to make this.

145
00:08:33.890 --> 00:08:36.590
But we're gonna find a surprising result.

146
00:08:36.590 --> 00:08:41.680
So I expect blue stake 42 and
then open and close curly breaks.

147
00:08:41.680 --> 00:08:46.599
Well, I actually have blue state 42 and

148
00:08:46.599 --> 00:08:50.410
then this weird object object.

149
00:08:50.410 --> 00:08:55.700
So you have to be careful sometimes
the string built-ins provide you with

150
00:08:55.700 --> 00:08:56.790
not a lot of detail.

151
00:08:56.790 --> 00:09:01.170
But it's in fact the closest
string approximation you can get

152
00:09:01.170 --> 00:09:03.130
to these data types.

153
00:09:03.130 --> 00:09:04.990
So object object.

154
00:09:04.990 --> 00:09:08.160
Array will also do things like this as

155
00:09:08.160 --> 00:09:10.380
that array type that
we touched on briefly.

156
00:09:10.380 --> 00:09:11.080
We'll see more.

157
00:09:12.510 --> 00:09:15.170
We have to be careful about
the string representation

158
00:09:15.170 --> 00:09:17.430
if we're doing this explicit conversion.

159
00:09:17.430 --> 00:09:19.800
So, I like to stay with string literals,
so

160
00:09:19.800 --> 00:09:24.305
as a matter of choice, whoa was about
to get crazy there for a second.

161
00:09:24.305 --> 00:09:27.860
>> [LAUGH]
>> I'm gonna comment these out,

162
00:09:27.860 --> 00:09:31.840
and then just uncomment these couple
of lines here, not this line,

163
00:09:31.840 --> 00:09:35.130
this line,
because I want to keep that around.

164
00:09:35.130 --> 00:09:38.220
So, I have a couple of
words represented and

165
00:09:38.220 --> 00:09:40.590
then I have a number
represented as a string.

166
00:09:42.480 --> 00:09:48.120
And to add for some overflow here
I'm gonna add a comment down here so

167
00:09:48.120 --> 00:09:50.220
I don't have that weird cutoff.

168
00:09:50.220 --> 00:09:55.150
Save, and here we go.

169
00:09:55.150 --> 00:09:57.395
So how can I manipulate strings?

170
00:09:57.395 --> 00:10:01.170
Well, as I've all ready said we
have a string of characters and

171
00:10:01.170 --> 00:10:03.470
there is a couple of ways
that i can get add those.

172
00:10:03.470 --> 00:10:07.860
There is something called brackets
syntax and let's see how that works.

173
00:10:07.860 --> 00:10:12.386
So if I log my favorite color
I'm starting to think maybe I

174
00:10:12.386 --> 00:10:15.230
should have chosen smaller names.

175
00:10:15.230 --> 00:10:21.400
Even when my code completion it's a little
iffy sometimes so please bear with me.

176
00:10:21.400 --> 00:10:26.890
I'm gonna actually type a square bracket
and then a closed square bracket.

177
00:10:26.890 --> 00:10:29.910
Notice they're in pairs.

178
00:10:29.910 --> 00:10:35.140
And they are also the same keys
that the curly braces come within.

179
00:10:35.140 --> 00:10:38.720
So when I say bracket I typically
mean the square brackets.

180
00:10:38.720 --> 00:10:43.520
So myFavoriteColor, and right after that,
I'm going to type, I dunno, 2.

181
00:10:43.520 --> 00:10:47.090
And we have to be careful, because

182
00:10:47.090 --> 00:10:52.120
we have to make sure that this number has
an appropriate matching piece, right?

183
00:10:52.120 --> 00:10:57.040
So if I go to myFavoriteColor and I look
at blue, I have to start counting at zero.

184
00:10:57.040 --> 00:11:01.160
This is zero, one, two.

00:14:42.760 --> 00:14:46.340
Now, these do not mutate, as we've seen.

250
00:14:46.340 --> 00:14:49.289
Strings should not be mutated,
are not going to be mutated easily.

251
00:14:49.289 --> 00:14:53.102
I reserved to say easily because
someone'll figure out of way and

252
00:14:53.102 --> 00:14:55.123
be like I did it, I figured it out.

253
00:14:55.123 --> 00:14:59.180
>> [LAUGH] So just to be clear, then,
when you do the two upper and it displays

254
00:14:59.180 --> 00:15:03.504
all upper case, it's not really changing
the value that's being stored and

255
00:15:03.504 --> 00:15:07.950
the variable to upper case,
it's just displaying that as upper case?

256
00:15:07.950 --> 00:15:10.670
>> Correct.
I'm getting a copy with the changes made.

257
00:15:10.670 --> 00:15:14.250
And let's just for
consistency show that that is the case.

258
00:15:14.250 --> 00:15:18.798
So I'm gonna remove this log,
and this is gonna be upperfood.

259
00:15:18.798 --> 00:15:23.226
I'm not gonna keep that entire
giant name there for a moment.

260
00:15:23.226 --> 00:15:28.572
And then I'm going to console.log,

261
00:15:28.572 --> 00:15:33.257
upperFood and myFavoriteFood.

262
00:15:36.833 --> 00:15:37.592
Nice.

263
00:15:40.178 --> 00:15:41.780
You caught me, you caught me.

264
00:15:41.780 --> 00:15:44.300
Hold on a second,
there was that thing again.

265
00:15:46.330 --> 00:15:46.910
My favorite food.

266
00:15:48.500 --> 00:15:50.430
Getting all kinds of crazy up in here,
Mike.

267
00:15:50.430 --> 00:15:51.073
There we go.

268
00:15:51.073 --> 00:15:55.847
So again, validated that we're getting
a copy that is all uppercase versus

269
00:15:55.847 --> 00:15:58.620
the original which was all lowercase.

270
00:15:58.620 --> 00:15:59.126
>> Fantastic.

271
00:15:59.126 --> 00:16:00.834
So, there's couple of other
ones that are very useful.

272
00:16:00.834 --> 00:16:07.945
And these lead into some,
one of them leads into another type.

273
00:16:07.945 --> 00:16:15.520
So, if I wanted to split
the characters apart,

274
00:16:15.520 --> 00:16:19.330
and just get a collection of characters,
but separately, so I could look at them

275
00:16:19.330 --> 00:16:23.740
one at a time, and that is what
an array is, as we'll see later on.

276
00:16:23.740 --> 00:16:27.820
But if you can suspend that, I don't
know what you're talking about moment,

277
00:16:27.820 --> 00:16:30.810
then let's take a look at how
these strings are manipulated.

278
00:16:30.810 --> 00:16:33.450
And I'm gonna keep this
as just a string literal.

279
00:16:33.450 --> 00:16:38.290
So, if I wanted to split, and

280
00:16:38.290 --> 00:16:42.820
notice I put just empty quotes,
which is the empty string,

281
00:16:42.820 --> 00:16:47.220
that will actually split on all,
just pull the characters apart.

282
00:16:47.220 --> 00:16:49.638
And you can see that I have
these square brackets now.

283
00:16:49.638 --> 00:16:52.297
And I have individual characters.

284
00:16:52.297 --> 00:16:58.007
So I've split that collection apart
into a different data structure

285
00:16:58.007 --> 00:17:05.310
that did not alter ABC, but instead, gave
me a copy as it pulled those apart for me.

286
00:17:05.310 --> 00:17:09.602
Now the split is very handy,
because what if I wanted to validate that

287
00:17:09.602 --> 00:17:13.904
email address, like you said,
by looking at the individual parts?

288
00:17:13.904 --> 00:17:16.511
Well, let's actually
look at an email address.

289
00:17:16.511 --> 00:17:24.830
So, steak@blue.com,
looks like a valid email address to me.

290
00:17:24.830 --> 00:17:31.530
And I'm just going to
split on the at symbol.

291
00:17:31.530 --> 00:17:35.626
If I split on the at symbol, I will get
the first part of the email address and

292
00:17:35.626 --> 00:17:37.720
the second part of the email address.

293
00:17:37.720 --> 00:17:40.390
And then I can process those separately.

294
00:17:40.390 --> 00:17:43.892
>> And it looks like the character
you're using to do the split is excluded

295
00:17:43.892 --> 00:17:44.440
on those.

296
00:17:44.440 --> 00:17:47.570
>> Yes, yes so
when it splits it cuts those out and

297
00:17:47.570 --> 00:17:50.234
then moves the other parts to the side.

298
00:17:50.234 --> 00:17:52.355
Except for the empty string which,

299
00:17:52.355 --> 00:17:57.410
that means there's nothing there to
split on so split everything to pieces.

300
00:17:57.410 --> 00:18:00.020
Just macerate it.

301
00:18:00.020 --> 00:18:06.540
The last part is, sometimes you'll have
these people will get into text fields and

302
00:18:06.540 --> 00:18:11.010
do stuff like this so
you have these weird leading or

303
00:18:11.010 --> 00:18:16.030
trailing white spaces, and white spaces
do count as characters within strings.

304
00:18:16.030 --> 00:18:20.630
Well, I don't want to try to process
those because then if I look at the first

305
00:18:20.630 --> 00:18:24.185
character and
I'm expecting it be a valid letter and

306
00:18:24.185 --> 00:18:27.210
it's an empty string that's kinda weird.

307
00:18:27.210 --> 00:18:35.300
So if I change this instead to, Trim and
this may be a little hard to see.

308
00:18:35.300 --> 00:18:37.830
I'm gonna try to show this as best I can.

309
00:18:37.830 --> 00:18:43.031
So, this will actually remove
those leading white spaces.

310
00:18:43.031 --> 00:18:47.129
It kinda comes and goes to the first
non-white space character and the first

311
00:18:47.129 --> 00:18:51.440
non-white space character to the end and
cuts off the white space characters.

312
00:18:51.440 --> 00:18:54.040
So those are handy for
data processing, as well.

313
00:18:54.040 --> 00:18:58.730
>> Yeah, I see that a lot of times when
you've got first and last name fields and

314
00:18:58.730 --> 00:19:00.970
the first name field is a fixed length.

315
00:19:00.970 --> 00:19:05.000
So some short names you end up with a lot
of white space on the end of it and

316
00:19:05.000 --> 00:19:07.090
then you try to concatenate the first and
last name and

317
00:19:07.090 --> 00:19:09.380
sometimes there's a lot of
extra space between them.

318
00:19:09.380 --> 00:19:11.470
That trim command can be very,
very useful.

319
00:19:13.060 --> 00:19:17.980
>> I've used the trim command more times
than I thought I would ever use it,

320
00:19:17.980 --> 00:19:19.280
for some reason.

321
00:19:19.280 --> 00:19:21.723
Or, I've been guilty of typing a password,
and

322
00:19:21.723 --> 00:19:24.477
then there's a white space
character on the end of it.

323
00:19:24.477 --> 00:19:28.755
Or typing a user name when I'm trying
to log in, and I've hit a space, and

324
00:19:28.755 --> 00:19:31.860
then it doesn't match
because the service I'm using

325
00:19:31.860 --> 00:19:34.832
isn't trimming to
non-white space characters.

326
00:19:34.832 --> 00:19:38.948
So those are handy for validation.

327
00:19:38.948 --> 00:19:41.320
>> All right, Justin, a lot of cool
things we can do with strings,

328
00:19:41.320 --> 00:19:43.130
but I know there's more, right?

329
00:19:43.130 --> 00:19:44.870
>> There's one final thing.

330
00:19:44.870 --> 00:19:47.120
And we have to be careful
because this will trip you up.

331
00:19:47.120 --> 00:19:51.120
We've talked about type coersion,
those conversions between data types.

332
00:19:51.120 --> 00:19:55.630
But, I really want to emphasize
this final string operation that is

333
00:19:55.630 --> 00:20:00.810
fairly ubiquitous as you're building
URLs or building user names and

334
00:20:00.810 --> 00:20:05.430
that's actually the concatenation,
concatenation, operator.

335
00:20:05.430 --> 00:20:07.180
I think I spelled that right.

336
00:20:07.180 --> 00:20:11.338
I like to think of it as
the squish together operator.

337
00:20:11.338 --> 00:20:14.047
>> [LAUGH]
>> And what's weird is,

338
00:20:14.047 --> 00:20:17.622
the string prototype, if we look,
and what I mean by prototype,

339
00:20:17.622 --> 00:20:21.260
these are all methods that I
can use with string objects.

340
00:20:21.260 --> 00:20:24.410
If I look,
there's actually a concat method.

341
00:20:25.720 --> 00:20:28.900
And that says,
if I give it a bunch of strings,

342
00:20:28.900 --> 00:20:32.390
it'll actually smash them together,
just like you have here.

343
00:20:32.390 --> 00:20:38.290
But it's the first one concat with every
other thing, so it'll push them together.

344
00:20:38.290 --> 00:20:42.280
Now, I find that kind of hard to reason
about because usually I'm like, I want

345
00:20:42.280 --> 00:20:48.540
this first and then this and this next,
and visually it's hard for me to figure

346
00:20:48.540 --> 00:20:53.140
out what I need to put in what order
unless I have really good variable names.

347
00:20:53.140 --> 00:20:59.305
But instead, you will see a lot of people,
me included, use the plus sign actually.

348
00:20:59.305 --> 00:21:02.950
So we think of plus as like 2 + 3.

349
00:21:02.950 --> 00:21:04.300
Okay, well, that's 5.

350
00:21:04.300 --> 00:21:08.668
Well, if I have 2 + 3, and

351
00:21:08.668 --> 00:21:13.229
we've seen this one before.

352
00:21:13.229 --> 00:21:14.564
There we go.

353
00:21:14.564 --> 00:21:17.374
Was getting a little out of hand there for
a second, Mike.

354
00:21:17.374 --> 00:21:22.760
>> [LAUGH]
>> This is some bad math, 2 + 3 is 23.

355
00:21:22.760 --> 00:21:26.362
And that's because it took the first
string, the next string and

356
00:21:26.362 --> 00:21:28.160
smashed them together.

357
00:21:28.160 --> 00:21:32.187
Also notice, it went, literally,
what you asked for it to.

358
00:21:32.187 --> 00:21:37.420
If I put a space here,
it now is 2 space 3.

359
00:21:37.420 --> 00:21:40.590
So, in order to get those white
spaces when you're building these up,

360
00:21:40.590 --> 00:21:45.260
you have to put the white
space in explicitly.

361
00:21:45.260 --> 00:21:48.552
Now, the reason I bring this
up is this plus operator,

362
00:21:48.552 --> 00:21:52.793
if one of these is a string,
then you may end up getting weird results.

363
00:21:52.793 --> 00:21:55.980
So you should be cognitive
of this operator.

364
00:21:55.980 --> 00:21:57.490
Because if I do 2 + 3,

365
00:21:57.490 --> 00:22:01.960
I still get 23 and that's because
I have a string plus a number.

366
00:22:01.960 --> 00:22:06.015
Well now it's not using the number plus
but instead the string concatenation and

367
00:22:06.015 --> 00:22:11.210
it'll force this other one to be
a string and kinda squish them together.

368
00:22:11.210 --> 00:22:17.867
Likewise, I can have empty open curly,
close curly brace which, is an object.

369
00:22:17.867 --> 00:22:23.190
And okay, then that's probably
going to be two curly braces.

370
00:22:23.190 --> 00:22:24.504
Well no, it's not.

371
00:22:24.504 --> 00:22:27.470
It actually says, this is an object.

372
00:22:27.470 --> 00:22:32.880
And that's because, in higher and
kind of more complex types, there's behind

373
00:22:32.880 --> 00:22:36.980
the scenes machinations that will give you
a representation that is easy to print.

374
00:22:36.980 --> 00:22:38.640
I don't think this is very helpful,

375
00:22:38.640 --> 00:22:42.640
but that's what your gonna get when you
get an object, and that's object object.

376
00:22:42.640 --> 00:22:46.310
So be very careful about
the string concatenation operator.

377
00:22:46.310 --> 00:22:48.760
But, what are some use cases for this?

378
00:22:48.760 --> 00:22:55.070
Well, if we go back to a website, right?

379
00:22:55.070 --> 00:23:02.110
If I know that I'm searching, whoa,
I was about to put a bad website in there.

380
00:23:02.110 --> 00:23:08.358
For searchandstuff.things,

381
00:23:08.358 --> 00:23:14.790
but I don't know what I'm actually
gonna be searching for, right?

382
00:23:16.270 --> 00:23:18.360
That is not the correct character.

383
00:23:18.360 --> 00:23:23.640
I know is gonna be some kind of query but
I'm gonna use this in a dynamic manner.

384
00:23:23.640 --> 00:23:26.066
Well, I'm gonna search for myFavoriteFood.

385
00:23:29.154 --> 00:23:31.962
Now, I can dynamically build URLs and

386
00:23:31.962 --> 00:23:37.550
this is helpful when we start building
kind of dynamic web applications.

387
00:23:37.550 --> 00:23:40.330
So that's a very common usage pattern.

388
00:23:40.330 --> 00:23:41.935
>> All right Justin, fantastic!

389
00:23:41.935 --> 00:23:46.080
Great look at there at strings and
all of the different things that we can

390
00:23:46.080 --> 00:23:50.050
use to manipulate, combine and
work with those strings.

391
00:23:50.050 --> 00:23:50.716
We appreciate that.

392
00:23:50.716 --> 00:23:52.863
Hope everybody out there
enjoyed watching this one.

393
00:23:52.863 --> 00:23:54.247
Singing off for ITProTV.

394
00:23:54.247 --> 00:23:56.150
I've been your host Mike Rodrick.

395
00:23:56.150 --> 00:23:57.474
And I'm Justin Dennison.

396
00:23:57.474 --> 00:23:58.995
>> And we'll see you next time.

397
00:23:58.995 --> 00:24:06.112
[MUSIC]

398
00:24:06.112 --> 00:24:10.570
Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Mike work with arrays. They demonstrate creating arrays and working with an arrays properties. They also demonstrate various methods used to manipulate arrays.
episodes.title: Working with Arrays
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.053 --> 00:00:04.313
Welcome to ITPro TV,
I'm your host [CROSSTALK].

2
00:00:04.313 --> 00:00:08.294
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:08.294 --> 00:00:12.460
>> You're watching ITPro TV.

4
00:00:12.460 --> 00:00:15.270
>> Hello, welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITPro TV.

5
00:00:15.270 --> 00:00:19.590
I'm your host Mike Rodrick, and today,
we're doing introduction to JavaScript.

6
00:00:19.590 --> 00:00:23.970
And in this episode,
we're going to be focusing in On arrays.

7
00:00:23.970 --> 00:00:25.250
And here to help us with arrays.

8
00:00:25.250 --> 00:00:28.800
Show us what they are and how we can
use them is Mr. Justin Dennison.

9
00:00:28.800 --> 00:00:29.720
Welcome back Justin.

10
00:00:29.720 --> 00:00:31.180
>> Thanks for having me back Mike.

11
00:00:31.180 --> 00:00:32.800
Yeah, arrays.

12
00:00:32.800 --> 00:00:34.670
That's just kind of a weird word.

13
00:00:34.670 --> 00:00:38.010
It's just another one of those
words that might be kind of scary.

14
00:00:38.010 --> 00:00:42.110
However, we've already seen something
that's very similar to arrays.

15
00:00:42.110 --> 00:00:43.620
And that's in fact the string.

16
00:00:43.620 --> 00:00:46.050
The string was a collection.

17
00:00:46.050 --> 00:00:51.800
Of letters and things, but
arrays can be a collection of anything.

18
00:00:51.800 --> 00:00:53.430
And what do I mean by a collection?

19
00:00:53.430 --> 00:00:57.575
Well, if you reach inside your pocket and
you have coins, sometimes I don't.

20
00:00:57.575 --> 00:00:58.860
>> [LAUGH]
>> But if you have coins,

21
00:00:58.860 --> 00:01:01.160
you have a collection of coins.

22
00:01:01.160 --> 00:01:04.230
And they're all of coin type.

23
00:01:04.230 --> 00:01:07.540
So that allows you to
see how Ray would work.

24
00:01:07.540 --> 00:01:12.200
Now if line them up on a table now
you have a true representation

25
00:01:13.570 --> 00:01:16.230
of what an array would conceptually be.

26
00:01:16.230 --> 00:01:20.080
So there's some key points that
I want to make about arrays.

27
00:01:21.190 --> 00:01:25.070
In JavaScript, you can just kinda
put anything you want into an array,

28
00:01:25.070 --> 00:01:28.800
you can treat it like the junk drawer,
that I don't know if you have, but

29
00:01:28.800 --> 00:01:29.480
I have at my house.

30
00:01:29.480 --> 00:01:32.020
Where you're like,
I don't know what to do with this.

31
00:01:32.020 --> 00:01:34.920
So just put it in the junk drawer and
then kind of jimmy it shut.

32
00:01:34.920 --> 00:01:37.960
And go, I don't know if I'll ever
need that, but you never know.

33
00:01:37.960 --> 00:01:41.560
So I would be very careful
because it's really hard to keep

34
00:01:41.560 --> 00:01:42.640
track of those in your mind.

35
00:01:42.640 --> 00:01:45.827
Because arrays can be
anywhere from ten items,

36
00:01:45.827 --> 00:01:49.690
like a ten-letter string
that you split apart.

37
00:01:49.690 --> 00:01:52.240
Or, it could be up to a million items.

38
00:01:52.240 --> 00:01:54.410
So, if you open the junk drawer, and

39
00:01:54.410 --> 00:01:58.620
there's a million different things
in there, you kinda get scared.

40
00:01:58.620 --> 00:01:59.140
I know I do.

41
00:01:59.140 --> 00:02:01.767
>> [LAUGH]
>> I mean I get scared when there's like

42
00:02:01.767 --> 00:02:04.591
30 things in my junk drawer,
or even 4, and I'm like,

43
00:02:04.591 --> 00:02:06.306
I don't know what those are for.

44
00:02:06.306 --> 00:02:12.420
But arrays are, they're a way of kind of
bundling things together then track along.

45
00:02:13.490 --> 00:02:16.140
Arrays are still zero indexed.

46
00:02:16.140 --> 00:02:19.440
All collections in JavaScript
are going to be zero indexed.

47
00:02:19.440 --> 00:02:24.020
And there's several ways to
access within that collection.

48
00:02:24.020 --> 00:02:28.140
But let's go ahead and get started and
stop conceptualizing and

49
00:02:28.140 --> 00:02:30.310
actually see concrete examples.

50
00:02:30.310 --> 00:02:32.070
So I have Chrome open.

51
00:02:32.070 --> 00:02:35.460
I'm again going to move
to one of those projects

52
00:02:35.460 --> 00:02:39.610
that have that @.js in index.html.

53
00:02:39.610 --> 00:02:42.260
I name my folders appropriately.

54
00:02:42.260 --> 00:02:46.540
Working with arrays, so I don't have to,
am I in the right index.html?

55
00:02:46.540 --> 00:02:48.040
Be very, very careful of that.

56
00:02:48.040 --> 00:02:49.300
I can't emphasize that enough.

57
00:02:49.300 --> 00:02:54.152
This calls me a lot of strife and
I don't wanna call you any strife either.

58
00:02:54.152 --> 00:02:55.410
So in addition to,

59
00:02:55.410 --> 00:02:58.850
while I'm in Chrome, I'm going to
open the Chrome developer tools.

60
00:02:58.850 --> 00:03:03.190
There's our console that's gonna
print out our nice little examples.

61
00:03:03.190 --> 00:03:05.520
And then I'm gonna hop over into Atom and
go ahead and

62
00:03:05.520 --> 00:03:07.230
open the corresponding folder.

63
00:03:08.320 --> 00:03:11.460
And that's Add Project folder, and

64
00:03:11.460 --> 00:03:16.630
I'm gonna navigate to working with arrays,
and there we have it.

65
00:03:16.630 --> 00:03:21.080
My index is just an entry way
into executing my app.js,

66
00:03:21.080 --> 00:03:24.760
my app JS is where
the magic really happens.

67
00:03:24.760 --> 00:03:26.070
So what is an array?

68
00:03:26.070 --> 00:03:27.660
Well, I said it was a collection.

69
00:03:27.660 --> 00:03:30.820
And let's use one of those block comments,
again, to talk about it.

70
00:03:30.820 --> 00:03:34.350
An array is going to have
square brackets on either end.

71
00:03:34.350 --> 00:03:38.870
If you ever see a printout that
has square brackets on either end,

72
00:03:40.230 --> 00:03:44.080
that means you have an array type,
a collection of things.

73
00:03:45.100 --> 00:03:46.280
So let's look.

74
00:03:46.280 --> 00:03:52.220
If I had 1, 2, 3, and this is typically
how you're gonna see them printed out,

75
00:03:52.220 --> 00:03:53.480
unless they get really large and

76
00:03:53.480 --> 00:03:57.600
then JavaScript will actually
make them drop downs.

77
00:03:57.600 --> 00:04:02.810
This, as we saw with a, b, c in strings
is going to be the zeroth element,

78
00:04:02.810 --> 00:04:07.260
the first element, and the second element.

79

00:19:27.613 --> 00:19:33.631
0, But only put 1 as the delete count?

311
00:19:33.631 --> 00:19:34.699
Let's see how that differs.

312
00:19:37.403 --> 00:19:42.156
And in fact it starts at 0 but it only
deletes the first thing it comes to, and

313
00:19:42.156 --> 00:19:43.510
that's different.

314
00:19:43.510 --> 00:19:46.410
If I put just 0 and just for

315
00:19:46.410 --> 00:19:51.860
comparison it will actually
delete everything in the array.

316
00:19:51.860 --> 00:19:56.262
So telling it how many things to delete
after the starting position can be

317
00:19:56.262 --> 00:19:57.282
advantageous.

318
00:19:57.282 --> 00:20:05.115
And then the final final form
of splice is let's say, 2 and 3.

319
00:20:06.135 --> 00:20:08.885
Now this looks like a bunch of numbers,
but I'm starting at 0,

320
00:20:08.885 --> 00:20:14.257
I'm deleting the first one, and
I'm replacing it with item 1, item 2.

321
00:20:15.290 --> 00:20:17.480
Let's remind ourselves of
what that looked like.

322
00:20:17.480 --> 00:20:20.371
It was 42, 13 and 17.

323
00:20:20.371 --> 00:20:23.720
But I delete the first one and
replace 2 and 3, I should see,

324
00:20:23.720 --> 00:20:26.556
if I'm reading this
documentation correctly, and

325
00:20:26.556 --> 00:20:28.178
it's a toss up sometimes-
>> [LAUGH]

326
00:20:28.178 --> 00:20:31.564
>> Not gonna lie, I should see 2, 3,

327
00:20:31.564 --> 00:20:32.800
13 and 7.

328
00:20:32.800 --> 00:20:33.880
Don't forget to save.

329
00:20:33.880 --> 00:20:38.810
And in fact, I've deleted the first one
and replaced it with how many everythings

330
00:20:38.810 --> 00:20:42.680
I want to put on the back end of a splice.

331
00:20:43.890 --> 00:20:48.100
Again, splice, you have to be careful
because it does a great deal of things and

332
00:20:48.100 --> 00:20:49.310
it does mutate your array.

333
00:20:50.990 --> 00:20:52.970
So those are the mutator methods.

334
00:20:54.060 --> 00:20:59.720
Well, there's actually ways to transform,
move, change.

335
00:20:59.720 --> 00:21:06.490
But it does require us to kind of suspend
our misunderstanding of some new concepts.

336
00:21:06.490 --> 00:21:10.680
We're gonna actually have to declare some
functions which we will see more in depth

337
00:21:10.680 --> 00:21:11.930
at a later time.

338
00:21:11.930 --> 00:21:15.360
But just stay with me and
stay in awe of the magic.

339
00:21:15.360 --> 00:21:16.180
I hope it's magical.

340
00:21:16.180 --> 00:21:18.830
If it's not magical,
just pretend it's magic.

341
00:21:20.760 --> 00:21:22.850
So, we have myFavNums.

342
00:21:22.850 --> 00:21:27.870
I'm actually going to
say function doubler and

343
00:21:27.870 --> 00:21:32.480
that's going to take a number.

344
00:21:32.480 --> 00:21:38.289
And that's going to return
2 times that number.

345
00:21:38.289 --> 00:21:43.200
Okay, so whatever I give it it's
gonna give me back twice that.

346
00:21:43.200 --> 00:21:46.340
And I'm also gonna make tripler.

347
00:21:48.270 --> 00:21:49.580
And that's gonna take a number.

348
00:21:49.580 --> 00:21:51.429
I should be careful.

349
00:21:51.429 --> 00:21:57.967
I should make this num,
because number is a type.

350
00:21:57.967 --> 00:22:03.090
It's going to take a num,
and return 3 times num.

351
00:22:03.090 --> 00:22:06.880
Notice these are very similar,
other than the 2 and the 3 and the name.

352
00:22:06.880 --> 00:22:11.100
And we'll see how that plays into
function declarations later.

353
00:22:11.100 --> 00:22:12.860
So I've declared these functions and for

354
00:22:12.860 --> 00:22:14.860
now we're just gonna
leave those at the top.

355
00:22:16.620 --> 00:22:19.318
Well, we're treating
these like a number so

356
00:22:19.318 --> 00:22:22.304
what kind of array would
we need to use these with?

357
00:22:22.304 --> 00:22:25.251
Well, a number array,
otherwise it doesn't make any sense.

358
00:22:25.251 --> 00:22:30.703
Okay, let's see, so if I console that log,

359
00:22:30.703 --> 00:22:34.300
there is a way to map through.

360
00:22:34.300 --> 00:22:39.220
And what I mean by map is, apply this
function to each element of the array.

361
00:22:39.220 --> 00:22:44.050
So if I were to say doubler
of 42 I would get 84.

362
00:22:44.050 --> 00:22:50.777
Doubler of 23, I should get 26,
and doubler of 7, I should get 14.

363
00:22:50.777 --> 00:22:55.625
And I make sure I have all my splices so
we'll see the original version.

364
00:22:56.625 --> 00:23:02.898
We will say myFavNums.map doubler and

365
00:23:02.898 --> 00:23:07.135
then let's console log myFavNums again.

366
00:23:11.465 --> 00:23:14.660
Let's see, the output of that,
there it was originally.

367
00:23:14.660 --> 00:23:18.910
There's doubler applied, so
I've doubled each element.

368
00:23:18.910 --> 00:23:21.310
And then here is myFavNums again.

369
00:23:21.310 --> 00:23:22.240
That's kinda weird.

370
00:23:23.440 --> 00:23:28.070
Map is one of those functions that
actually returns you a copy with

371
00:23:28.070 --> 00:23:28.750
the changes.

372
00:23:28.750 --> 00:23:32.000
It's kinda like those string methods
that will return you a copy.

373
00:23:32.000 --> 00:23:35.684
So map doesn't change the original,
it is not a mutator method.

374
00:23:35.684 --> 00:23:40.634
It is instead a transformation
that returns you a copy by

375
00:23:40.634 --> 00:23:44.650
applying the function across the elements.

376
00:23:44.650 --> 00:23:47.770
[COUGH] So there's a couple other ones
that are like that that we do need another

377
00:23:47.770 --> 00:23:48.590
function for them.

378
00:23:50.190 --> 00:24:00.130
So let's make a function,
isLessThanTwo, okay.

379
00:24:00.130 --> 00:24:05.403
And that takes a number and
returns num less than 2.

380
00:24:05.403 --> 00:24:07.881
Okay, and
that's just gonna evaluate to a yes or no.

381
00:24:07.881 --> 00:24:08.693
Is it less than 2?

382
00:24:08.693 --> 00:24:09.534
Yes.

383
00:24:09.534 --> 00:24:11.929
Is it more than, or is it not less than 2?

384
00:24:11.929 --> 00:24:14.870
Excuse me, is it less than 2, yes or no?

385
00:24:14.870 --> 00:24:18.680
Well, how does that work, and
now I don't have to comment these out

386
00:24:18.680 --> 00:24:23.260
because the MAP method does
not alter the original array.

387
00:24:23.260 --> 00:24:27.260
So let's make a couple of copies here and
I'm gonna use this filter.

388
00:24:27.260 --> 00:24:33.740
Filter is a way to only get certain
portions of an array as a copy.

389
00:24:33.740 --> 00:24:37.460
So islessthantwo.

390
00:24:37.460 --> 00:24:42.830
Well, if I go back and look,
I should get absolutely nothing.

391
00:24:44.100 --> 00:24:46.400
I think I have a good
gut instinct about this.

392
00:24:46.400 --> 00:24:51.590
And I do actually get an empty array, but
notice the original one is still intact.

393
00:24:51.590 --> 00:24:54.940
And that's a great stance to take.

394
00:24:54.940 --> 00:24:58.000
Mutating arrays can be
problematic from time to time.

395
00:24:58.000 --> 00:25:01.780
If you can get away without mutating, it
will make your life a little bit easier.

396
00:25:03.160 --> 00:25:08.614
However, let's change
this to is more than 2,

397
00:25:08.614 --> 00:25:13.679
just to see, or actually IsMoreThanSeven.

398
00:25:15.607 --> 00:25:18.660
Cuz I know that seven is in the array.

399
00:25:18.660 --> 00:25:25.058
So I wanna see, does it filter out a
select portion of what is available to me?

400
00:25:25.058 --> 00:25:29.780
So, IsMoreThanSeven.

401
00:25:29.780 --> 00:25:33.610
So I should get only the numbers
within the myFavNums array

402
00:25:33.610 --> 00:25:35.250
that are bigger than seven.

403
00:25:37.290 --> 00:25:39.020
And I, in fact, get 42 and 13.

404
00:25:39.020 --> 00:25:42.310
But as a reminder,
the original array does not change.

405
00:25:43.640 --> 00:25:48.060
Now, those are kind of a great start to

406
00:25:49.340 --> 00:25:52.520
some pretty powerful applications
that you've seen on the Internet.

407
00:25:52.520 --> 00:25:57.410
This is actually the operations
that may occur in big data.

408
00:25:57.410 --> 00:26:01.530
They are not in JavaScript necessarily,
but they're for condensing down,

409
00:26:01.530 --> 00:26:06.380
manipulating data, and then having
websites or other applications built with

410
00:26:06.380 --> 00:26:10.740
JavaScript be very dynamic based
on just the decision making.

411
00:26:10.740 --> 00:26:16.023
In addition to these MAP filter
methods are a lot more readable

412
00:26:16.023 --> 00:26:20.706
than changing individual
elements within the array.

413
00:26:22.248 --> 00:26:23.261
>> All right, Justin,

414
00:26:23.261 --> 00:26:26.480
anything else we need to go over when
it comes to the world of arrays?

415
00:26:26.480 --> 00:26:28.130
A lot of great stuff, so far.

416
00:26:28.130 --> 00:26:30.170
>> No,
I think that actually gets a started.

417
00:26:30.170 --> 00:26:34.990
As always, we can always get really
nit picky with a data structure,

418
00:26:34.990 --> 00:26:38.070
but I think this will
serve our purpose well.

419
00:26:38.070 --> 00:26:39.290
>> All right, fantastic.

420
00:26:39.290 --> 00:26:43.410
Again, great demonstrations as always,
really thoroughly explaining

421
00:26:43.410 --> 00:26:46.220
what arrays are and what we can do with
them and how we can work with them.

422
00:26:46.220 --> 00:26:47.500
So we appreciate that.

423
00:26:47.500 --> 00:26:49.670
We hope everybody out there
enjoyed watching this one.

424
00:26:49.670 --> 00:26:52.630
Signing off for ITProTv,
I've been your host, Mike Rodrick.

425
00:26:52.630 --> 00:26:53.599
>> And I'm Justin Dennison.

426
00:26:53.599 --> 00:26:56.080
>> And we'll see you next time.

427
00:26:56.080 --> 00:27:02.061
>> [MUSIC]

428
00:27:02.061 --> 00:27:04.038
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Mike discuss objects. They define what an object is and look at it's properties and methods. They also demonstrate creating and working with an object.
episodes.title: Working with Objects

I don't know the taste of cars

So this should be no surprise, but now

Well, I know when I think about a car,

So number, and

I'm just brainstorming here and this is

Number of doors,
that's a good one and believe it or

Cuz there are some new cars

We can get super specific

[SOUND] I think that's some

But I have these properties and

Well if I knew that I was

I could build JavaScript objects that map

Now I'm talking kinda hand wavy

But trust me you'll see

So what can my car do first.

350
00:21:03.050 --> 00:21:05.360
Well a car.move.

351

And let's move three times.

I drove three blocks.

And then I turn.

356

Okay?

357

Now the power of this is our code

00:21:26.970 --> 00:21:28.460

359
00:21:28.460 --> 00:21:31.640
So instead of step 1, step 2, step 3.

360

It's still kind of in a list like that but

361
00:21:35.060 --> 00:21:35.660
So car.move.

362
00:21:35.660 --> 00:21:37.200
What's going on?

363
00:21:37.200 --> 00:21:38.610
The car's moving.

364
00:21:38.610 --> 00:21:39.310
Car.move again.

365
00:21:39.310 --> 00:21:40.400
So what's going on now?

366
00:21:40.400 --> 00:21:41.360
The car is moving.

367
00:21:41.360 --> 00:21:46.246
We don't have to worry ourselves with the
behind the scenes implementation details

368
00:21:46.246 --> 00:21:50.520

369
00:21:50.520 --> 00:21:53.900
What do we want to happen

370
00:21:53.900 --> 00:21:57.030
So let's see how this works out.

371
00:21:57.030 --> 00:22:00.010
There's my car,
let's look at the properties.

372
00:22:00.010 --> 00:22:03.960
I'm yellow Chevy Camaro, two doors,

373
00:22:03.960 --> 00:22:08.045
Notice vroom vroom vroom, so
I'm moving, moving, moving.

374
00:22:08.045 --> 00:22:12.190
Harooga, screech, and then I turn left.

375
00:22:12.190 --> 00:22:17.730
And my car has not changed, right?

376
00:22:17.730 --> 00:22:21.580
The car in not changing state, that's

377
00:22:21.580 --> 00:22:26.220
This is our starting to go a little deeper
on objects, but objects are incredibly

378
00:22:26.220 --> 00:22:32.620

and kinda moving around in fragments.

379
00:22:32.620 --> 00:22:39.200
It's also wonderful way to transmit

380
00:22:39.200 --> 00:22:43.410
And now you have to transform the object

381
00:22:43.410 --> 00:22:46.800
But now I have ways of
moving information around.

382
00:22:46.800 --> 00:22:50.580
>> So we might have a method
on this car called paint job.

383
00:22:50.580 --> 00:22:56.240
And then if we call that method, it might

384
00:22:56.240 --> 00:22:56.780
>> Exactly.

385
00:22:56.780 --> 00:23:00.540
And as a matter of fact Mike,
let's go ahead and see like, paint job.

386
00:23:02.120 --> 00:23:03.480
Or even paint.

387
00:23:03.480 --> 00:23:04.650
See how that would work.

388

Now keep in mind this is just
getting you familiar with

don't worry so

much if you're seeing some syntax and

Focus on how this is being constructed,

392
00:23:20.300 --> 00:23:24.270
So, let's actually make a paint.

393

Let's just call it paint.

And it takes a new color.

395
00:23:33.430 --> 00:23:39.020
And that new color says for this car,

396

Okay, so this keyword gets a little weird.

397
00:23:44.770 --> 00:23:50.480
We'll cover that in more depth later,
but I'm saying, okay,

398
00:23:50.480 --> 00:23:55.670
if I paint this car, whatever I tell it

399
00:23:55.670 --> 00:23:57.060
Let's test it out.

400
00:23:57.060 --> 00:24:00.320
In order to do that,
I actually was driving to the paint shop.

401
00:24:01.840 --> 00:24:06.360
So luckily I didn't get in an accident,
I was able to stop but I paint and

402
00:24:06.360 --> 00:24:10.970
this car was originally yellow,
I want it black.

403
00:24:10.970 --> 00:24:14.470
So let's paint it black and let's see.

404
00:24:14.470 --> 00:24:16.020
Well, yellow, and

00:24:16.020 --> 00:24:19.270
now the car has been painted black

406
00:24:19.270 --> 00:24:24.690
I have changed the state through the use

407

Car, paint, black, done.

00:24:27.270 --> 00:24:29.330
So very powerful.

409

And we will use these more, and more as

>> Fantastic Justin, way to take

and make it simple enough for

We love it.

Great demonstrations there.

414
00:24:44.090 --> 00:24:46.550
Objects.
Obviously very powerful.

415

Can be a little complex.

But I think now we've got a good
hand of it of what we can expect

417
00:24:51.090 --> 00:24:52.240
with working with objects.

418
00:24:52.240 --> 00:24:53.470
So we appreciate that.

419

We hope everybody out there

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Mike look at adding decision making capabilities to JavaScript. They look at if, else, and else if statements. They also demonstrate using a switch block.
episodes.title: Decisions IF Else and Switches
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:01.365
Welcome to ITPro.TV.

2
00:00:01.365 --> 00:00:02.134
I'm your host for Don Pezet.

3
00:00:02.134 --> 00:00:06.754
[CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:06.754 --> 00:00:09.528
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:09.528 --> 00:00:12.917
>> You're watching ITPro.TV
>> Hello,

6
00:00:12.917 --> 00:00:15.173
welcome to another exciting
episode here at ITPro.TV.

7
00:00:15.173 --> 00:00:17.420
I'm your host Mike Rodrick.

8

Today, we're doing our
introduction to JavaScript.

9

And in this episode, we're gonna be
talking a look at decision making.

10
00:00:23.405 --> 00:00:28.017
Ifs, elses, switches,
how do we make our program make decisions,

11
00:00:28.017 --> 00:00:30.174
or our JavaScript I should say.

12
00:00:30.174 --> 00:00:35.350
Here to explain it in much better detail
then I'm doing is Mr. Justin Dennison.

13
00:00:35.350 --> 00:00:35.862
Welcome back Justin.

14

>> Thanks for having me back Mike.

15
00:00:36.569 --> 00:00:41.154
Yeah, sometimes I get a little
confused as well, so don't worry.

16
00:00:41.154 --> 00:00:41.903
>> [LAUGH]
>> That's part of the game.

17
00:00:41.903 --> 00:00:46.150
So today, we're actually gonna
worry about making decisions.

18
00:00:46.150 --> 00:00:50.180
Now, I wanna take a step back
before we talk about technology.

19
00:00:50.180 --> 00:00:52.040
We make decisions every day.

20
00:00:52.040 --> 00:00:55.390
What shirt to wear, what shoes to put on,
what to eat for breakfast,

21
00:00:55.390 --> 00:00:56.010
lunch and dinner?

22
00:00:57.170 --> 00:00:59.300
And those decisions are very important,

23
00:00:59.300 --> 00:01:02.900
because sometimes those
decisions are safe for us.

24
00:01:02.900 --> 00:01:06.840
I know sometimes I'll be cooking and
take something out of the oven.

25
00:01:06.840 --> 00:01:11.720
And right before I grab it with my hand,
I'm like should I touch this,

26
00:01:11.720 --> 00:01:13.400
is it hot or is it not?

27
00:01:13.400 --> 00:01:18.191
And those decisions do define us
versus what we're currently writing.

28
00:01:18.191 --> 00:01:20.623
And that brings me to my second point,

29
00:01:20.623 --> 00:01:24.540
do you remember computers
only do what we tell them to.

30
00:01:24.540 --> 00:01:27.692
They're not magical
creatures inside of a box.

31
00:01:27.692 --> 00:01:32.110
We don't have just magic in a box even
though it does seem like magic sometimes.

32
00:01:33.530 --> 00:01:38.720
And we see some scientific renditions
of incredibly intelligent computers.

33
00:01:38.720 --> 00:01:42.600
For the most part, computers are only
there to execute commands that we have.

34
00:01:42.600 --> 00:01:45.680
So they only do what we tell them to do.

35
00:01:45.680 --> 00:01:49.860
And part of that is we need to give them
the ability to make some discernible

36
00:01:49.860 --> 00:01:52.090
kind of left right decision making.

37
00:01:52.090 --> 00:01:54.990
Do I take the left path or the right path?

38
00:01:54.990 --> 00:01:58.998
And we're gonna do that with
a common JavaScript constructs.

39
00:01:58.998 --> 00:02:02.690
So let's take a look and go ahead and
get our project started.

40
00:02:02.690 --> 00:02:06.350
So we can start with ifs,
elses, and switches.

41
00:02:06.350 --> 00:02:07.479
That's kind of a mouthful to say.

42
00:02:07.479 --> 00:02:08.224
>> It is.

43
00:02:08.224 --> 00:02:13.533
>> So I'm gonna open my project
directory and again that index.html,

44
00:02:13.533 --> 00:02:18.785
I'm hypervison, I was getting

45
00:02:18.785 --> 00:02:21.157
>> llll
>> We were about to see an example of what

46
00:02:21.157 --> 00:02:22.880
I've been warning about.

47

And I'm gonna go to hood and
open the dev tools while I'm here.

00:02:27.679 --> 00:02:31.408
And there we go, those keyboard shortcuts
will save you a lot of time, but

just as a reminder.

50

And then within Atom, I'm gonna add the
project folder for this decision making.

51
00:02:39.895 --> 00:02:44.836
Now, within this project we have
our index.html, again still blank,

52
00:02:44.836 --> 00:02:47.600
nothing special about it.

53
00:02:47.600 --> 00:02:50.443
In app.js,
we will have all of our existing code.

54
00:02:50.443 --> 00:02:53.280
What we're gonna write,
how it's gonna work?

55
00:02:53.280 --> 00:02:57.732
Now these will be a little more involved
examples because the entire purpose of

56
00:02:57.732 --> 00:03:00.904

to handle when things are,

57

they don't have a one way street.

58
00:03:02.870 --> 00:03:07.726
It's do I take a left or a right or

59

Or never been went to those places
has the giant round abouts,

60
00:03:11.470 --> 00:03:13.060
that has like nine exits.

61
00:03:13.060 --> 00:03:16.965
You like I don't, it says,
my GPS turn right.

62

>> [LAUGH]
>> But there are like seven rights.

63
00:03:18.776 --> 00:03:21.933
And I don't know where to turn,

64

So what is the best way

65

The first thing is kind of

If this pan is hot, should I touch it?

67
00:03:34.690 --> 00:03:37.618
If it is hot, I will not and

68
00:03:37.618 --> 00:03:42.590
We don't say that out loud to ourselves,
but intrinsically, we're kinda

69

thinking through that even if it's not
construct it like that as a thought.

70

So let's just start with

71

I'm gonna start with var and

73

>> And

00:04:01.650 --> 00:04:07.009

75
00:04:07.009 --> 00:04:09.021
If the day of the week and

I wanna make sure that I am exactly

77

Again, this triple equals

78

I wanna make string to string, and I wanna

79
00:04:21.244 --> 00:04:29.986
So if the day of the week is Friday Yehey!

80
00:04:29.986 --> 00:04:33.500

81
00:04:37.045 --> 00:04:41.017
Now as we've seen,

00:04:41.017 --> 00:04:44.790

83
00:04:44.790 --> 00:04:48.390
Well if I look here,
this should evaluate the true, so

effectively this will say if true.

Well if true will always execute,

if I type if true it's like I didn't

This if statement is gonna be a block, so

89

And notice these curly braces here, and

00:05:07.413 --> 00:05:12.920

91
00:05:12.920 --> 00:05:16.491
Then anything between these

92
00:05:16.491 --> 00:05:19.383

93
00:05:19.383 --> 00:05:24.760
So yehey, it's Friday or

94
00:05:24.760 --> 00:05:27.660
However, we have to be very careful

95
00:05:27.660 --> 00:05:31.860
Remember I said, I wanna check types and

96
00:05:31.860 --> 00:05:37.110
If I come to the day of the week and

98

Notice that this is a lowercase f and

99
00:05:47.621 --> 00:05:51.842
Well that if statement is no
longer comparing the same value to

100
00:05:51.842 --> 00:05:53.620
the same value.

101
00:05:53.620 --> 00:05:56.395
What I mean is lower case f Friday,

102
00:05:56.395 --> 00:06:01.388
strictly equal to upper case Friday,

103
00:06:01.388 --> 00:06:03.760
So okay, that's kind of weird.

104
00:06:05.120 --> 00:06:07.344
What's the best way to handle that?

105
00:06:07.344 --> 00:06:10.547
Well the best way to handle
that is in my sense,

106
00:06:10.547 --> 00:06:13.865
this is a common pattern

Especially with strings is try to

00:06:17.931 --> 00:06:21.572

109

And part of that is through some of

110
00:06:28.690 --> 00:06:32.605
And I'm saying,
if the lower case version of day

00:06:32.605 --> 00:06:36.820
week is strictly equal to Friday,
all lower cases.

112
00:06:36.820 --> 00:06:39.620
Now, I've removed
the capitalization issues.

113
00:06:39.620 --> 00:06:42.610
>> So wouldn't matter for
user type in Friday with a lowercase,

114
00:06:42.610 --> 00:06:45.031
Friday with an uppercase,
it would still match.

115
00:06:45.031 --> 00:06:48.449
>> Correct, and we will make sure,
I always like the test because sometimes I

116
00:06:48.449 --> 00:06:51.920
have these thoughts when I'm like,
that'll definitely work.

117
00:06:51.920 --> 00:06:52.668
And then it doesn't work.

118
00:06:52.668 --> 00:06:55.475
>> [LAUGH]
>> And I have to figure them out that's

119
00:06:55.475 --> 00:06:59.624
just part for the course, if my
assertion is correct this should work.

120
00:06:59.624 --> 00:07:03.778
It would have worked in this
case without two lowercase, but

121
00:07:03.778 --> 00:07:07.530
I'm preparing for
possible deviations in the input.

122
00:07:09.020 --> 00:07:12.220
So yey, it's the weekend and it works.

123
00:07:12.220 --> 00:07:17.050
Well let's see what happens

124
00:07:17.050 --> 00:07:20.824
Originally, these two comparisons
would now evaluate the false.

125
00:07:20.824 --> 00:07:26.946
Because the capital f and lower case
f are in fact different letters and

126
00:07:26.946 --> 00:07:29.447

127
00:07:29.447 --> 00:07:33.630
Yep, and it still prints out and

128
00:07:33.630 --> 00:07:37.800
Well I've now taken the lower
case version of the input and

129
00:07:37.800 --> 00:07:40.000
compared it to an all lowercase version.

130
00:07:40.000 --> 00:07:43.864
Now you could make the same
distinction with two uppercase and

131
00:07:43.864 --> 00:07:46.175

132
00:07:46.175 --> 00:07:49.548
I don't like typing capital letters,
cuz I gotta hold shift or

133
00:07:49.548 --> 00:07:52.423

then it just messes up my flow.

134
00:07:52.423 --> 00:07:58.279
[COUGH] Now within this day of the week,
I have this comparison here.

135
00:07:58.279 --> 00:08:02.609
But right now.

136
00:08:02.609 --> 00:08:05.539
If it is Friday,
it's the start of the weekend.

137
00:08:05.539 --> 00:08:14.290
But if it's not, I could just put
('This is just another weekday').

138
00:08:14.290 --> 00:08:16.950
And there could be some
argument may that Friday is

139
00:08:16.950 --> 00:08:18.535
still technically part of the week.

140
00:08:18.535 --> 00:08:21.640
>> [LAUGH]
>> So, let's not split hairs there,

141
00:08:21.640 --> 00:08:26.720
but as I've constructed this,
this is gonna run from top to bottom.

142
00:08:26.720 --> 00:08:29.470
Declare variable dayofweek
is equal to Friday.

143
00:08:29.470 --> 00:08:31.060
This would be some kind of user input.

144
00:08:33.530 --> 00:08:37.880
And then, if the day of the week is
equal to Friday, the lowercase version

145
00:08:37.880 --> 00:08:41.320
is equal to friday, then say, Yayyy!!,
It is the start of the weekend.

146
00:08:42.750 --> 00:08:44.890
Otherwise, notice this is outside.

147
00:08:44.890 --> 00:08:48.080
This is just another weekday.

148
00:08:48.080 --> 00:08:50.450
Now, that's how I've thought about this.

149
00:08:50.450 --> 00:08:55.520
But we have to be careful, because, I
don't know, something's not setting right.

150
00:08:55.520 --> 00:08:58.490
You ever have those gut feelings
where you're like, I don't know,

151
00:08:58.490 --> 00:09:00.560

152
00:09:01.790 --> 00:09:04.170
But there's only one way to find out.

153
00:09:04.170 --> 00:09:08.792
And I've noticed when I refresh, I get
Yayyy!!, It is the start of the weekend.

154
00:09:08.792 --> 00:09:10.510
This is just another weekday.

155
00:09:11.851 --> 00:09:16.900
>> Well that was not
my anticipated action.

the bottom, unless within that
case statement, you say break.

390
00:25:20.330 --> 00:25:23.450
And that means break the execution steps.

391
00:25:23.450 --> 00:25:28.090
I don't want to waterfall down through,
I want to stop here.

392
00:25:28.090 --> 00:25:31.780
And that is similar to adding
that else instead of the ifs

393
00:25:31.780 --> 00:25:34.760
instead of the just if, if, if.

394
00:25:34.760 --> 00:25:37.867
So if I add a break
within each one of these

395
00:25:43.590 --> 00:25:48.420
Then I in fact get my expected behavior.

396
00:25:50.260 --> 00:25:53.085
Now what happens if I change this to,

397
00:25:53.085 --> 00:25:57.126
I don't know,
what's your favorite number Mike?

398
00:25:57.126 --> 00:26:00.250
>> 24.
>> 24, all right, let's go with 24.

399
00:26:00.250 --> 00:26:02.930
I'm glad it wasn't 34, 57, or 42.

00:26:02.930 --> 00:26:07.350
You're like, you had all my favorite
numbers, so I gotta pick another one.

401
00:26:07.350 --> 00:26:08.865
Gonna fix a quick typo here.

402
00:26:08.865 --> 00:26:13.856
And let's see what happens when I

00:26:13.856 --> 00:26:15.227

00:26:15.227 --> 00:26:17.096

00:26:17.096 --> 00:26:18.050
I don't know.

00:26:40.580 --> 00:26:45.790
I need kind of that fall back option Okay,

415
00:26:47.120 --> 00:26:48.740
Well the rest of these,

00:26:48.740 --> 00:26:52.320
this case is trying to match

00:26:52.320 --> 00:26:53.836
But if I say default,

00:27:00.784 --> 00:27:02.470
I was getting ready to

00:27:04.600 --> 00:27:08.402
Let's just go with, uh-oh, defaultiness.

00:27:08.402 --> 00:27:11.120
>> [LAUGH]
>> It's a made up word.

00:27:11.120 --> 00:27:13.270
I think,
I'm pretty sure it's a made up word.

00:27:13.270 --> 00:27:14.270
And then don't forget to break.

00:27:16.280 --> 00:27:18.460
This default doesn't necessarily

00:27:18.460 --> 00:27:20.990
I tend to put it at the end just for

00:27:20.990 --> 00:27:24.870

00:27:24.870 --> 00:27:29.160
If none of other ones are matched, I have

00:27:30.350 --> 00:27:35.390
and that means that it would probably

00:27:35.390 --> 00:27:39.030
kind of machinations or in the middle.

429
00:27:39.030 --> 00:27:43.430
I recommend at the bottom because that's
your fallback, that's the last option.

430
00:27:43.430 --> 00:27:44.740
And that's how I think of it.

431
00:27:44.740 --> 00:27:47.640
There are times where
that paradigm may change.

432
00:27:47.640 --> 00:27:49.628
So let's see how this works out.

433
00:27:49.628 --> 00:27:51.070
The faultiness!

434
00:27:51.070 --> 00:27:56.770
So now I have a fall back statement and
this is handy if I'm using this switch to

435
00:27:56.770 --> 00:28:01.500
define another variable like x so
I have x here.

436
00:28:02.540 --> 00:28:08.120
And I have, let's say,
in forty, I say X equals ten.

437
00:28:10.310 --> 00:28:13.760
And here, I say X equals zero.

438
00:28:13.760 --> 00:28:19.100
I want default to assign that to zero
if none of the other cases catch.

439
00:28:19.100 --> 00:28:22.950
If I didn't have this default and

440
00:28:24.640 --> 00:28:29.630

441
00:28:29.630 --> 00:28:35.210
variable which can lead to runtime errors,
all kinds of crazy stuff.

442
00:28:35.210 --> 00:28:36.420
Undefined is not a function.

443
00:28:36.420 --> 00:28:45.850
So just to see, So
right now another number is 34.

444
00:28:45.850 --> 00:28:48.840
It should catch on case 34.

445
00:28:48.840 --> 00:28:51.600
And, okay, that's nice.

446
00:28:53.570 --> 00:28:54.850
Wait for it, wait for it.

447
00:28:54.850 --> 00:28:56.830
I have undefined.

448
00:28:56.830 --> 00:28:58.110
And that's because I have a break.

449
00:28:59.710 --> 00:29:05.350
So I have my break here and
that's an anticipated behavior so

450
00:29:05.350 --> 00:29:09.410
if you're assigning variables
within switch statements you should

451
00:29:09.410 --> 00:29:14.660
always assign variables for each case or
devised your switch statements to where

452
00:29:14.660 --> 00:29:17.620
it kind of falls through and
use that cascade to your advantage.

453
00:29:18.730 --> 00:29:23.010
So be very aware that if
you're making assignments,

454
00:29:23.010 --> 00:29:26.090
reassignments, doing some kind of
transformations within switches.

455
00:29:27.180 --> 00:29:29.460
You may end up with some errors.

456
00:29:29.460 --> 00:29:34.660
Just like I will still have an error here
if I had another number as 57 because

457
00:29:34.660 --> 00:29:39.160
in that case would not
assign any value to x.

458
00:29:39.160 --> 00:29:44.210
Another way to get around that and this is
kind of a preferred method of mine is if

459
00:29:44.210 --> 00:29:48.300
you needed to fall assignment,
and you only want to change,

460
00:29:48.300 --> 00:29:52.560
if the switch catches,
then assign it at the beginning and

461
00:29:52.560 --> 00:29:56.250
only change within the case statements or
the if fail statements.

462
00:29:56.250 --> 00:30:02.078
So, have a value there and then you don't
end up with undefined stuff That occurs.

463
00:30:02.078 --> 00:30:05.580
So we've seen several
ways to make decisions.

464
00:30:05.580 --> 00:30:08.250
Now these are very much contextual.

465
00:30:08.250 --> 00:30:11.450
We've seen some nice
examples to think about.

466
00:30:11.450 --> 00:30:12.930
But how do we use these?

467
00:30:12.930 --> 00:30:15.340
How are these gonna be useful to us?

468
00:30:16.480 --> 00:30:20.310
Well, that's one of those things
where the context really does matter.

469
00:30:20.310 --> 00:30:21.897
And we will definitely
see that at some point.

470
00:30:21.897 --> 00:30:23.120
>> All right, Justin.

471
00:30:23.120 --> 00:30:28.140
Fantastic, look at how we can include
decision making in our Java Script using

472
00:30:28.140 --> 00:30:30.860
if's, else if's and our switch cases.

473
00:30:30.860 --> 00:30:31.850
So we appreciate that,

474
00:30:31.850 --> 00:30:35.450
great demonstrations, hope everybody
out there enjoyed watching this one.

475
00:30:35.450 --> 00:30:38.580
Signing off for ITPROTV,
I've been your host Mike Roderick.

476
00:30:38.580 --> 00:30:39.600
>> And I'm Justin Dennison.

477
00:30:39.600 --> 00:30:41.591
>> And we'll see you next time

478
00:30:41.591 --> 00:30:47.608
[MUSIC]

479
00:30:47.608 --> 00:30:52.089
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Mike demonstrate working with loops. They look at for loops, used when you know how many iterations you need. They also look at while loops, that loop until something happens.
episodes.title: Working with Loops

And I do have a couple of

cuz if I hand Mike a hammer,

console.log"Found letters" +

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Mike continue their look into loops. This time they look at do while loops that always run once. They also look at for in loops, used to cycle through a collection.
episodes.title: Working with Loops Part 2

Your

I want to have a collection,

Unexpected token.
