00:08:55.040 --> 00:08:59.440
I actually might be yeah,

135
00:08:59.440 --> 00:09:04.160
so unit I fill it in it's gonna give
me an error so be aware of that.

136
00:09:04.160 --> 00:09:08.250
So, I have this object that has keys and
values.

137
00:09:08.250 --> 00:09:12.230
So, this four n loop will
actually run through keys,

138
00:09:12.230 --> 00:09:16.770
I could use those to retrieve the values,
but it allows me not to have to.

139
00:09:18.500 --> 00:09:20.300
Go how am I gonna run through this object.

140
00:09:20.300 --> 00:09:21.680
I wanna just loop through and

141
00:09:21.680 --> 00:09:25.980
see if any of these keys have
a corresponding value of two.

142
00:09:25.980 --> 00:09:30.040
Or I just wanna see if
the key b is in there.

143
00:09:30.040 --> 00:09:32.030
So, the for end is helpful for that.

144
00:09:32.030 --> 00:09:35.380
And there are times when I just
want to collect all the keys.

145
00:09:35.380 --> 00:09:40.848
And we'll actually see that as an example
but let's start with var key in obj.

146
00:09:44.674 --> 00:09:47.830
And let's just log that and
see what it logs out.

147
00:09:47.830 --> 00:09:49.780
Now, I've obviously picked
the variable name here

148
00:09:51.110 --> 00:09:53.120
because I know what this is going to do.

149
00:09:53.120 --> 00:09:56.110
In times like this,
if I'm just testing around,

150
00:09:56.110 --> 00:10:00.580
I may very well just use x or
a or something of that nature.

151
00:10:00.580 --> 00:10:02.980
But let's see how that works out.

152
00:10:02.980 --> 00:10:08.100
And it prints a, b, c, it runs
through all of the keys of the object.

153
00:10:08.100 --> 00:10:11.960
Well, that's handy because there's
times where I just wanna know what

154
00:10:11.960 --> 00:10:12.810
the properties are.

155
00:10:12.810 --> 00:10:14.840
I don't wanna know what their values are,

156
00:10:14.840 --> 00:10:19.410
I just wanna collect all the properties
from the object into an array,

157
00:10:20.610 --> 00:10:24.460
and that way I can kind of pass that
information around and loop back through.

158
00:10:25.970 --> 00:10:28.390
So, let's collect the keys

159
00:10:32.170 --> 00:10:36.439
of the object and
again we're gonna start with.

160
00:10:37.460 --> 00:10:39.620
Kind of a results.

161
00:10:39.620 --> 00:10:43.859
Our end results will be here, but
it's going to be empty for now.

162
00:10:45.425 --> 00:10:51.081
And all I wanna do is gather the keys into
this array, and that way I can keep just

163
00:10:51.081 --> 00:10:57.020
the keys as strings instead of having to
use this for(var key in obj) every time.

164
00:10:57.020 --> 00:11:01.630
So this is a quick little helper to just
gather all of those into a collection.

165
00:11:01.630 --> 00:11:11.450
And I just say results.push Keys and
just to look at those.

166
00:11:17.453 --> 00:11:18.600
And there we go.

167
00:11:18.600 --> 00:11:21.870
My fingers are getting a little
tripped up on me there, Mike.

168
00:11:21.870 --> 00:11:22.810
You gotta be careful.

169
00:11:23.870 --> 00:11:27.390
So keys is not defined.

170
00:11:28.820 --> 00:11:29.430
No, there we go.

171
00:11:29.430 --> 00:11:34.860
And now, I have an array that is
representing all the property names.

172
00:11:34.860 --> 00:11:38.030
All right, I've used a, b, and c here, but

173
00:11:38.030 --> 00:11:41.920
it would represent all of the property
names for that particular object.

174
00:11:41.920 --> 00:11:49.258
If this object was not just obj with a,
b, c, but instead, like car, with make,

175
00:11:54.378 --> 00:11:58.950
Model, and color as the properties for
that object.

176
00:11:58.950 --> 00:12:02.430
When I gather all of
the keys can't use obj now.

177
00:12:05.428 --> 00:12:08.906
Car, be careful with that multiselect
cuz it'll do weird things in

178
00:12:08.906 --> 00:12:09.975
the comments also.

179
00:12:09.975 --> 00:12:12.740
>> [LAUGH]
>> So, now I know,

180
00:12:12.740 --> 00:12:17.520
well cars have this defined,
make, model, and

181
00:12:17.520 --> 00:12:22.150
color and I won't try to say,
well, how many horsepower is it?

182
00:12:22.150 --> 00:12:24.260
Or, how many wheels does it have?

183
00:12:24.260 --> 00:12:27.615
So it allows me to do a quick
inspection and I can use that for

184
00:12:27.615 --> 00:12:30.510
decision-making processes.

185
00:12:30.510 --> 00:12:35.250
And that's a quick little helper just to
gather the information from an object

186
00:12:35.250 --> 00:12:35.850
into an array.

187
00:12:37.380 --> 00:12:43.330
So, as a review, we've had a while,
a do while, a for.

188
00:12:43.330 --> 00:12:46.410
A regular for
loop with just counting and then,

189
00:12:46.410 --> 00:12:50.060
running through the keys with the for
in loop.

190
00:12:50.060 --> 00:12:55.790
There are additional loops being
proposed for JavaScript language

191
00:12:57.130 --> 00:13:00.830
but, they're not currently ubiquitously
available in all browser so

192
00:13:00.830 --> 00:13:03.450
we're gonna focus on the ones
that are pretty pervasive.

193
00:13:04.540 --> 00:13:08.260
Remember the fours,
not the regular four loop,

194
00:13:08.260 --> 00:13:11.800
is designed to run through
a particular number of things.

195
00:13:11.800 --> 00:13:13.550
Think of a raise or strings.

196
00:13:14.620 --> 00:13:20.520
The wiles, if you ever say the words
I need to do something until,

197
00:13:20.520 --> 00:13:22.590
as soon as you say until to yourself.

198
00:13:24.030 --> 00:13:26.770
I should probably use a wow or
maybe even a do wow if I need to.

199
00:13:26.770 --> 00:13:31.090
I need to do this at least once,
but then it needs to run until.

200
00:13:31.090 --> 00:13:31.900
So, think of until.

201
00:13:33.150 --> 00:13:39.500
And lastly, just as a reminder, be careful
with wows and do wows for infinite loops.

202
00:13:39.500 --> 00:13:43.950
If you're not changing part of the state,
like that count variable, or the start, or

203
00:13:43.950 --> 00:13:45.070
the index.

204
00:13:45.070 --> 00:13:46.890
If you're not changing
that within the WOW loop,

205
00:13:46.890 --> 00:13:48.870
you could run into
an infinite loop situation.

206
00:13:48.870 --> 00:13:53.590
That will lock up your browser; it's
more annoying than it is dangerous.

207
00:13:53.590 --> 00:13:57.300
But maybe you have a bunch of tabs
open and your history automatically

208
00:13:57.300 --> 00:14:01.510
clears upon restart, and
you really need to know that information.

209
00:14:01.510 --> 00:14:04.220
It's not the end of the world,
but it can be.

210
00:14:04.220 --> 00:14:05.380
Very dissettling.

211
00:14:05.380 --> 00:14:07.760
So, be careful about those infinite loops.

212
00:14:07.760 --> 00:14:09.460
And if Chrome ever asks you hey,

213
00:14:09.460 --> 00:14:12.690
this looks like an infinite loop,
are you sure you wanna run?

214
00:14:12.690 --> 00:14:13.595
Don't click yes.

215
00:14:13.595 --> 00:14:18.340
>> [LAUGH] All right, words to live
by there from Justin Dennison.

216
00:14:18.340 --> 00:14:22.450
We appreciate that, great round out on the
different types of loop constructs we have

217
00:14:22.450 --> 00:14:25.590
within our JavaScript, so thank you for
those great demonstrations.

218
00:14:25.590 --> 00:14:27.740
Hope everybody out there
enjoyed watching this one.

219
00:14:27.740 --> 00:14:30.843
Signing off from ITPRO.TV,
I'm been you're host Mike Rodrick

220
00:14:30.843 --> 00:14:31.846
>> And I'm Justin Dennison

221
00:14:31.846 --> 00:14:32.769
>> And we'll see you next time.

222
00:14:32.769 --> 00:14:40.398
[MUSIC]

223
00:14:40.398 --> 00:14:44.844
Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Mike begin their look into functions in JavaScript. They discuss what a function is and why we use them. They also talk about function scope.
episodes.title: Working with Functions
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.002 --> 00:00:02.949
Welcome to ITPRO.TV,
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.949 --> 00:00:08.499
[CROSSTALK]
[SOUND]

3
00:00:08.499 --> 00:00:12.660
>> You're watching ITPRO.TV.

4
00:00:12.660 --> 00:00:16.230
>> Hello, welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITPRO.TV.

5
00:00:16.230 --> 00:00:17.580
I'm your host, Mike Rodrick, and

6
00:00:17.580 --> 00:00:20.100
today we're doing our
introduction to JavaScript.

7
00:00:20.100 --> 00:00:23.720
In this episode, we're gonna be
looking at functions, all right,

8
00:00:23.720 --> 00:00:27.670
a very important part, gives us a lot
of power within our JavaScript.

9
00:00:27.670 --> 00:00:30.995
So here to tell us how to create them and
what we can do with them is Mr.

10
00:00:30.995 --> 00:00:31.640
Justin Dennison.

11
00:00:31.640 --> 00:00:32.570
Welcome back, Justin.

12
00:00:32.570 --> 00:00:33.920
>> Thanks for having me back, Mike.

13
00:00:33.920 --> 00:00:36.794
I do wanna emphasize the fun in function.

14
00:00:36.794 --> 00:00:37.730
>> [LAUGH]
>> Or

15
00:00:37.730 --> 00:00:40.720
maybe I'm just being
a little dramatic about it.

16
00:00:40.720 --> 00:00:43.395
>> Hey, we're geeks, and
everybody out there is a geek, so

17
00:00:43.395 --> 00:00:44.820
we should find functions fun.

18
00:00:44.820 --> 00:00:46.680
>> Fun is the emphasis there.

19
00:00:46.680 --> 00:00:52.474
So I do agree that functions can
be a little intimidating at times,

20
00:00:52.474 --> 00:00:56.519
but they provide a wonderful
amount of power.

21
00:00:56.519 --> 00:00:57.880
Why do we use functions?

22
00:00:58.940 --> 00:01:04.170
Well, the easiest way to explain it is,
we want to encapsulate

23
00:01:04.170 --> 00:01:07.440
all of this functionality, these steps
that we've been working through.

24
00:01:07.440 --> 00:01:10.480
Okay, I need to do this next,
and this next, and this next.

25
00:01:10.480 --> 00:01:12.220
And as we're building larger and
larger projects,

26
00:01:12.220 --> 00:01:17.360
we find we keep doing those same
steps over and over and over again.

27
00:01:17.360 --> 00:01:21.160
And I'll forewarn you, the first initial
instinct is to go, well, I'm just gonna

28
00:01:21.160 --> 00:01:27.900
highlight that, Ctrl+C, or Cmd+C, paste
it over here, change a couple of things.

29
00:01:27.900 --> 00:01:30.020
However, there's a couple
of issues with that.

30
00:01:30.020 --> 00:01:31.480
Number one, copying and

31
00:01:31.480 --> 00:01:34.980
pasting, if you don't do it just correct,
now you have syntax errors.

32
00:01:34.980 --> 00:01:37.960
In addition to, if you have what
are runtime errors, which you

33
00:01:37.960 --> 00:01:42.000
won't really know until you start testing
your application a little more, those will

34
00:01:42.000 --> 00:01:46.410
propagate throughout your app, and
now you have to fix it a bunch of places.

35
00:01:46.410 --> 00:01:49.850
I've actually seen copy,
paste it functions five, six times, and

36
00:01:49.850 --> 00:01:52.800
I'm like that's actually
supposed to be a plus three.

37
00:01:52.800 --> 00:01:55.730
Or hey, that shouldn't be a string.

38
00:01:55.730 --> 00:01:57.670
And now you have to do a giant find and

39
00:01:57.670 --> 00:02:01.930
replace and hope that you haven't used
the same variable name other places.

40
00:02:01.930 --> 00:02:03.811
It can be [CROSSTALK]
>> Sounds like a mess.

41
00:02:03.811 --> 00:02:06.850
>> It's absolutely horrible.

42
00:02:06.850 --> 00:02:10.510
As someone who's had to fix things
like that, I don't recommend it.

43
00:02:11.810 --> 00:02:16.070
Now, when you're constructing functions,
there's a couple of things

44
00:02:16.070 --> 00:02:20.510
that do hold people back, and
that's the syntax and how to use them.

45
00:02:20.510 --> 00:02:21.820
We will cover both of those, but

46
00:02:21.820 --> 00:02:24.540
be very careful about making
sure everything's paired up.

47
00:02:24.540 --> 00:02:28.768
Curly braces and parentheses always
have pairs, shoes, mittens, socks.

48
00:02:28.768 --> 00:02:32.619
>> [LAUGH]
>> Anything that has pairs, your pants,

49
00:02:32.619 --> 00:02:34.190
pairs of legs.

50
00:02:34.190 --> 00:02:37.637
If you have pants and you dig them out of
your closet and one of the legs is gone,

51
00:02:37.637 --> 00:02:40.575
you should probably, I don't know,
maybe that's your thing.

52
00:02:40.575 --> 00:02:42.001
>> That might be a big runtime error.

53
00:02:42.001 --> 00:02:44.110
>> Yeah,
that might be a big runtime error.

54
00:02:44.110 --> 00:02:46.040
I'm getting weird looks at the office,
yeah,

55
00:02:46.040 --> 00:02:48.740
it's cuz you only have
one leg in your pants.

56
00:02:48.740 --> 00:02:53.090
So we use functions to
encapsulate this behavior, and

57
00:02:53.090 --> 00:02:56.060
we get this reusability that we can
kind of port between applications.

58
00:02:57.110 --> 00:02:59.840
So I can write functions
that I use everywhere,

59
00:02:59.840 --> 00:03:03.949
keep those in a separate project, and
then just use them as I need them.

60
00:03:03.949 --> 00:03:07.178
So I like that portability,
that encapsulation,

61
00:03:07.178 --> 00:03:12.300
that kind of bundling together, and
that's what makes them so powerful.

62
00:03:12.300 --> 00:03:15.590
>> And like you said at the beginning,
the copy and paste method doesn't work,

63
00:03:15.590 --> 00:03:17.590
if I've got an error in the first one.

64
00:03:17.590 --> 00:03:21.120
But likewise, I guess with the inverse,
if I've troubleshot that function,

65
00:03:21.120 --> 00:03:25.853
I know it works, everything's perfect
every time I use it, it should be good.

66
00:03:25.853 --> 00:03:31.225
>> Exactly, through use and reuse, you can
find those little errors, iron them out,

67
00:03:31.225 --> 00:03:36.159
and now you have a better well defined
algorithm, set of steps, procedure.

68
00:03:36.159 --> 00:03:41.097
Whatever you end up having within
that function body that you know

69
00:03:41.097 --> 00:03:43.780
works can be reliable.

70
00:03:43.780 --> 00:03:47.735
Now within functions,
there's this concept called scope.

71
00:03:47.735 --> 00:03:50.800
In JavaScript, we have this idea of scope.

72
00:03:50.800 --> 00:03:55.910
I like to think of scope as you have
a global scope, which is your house.

73
00:03:55.910 --> 00:04:00.077
And then each room within your house or
your apartment or any other dwelling that

74
00:04:00.077 --> 00:04:04.115
you're in, as long as it has kind of
segmented, I guess if you're in a tent,

75
00:04:04.115 --> 00:04:06.468
that wouldn't really work, but-
>> [LAUGH] Well,

76
00:04:06.468 --> 00:04:08.345
have you seen some of these
bigger tents nowadays?

77
00:04:08.345 --> 00:04:11.330
>> Yeah, I have, they're like,
this is a tutu tent?

78
00:04:12.920 --> 00:04:15.745
Okay, all right,
big enough for king size beds.

79
00:04:15.745 --> 00:04:17.889
Yeah, I've seen those,
they're kind of crazy.

80
00:04:19.060 --> 00:04:22.860
So I like to think as the function
scopes as these little compartments.

81
00:04:22.860 --> 00:04:28.440
The rooms within those, and
typically, if I'm in my bedroom,

82
00:04:28.440 --> 00:04:34.130
I can't just reach through a wall and
grab something from the kitchen, right?

83
00:04:34.130 --> 00:04:39.527
So I have these kind of isolated areas
where my bedroom has all the contents

84
00:04:39.527 --> 00:04:45.500
that it has within it, my kitchen has
all the contents that it has within it.

85
00:04:45.500 --> 00:04:48.730
And I have to move between those,

86
00:04:48.730 --> 00:04:53.840
through kind of message passing or
actually moving between the functions,

87
00:04:53.840 --> 00:04:58.060
or the rooms, in this case, in order to
get that information out of those objects.

88
00:04:58.060 --> 00:05:00.650
Now, keep in mind there's a global scope.

89
00:05:00.650 --> 00:05:06.030
Your house does provide portions
to each one of those functions,

90
00:05:06.030 --> 00:05:09.470
such as all of the rooms in
your house have electricity.

91
00:05:09.470 --> 00:05:13.340
Some of them have water, so
we kind of have this trickling in.

92
00:05:13.340 --> 00:05:18.298
Now, keep in mind that's not the absolute
correct technical detail, but

93
00:05:18.298 --> 00:05:20.670
it's a great way to think about it.

94
00:05:20.670 --> 00:05:26.450
And if you can conceptualize, you'll have
a lot better time working with JavaScript.

95
00:05:26.450 --> 00:05:30.582
So, I think the best thing that we can
do is actually take a look at a few

96
00:05:30.582 --> 00:05:34.519
functions and see how we can
construct them, how we can use them.

97
00:05:34.519 --> 00:05:40.013
And then really start to see the power
that they come into them, as we implement

98
00:05:40.013 --> 00:05:45.440
some reusable features that I use
quite often in the projects that I do.

99
00:05:45.440 --> 00:05:47.190
>> All right, fantastic, let's see it.

100
00:05:47.190 --> 00:05:50.205
>> All right, so I have my Chrome open,
and I'm gonna go ahead and open that

101
00:05:50.205 --> 00:05:54.680
index.html that I've been opening,
making sure that I'm in the correct one.

102
00:05:55.800 --> 00:06:00.830
So here's my function folder, index.html,
and again, this is just the entry way.

103
00:06:00.830 --> 00:06:04.300
I'm gonna open the dev tools,
and that's the keyboard shortcut.

104
00:06:04.300 --> 00:06:08.790
On Mac, it's Option, or Alt, and Cmd+I.

105
00:06:08.790 --> 00:06:14.690
On Windows, I think it's Ctrl+Opt+I,
I'm not 100% sure.

106
00:06:14.690 --> 00:06:18.210
If you wanna know, you can actually
just click More Tools, and

107
00:06:18.210 --> 00:06:22.060
it will tell you what the shortcut
is right next to there.

108
00:06:22.060 --> 00:06:23.071
So I have this open,

109
00:06:23.071 --> 00:06:26.232
the console's gonna be where I
work most of the time right now.

110
00:06:26.232 --> 00:06:29.800
And then I'm gonna go into Atom and
open up my project folder.

111
00:06:32.720 --> 00:06:37.580
Make sure I navigate to the appropriate
folder, and I'm ready to go.

112
00:06:37.580 --> 00:06:41.140
So, within my app.js,
I can start writing functions.

113
00:06:41.140 --> 00:06:45.040
So let's take a look at just
a basic construction of functions.

114
00:06:45.040 --> 00:06:48.070
Functions have a couple of forms.

115
00:06:48.070 --> 00:06:49.679
Well, they have more
than a couple of forms.

116
00:06:51.870 --> 00:06:58.280
printWord, and I wanna really pin down,
notice I have the keyword function.

117
00:06:58.280 --> 00:07:03.449
A common error that I will see is
people who are using other editors,

118
00:07:03.449 --> 00:07:06.714
they will leave out a word in function,
and

119
00:07:06.714 --> 00:07:10.965
then JavaScript doesn't
parse that correctly.

120
00:07:10.965 --> 00:07:17.330
That's kinda funtion, or funtion,
or the one that I like is funcion.

121
00:07:18.470 --> 00:07:22.720
So be very careful about that,
that's why I like these rich text editors.

122
00:07:24.020 --> 00:07:28.000
Function names typically
are named similar to variables.

123
00:07:28.000 --> 00:07:31.200
And I have a set of parentheses and
a set of curly braces.

124
00:07:31.200 --> 00:07:33.570
This is evident in all
functions that you write.

125
00:07:35.150 --> 00:07:37.090
This is when you're defining the function.

126
00:07:38.440 --> 00:07:40.360
So, I have all of these paired up.

127
00:07:40.360 --> 00:07:43.983
What I do is write all that out and
then I break up the curly braces.

128
00:07:43.983 --> 00:07:48.002
Between the left, or
what I call the opening, and the right,

129
00:07:48.002 --> 00:07:53.181
what I call the closing, that's where
all of my information, all of my steps,

130
00:07:53.181 --> 00:07:57.540
my procedures, my data is going
to be typed, written, and held.

131
00:07:57.540 --> 00:08:02.050
So if I just wanna say printWord I

132
00:08:02.050 --> 00:08:06.910
can say Word up, just like so.

133

00:08:46.450 --> 00:08:51.890

Well, this is what is called a callable.

00:08:54.990 --> 00:08:58.810

00:09:03.390 --> 00:09:06.740

00:09:07.980 --> 00:09:09.790

different from a variable then,

where I can just use the variable name.

00:09:11.770 --> 00:09:14.450

However, this is not the only

you're actually assigning

00:11:38.840 --> 00:11:40.370

00:11:40.370 --> 00:11:44.942

00:11:44.942 --> 00:11:48.530

>> Be very careful, because you can

00:12:14.370 --> 00:12:15.490
That's the technical term.

00:12:15.490 --> 00:12:17.660
But, effectively you're just

00:12:21.920 --> 00:12:26.980
So, it's like with using the home analogy,

In this when we declared that variable

00:13:43.790 --> 00:13:48.778
Now, despite being able to do this, and

That eliminate this, because this

00:14:03.830 --> 00:14:07.991
Which other parts of your application

00:14:16.670 --> 00:14:18.620

00:14:18.620 --> 00:14:23.410
I will try to make functions as

00:14:23.410 --> 00:14:27.490
or completely de-coupled if

00:14:27.490 --> 00:14:30.730

00:18:03.520 --> 00:18:06.220
As soon as I hit a return statement,

00:18:08.140 --> 00:18:12.380

00:18:12.380 --> 00:18:15.320
Now, there are additional tools

00:18:22.670 --> 00:18:26.230

Like if I wanted to multiply

00:18:38.202 --> 00:18:45.290

00:18:45.290 --> 00:18:47.815

00:19:18.090 --> 00:19:20.489
So now I'm just gonna put a 1 here.

00:19:20.489 --> 00:19:24.236
And we will see that now instead of 5,

00:19:24.236 --> 00:19:28.318
because I've multiplied both

00:19:28.318 --> 00:19:31.370
And returned num1 + anotherNum1.

00:19:33.410 --> 00:19:37.034
Now, it's kinda odd,

316
00:19:37.034 --> 00:19:38.156
I have a variable here.

00:19:40.408 --> 00:19:42.300
This variable was
available within printNum.

318
00:19:43.390 --> 00:19:48.993
But, is it the case that num1 is
available after the function is done?

319
00:19:48.993 --> 00:19:52.490
The easiest way to always check that,

320
00:19:52.490 --> 00:19:57.730
is just see if it exists,
see if it has anything.

321
00:19:57.730 --> 00:20:01.400
So num1 is not defined.

322
00:20:01.400 --> 00:20:02.190
Well, why is that?

323
00:20:04.250 --> 00:20:08.130
Variables are scoped to
the closest enclosing function.

324
00:20:08.130 --> 00:20:10.870
The JavaScript interpreter
in the Chrome browser is

325
00:20:10.870 --> 00:20:13.920
kind of a giant function
that's just running stuff.

326
00:20:13.920 --> 00:20:18.769
So this one's scoped globally to
the JavaScript interpreter in Chrome.

327
00:20:18.769 --> 00:20:23.210
But num1 and anotherNum1
are scoped just to that function.

328
00:20:23.210 --> 00:20:28.100
So as soon as I hit this return statement,
and the function spits out a value.

329
00:20:28.100 --> 00:20:31.746
I like to think of those as being
crushed out of existence, and

330
00:20:31.746 --> 00:20:34.281
then they're recreated again and again.

331
00:20:34.281 --> 00:20:37.364
In that way,
I don't have weird leakage, okay?

device had var num1 and

And not a word, not a name.

365
00:22:50.760 --> 00:22:54.130
So, these are declared name functions.

366
00:22:54.130 --> 00:22:56.120
These are called function expressions.

367
00:22:57.130 --> 00:23:01.769
So if I have var and some name equals,
that is a function expression.

368
00:23:04.261 --> 00:23:11.200
And in particular,
this is an unnamed function expression.

369
00:23:14.776 --> 00:23:19.030
However, there's actually a second
way to declare a function expression.

370
00:23:20.850 --> 00:23:27.978
I can subtract, And

00:23:27.978 --> 00:23:32.757
let's give the function expression
a name on the right hand side, and

00:23:32.757 --> 00:23:35.200
that looks kinda weird.

373
00:23:35.200 --> 00:23:38.330
These are anonymous, I don't have a name.

It's really hard for Chrome or any other
JavaScript interpreter to track it down,

375
00:23:42.420 --> 00:23:45.960
and let you know when you've used this and
something's went wrong.

376
00:23:45.960 --> 00:23:51.380
But if I give this a name, it'll say hey,

00:23:51.380 --> 00:23:55.019
But I can call it with instead just sub.

378
00:23:55.019 --> 00:23:57.627
So it's kind of like an alias for

379
00:23:57.627 --> 00:24:00.836
So let's take a look at real quick.

380
00:24:07.832 --> 00:24:11.474
[SOUND] Double quotes, so if you ever
want or need quotes inside of quotes,

00:24:11.474 --> 00:24:13.782
double quotes and
then single quotes inside.

382
00:24:13.782 --> 00:24:15.901
Or there are other ways.

383
00:24:15.901 --> 00:24:18.520
But I'm subtracting.

384
00:24:20.470 --> 00:24:22.955
It's a very, very high level function.

385
00:24:22.955 --> 00:24:23.940
>> [LAUGH]
>> Gotta watch out.

386
00:24:25.690 --> 00:24:26.210
You're on fire.

387

388

But at this point, if I call sub,

However, if I say subtract as such,

And that's because the alias that

00:24:50.553 --> 00:24:52.020

00:24:52.020 --> 00:24:56.310
So I'm creating a variable and

394
00:24:56.310 --> 00:24:58.460
>> Advantage,
disadvantage to doing it this way?

00:24:58.460 --> 00:25:02.535
Why would I want to,
instead of just declaring function

00:25:02.535 --> 00:25:06.980
subtract() do var sub

397
00:25:06.980 --> 00:25:12.000
>> So this is a way of having

00:25:12.000 --> 00:25:15.340
And then having kind of an alias for

399
00:25:16.820 --> 00:25:21.700
In addition to,
to some extent it's a level of preference.

400
00:25:21.700 --> 00:25:23.980
So we've seen three ways

00:25:26.040 --> 00:25:28.410
We have an unnamed function expression.

00:25:28.410 --> 00:25:30.780

And it has a name.

406

That was the one with function,

407

Now I have kind of a preference

Function some name,

And that's because we end up with some

But there are times where I need

414

>> So
we've seen how to declare a function.

It would be nice to see using these

417
00:26:12.433 --> 00:26:15.980
But, I don't know, maybe that's good for
another time, right?

418
00:26:15.980 --> 00:26:16.956
>> Think so?

419
00:26:16.956 --> 00:26:17.784
>> Yeah.
>> All right.

420
00:26:17.784 --> 00:26:18.637
Sounds like a plan then, Justin.

421
00:26:18.637 --> 00:26:20.143
We've got our basics down, right?

422
00:26:20.143 --> 00:26:24.009
We've seen three different ways
that we can create functions and

423

we've seen a little bit of

424
00:26:27.460 --> 00:26:31.500
They can actually take input and
they can produce output,

425

426
00:26:33.140 --> 00:26:34.980
So fantastic look there, Justin.

427
00:26:34.980 --> 00:26:38.010
Looking forward to seeing the rest of it,
how we can actually put these guys to use.

428
00:26:38.010 --> 00:26:39.700
But for now, we are out of time.

429
00:26:39.700 --> 00:26:43.190
So signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Mike Rodrick.

00:26:43.190 --> 00:26:44.105
>> And I'm Justin Dennison.

431
00:26:44.105 --> 00:26:45.627
>> [LAUGH] And we'll see you next time.

432
00:26:45.627 --> 00:26:53.185
>> [MUSIC]

433
00:26:53.185 --> 00:26:57.439
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Mike continue their look into functions in JavaScript. They demonstrate defining named and unnamed functions. They also describe hoisting functions and closure.
episodes.title: Working with Functions Part 2

00:25:17.785 --> 00:25:20.096
>> [LAUGH]
>> Of how to not name variables,

407
00:25:20.096 --> 00:25:21.100
don't do that.

408
00:25:21.100 --> 00:25:22.270
>> Something is not a good one?

409
00:25:22.270 --> 00:25:23.138
>> Yeah [LAUGH], something.

410
00:25:23.138 --> 00:25:26.740
>> [LAUGH]
>> Stuffandthing, something, yeah.

411
00:25:26.740 --> 00:25:27.260
What is that?

412
00:25:27.260 --> 00:25:28.380
That's the thing.

413
00:25:28.380 --> 00:25:29.150
What's that other?

414
00:25:29.150 --> 00:25:30.060
That's a thing.

415
00:25:30.060 --> 00:25:31.405
>> Should be perfectly clear to your team.

416
00:25:31.405 --> 00:25:33.130
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, yeah.

417
00:25:33.130 --> 00:25:33.840
What are all these?

418
00:25:33.840 --> 00:25:35.740
That's the stuff and things array.

419
00:25:35.740 --> 00:25:37.672
It's just got stuff and things in it.

420
00:25:37.672 --> 00:25:39.970
[LAUGH] So [LAUGH],
be very careful of that.

421
00:25:39.970 --> 00:25:42.080
But notice this printout for something.

422
00:25:43.120 --> 00:25:44.720
A double(3).

423
00:25:44.720 --> 00:25:49.287
Well, I wonder if triple works.

424
00:25:49.287 --> 00:25:50.816
Hey, nine.

425
00:25:50.816 --> 00:25:51.528
>> Mm-hm.

426
00:25:51.528 --> 00:25:55.545
>> Now, I have a function factory that
any time I need to make some kind of

427
00:25:55.545 --> 00:25:59.429
multiplied based function where
I'm multiplying by a constant,

428
00:25:59.429 --> 00:26:03.171
like I'm doubling, tripling,
four timsing, five timsing,

429
00:26:03.171 --> 00:26:03.900
I dont-
>> [LAUGH]

430
00:26:03.900 --> 00:26:05.340
>> The others ones don't have good names.

431
00:26:05.340 --> 00:26:07.010
Quadrupling, quintupling.

432
00:26:07.010 --> 00:26:08.190
>> There you go.

433
00:26:08.190 --> 00:26:12.640
>> I can then create this kind of state,

434
00:26:12.640 --> 00:26:15.390
this encapsulated state with
this multiply function.

435
00:26:16.605 --> 00:26:18.990
Multipliers being passed in, but

436
00:26:18.990 --> 00:26:22.930
this function's actually what's being
returned and assigned to double.

437
00:26:24.120 --> 00:26:27.420
This function remembers the environment
that it was created in.

438
00:26:27.420 --> 00:26:29.290
That is called a closure.

439
00:26:29.290 --> 00:26:33.390
So, I still have access to
state within this function.

440
00:26:33.390 --> 00:26:40.400
And just to show you, I'm gonna define
a variable cheese, and it just says Yum.

441
00:26:41.400 --> 00:26:46.434
And this inner function is
going to console.log(cheese).

442
00:26:48.070 --> 00:26:51.300
So, anytime I run this inner function,
which would be double or

443
00:26:51.300 --> 00:26:56.950
triple in this case, cuz that's what's
being returned, I should see Yum.

444
00:26:56.950 --> 00:26:59.600
Let's see if that is in fact the case,
and it is.

445
00:26:59.600 --> 00:27:01.680
It remembers that state.

446
00:27:01.680 --> 00:27:04.050
That's incredibly powerful cuz now,

447
00:27:04.050 --> 00:27:09.180
I can start bundling up pieces of
information and passing the round just by

448
00:27:09.180 --> 00:27:14.150
bundling them up in a function that kind
of has a reference to an environment.

449
00:27:15.240 --> 00:27:19.300
And I can separate those environments and
not kind of have bleeding over.

450
00:27:19.300 --> 00:27:23.100
So, very, very tricky stuff but
wonderful stuff.

451
00:27:23.100 --> 00:27:23.805
This makes me excited.

452
00:27:23.805 --> 00:27:27.220
>> [LAUGH]
>> Like the first time I saw this,

453
00:27:27.220 --> 00:27:30.320
I was like, whoa, that's crazy.

454
00:27:30.320 --> 00:27:33.510
So, don't worry if you're like,
that's really weird.

455
00:27:34.690 --> 00:27:39.720
It comes in handy in future
experiences that you may have.

456
00:27:39.720 --> 00:27:43.150
>> All right, Justin,
way to put the fun back in functions.

457
00:27:43.150 --> 00:27:44.540
We appreciate that great look.

458
00:27:44.540 --> 00:27:46.850
Hope everybody out there
enjoyed watching this one.

459
00:27:46.850 --> 00:27:48.000
Signing off for ITProTV.

460
00:27:48.000 --> 00:27:49.920
I've been your host, Mike Rodrick.

461
00:27:49.920 --> 00:27:51.000
>> And I'm Justin Dennison.

462
00:27:51.000 --> 00:27:59.891
>> And we'll see you next time.
[MUSIC]

463
00:27:59.891 --> 00:28:02.527
Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Mike look at object-oriented programming in JavaScript. They demonstrate using a factory function to create new objects. They also use a constructor function to add methods to an object.
episodes.title: Intro to Object-Oriented JavaScript

JavaScript.

22
00:01:03.920 --> 00:01:07.900
Hello, welcome to another

23
00:01:07.900 --> 00:01:09.210
I'm your host Mike Rodrick, and

24
00:01:09.210 --> 00:01:12.140
today we're doing our
Introduction to JavaScript.

25
00:01:12.140 --> 00:01:16.920
And in this episode, we're gonna be
looking at object oriented JavaScript.

26
00:01:16.920 --> 00:01:20.820
And here to show us the way, guide us
through this, is Mr. Justin Dennison.

27
00:01:20.820 --> 00:01:21.680
Welcome back, Justin.

28
00:01:21.680 --> 00:01:22.715
Thanks for having me back Mike.

29
00:01:22.715 --> 00:01:25.110
Yeah, object oriented JavaScript.

30
00:01:26.880 --> 00:01:28.720
Object oriented, what does that even mean?

31
00:01:28.720 --> 00:01:29.600
It's crazy.

32
00:01:30.760 --> 00:01:33.970
So let's talk about what an object is,
a little bit of a throwback.

33
00:01:33.970 --> 00:01:36.863
An object is this bundling
of properties and

34
00:01:36.863 --> 00:01:40.863
methods that are a great abstraction for
a real world thing.

35
00:01:40.863 --> 00:01:48.080
A car which we will use,
a van, a bicycle, a house.

36
00:01:48.080 --> 00:01:50.070
All of those things have
kind of properties,

37
00:01:50.070 --> 00:01:51.860
some of them have more
behaviors than others.

38
00:01:53.150 --> 00:01:58.108
But in object oriented JavaScript
the goal is to build a data model.

39
00:01:58.108 --> 00:02:03.826
So, how your information is arranged into
these little chunks called objects that

40
00:02:03.826 --> 00:02:09.620
you can kinda can pass around and use to
achieve your program's ultimate goals.

41
00:02:09.620 --> 00:02:14.390
So, let's take a little throwback and
look at the object literal and

42
00:02:14.390 --> 00:02:16.170
creation of an object literal.

43
00:02:16.170 --> 00:02:19.070
And then we're gonna slowly work into

44
00:02:19.070 --> 00:02:21.750
how we would use this in
an object oriented pattern.

45
00:02:21.750 --> 00:02:22.360
Now, keep in mind,

46
00:02:22.360 --> 00:02:28.360
this is just a brief touch on how
these objects are used and created.

47
00:02:28.360 --> 00:02:32.200
This is not a super deep
dive at this point on

48
00:02:32.200 --> 00:02:34.380
designing an object oriented program.

49
00:02:34.380 --> 00:02:37.490
This is so
you'll be familiar with terminology and

50
00:02:37.490 --> 00:02:41.930
some basic patterns that you will see as
you're looking at other people's projects,

51
00:02:41.930 --> 00:02:45.060
or reading, or even in future episodes.

52
00:02:45.060 --> 00:02:48.890
So let's go ahead and
dive into our browser in Atom and

53
00:02:48.890 --> 00:02:51.680
see how we're going to accomplish this.

54
00:02:51.680 --> 00:02:53.244
I'm gonna open my index.html.

55
00:02:54.790 --> 00:02:57.400
Make sure you're in the right one,
can't emphasize that enough.

56
00:02:58.810 --> 00:03:02.320
So working, nope, object oriented.

57
00:03:02.320 --> 00:03:02.960
There we go.

58
00:03:04.140 --> 00:03:06.535
I should probably shorten the names
of some of my folders also.

59
00:03:06.535 --> 00:03:08.960
[LAUGH] It's hard to read them.

60
00:03:08.960 --> 00:03:12.230
So I have my Chrome open and
I'm gonna open my folder.

61
00:03:14.050 --> 00:03:21.173
So, Objects, as I said are this
encapsulated data method and

62
00:03:21.173 --> 00:03:27.970
the best way to see how those work is
actually just to create one and use it.

63
00:03:27.970 --> 00:03:32.190
Just as a quick reminder, and then start
to refactor to some of these more common

64
00:03:32.190 --> 00:03:36.650
patterns that you may see people use when
building a larger scale application.

65
00:03:36.650 --> 00:03:40.020
It's always good to have context and
at least some understanding,

66
00:03:40.020 --> 00:03:43.540
because object oriented
programming is a huge topic.

67
00:03:43.540 --> 00:03:45.980
It's used in a bunch of other languages,

68
00:03:45.980 --> 00:03:48.810
and JavaScript is a little
bit different take.

69
00:03:48.810 --> 00:03:51.310
It doesn't use the standard patterns that

70
00:03:51.310 --> 00:03:54.540
you will see in other what
are known as class based languages.

71
00:03:56.070 --> 00:04:00.129
So, let's build us an object literal and
a car.

72
00:04:00.129 --> 00:04:04.952
We've seen something like this before,

73
00:04:04.952 --> 00:04:09.910
we're having make, Chevy, and a model,

74
00:04:09.910 --> 00:04:14.870
Camaro And we're gonna keep this simple,

75
00:04:14.870 --> 00:04:19.310
and let's just go with color yellow.

76
00:04:20.370 --> 00:04:25.190
And it has a couple of methods,
like drive.

77
00:04:25.190 --> 00:04:31.810
And I'm gonna leave those empty,
and stop, very simple here.

78
00:04:31.810 --> 00:04:38.190
Now, this is all defined in as an object,
this will simulate a car.

79
00:04:39.880 --> 00:04:44.480
I can access the properties, car.make and

80
00:04:44.480 --> 00:04:47.580
let's see what that actually
prints out and that says Chevy.

81
00:04:47.580 --> 00:04:49.505
Okay, so this is a Chevy.

82
00:04:49.505 --> 00:04:54.670
What about car.model?

83
00:04:54.670 --> 00:04:56.040
Well, it's a Chevy Camaro.

84
00:04:57.300 --> 00:04:58.860
And I can actually look at the color,

85
00:04:58.860 --> 00:05:04.320
just by accessing these using that
shortcut syntax the dot methods.

86
00:05:04.320 --> 00:05:06.330
So theres my color.

87
00:05:07.740 --> 00:05:10.490
Now, what am I doing if I drive,

88
00:05:10.490 --> 00:05:15.100
we'll fill this in so theres something
interesting actually to see Vroom.

89
00:05:17.970 --> 00:05:20.530
Nothing happens, but
I haven't called that yet.

90
00:05:20.530 --> 00:05:25.020
So I'm gonna say car.drive, Vroom.

91
00:05:26.270 --> 00:05:31.216
So I now have an object that has these
encapsulated methods and data but,

92
00:05:31.216 --> 00:05:32.038
I have one.

93
00:05:32.038 --> 00:05:36.130
And that's where our kind of limitations,
start to occur.

94
00:05:36.130 --> 00:05:38.080
I have defined an object literal.

95
00:05:38.080 --> 00:05:40.170
That means I have to do this over,

96
00:05:40.170 --> 00:05:44.410
and over, and over again in
order to get a bunch of cars.

97
00:05:44.410 --> 00:05:47.530
Now, imagine if I was, for instance,
building an inventory system for

98
00:05:47.530 --> 00:05:48.870
like a dealership.

99
00:05:48.870 --> 00:05:54.460
I need a bunch of these objects to
represent all of the cars in my inventory.

100
00:05:54.460 --> 00:05:56.220
Well, this is not really practical.

101
00:05:56.220 --> 00:05:59.815
You're gonna just be paying someone days
and days and days to type, type, type.

102
00:05:59.815 --> 00:06:05.310
And they're going to be very
tempted to copy, paste.

103
00:06:05.310 --> 00:06:08.300
And copy, paste can be problematic.

104
00:06:08.300 --> 00:06:11.989
In addition to, it's really hard to
read if you have a great deal of these

105
00:06:13.150 --> 00:06:14.590
as you're creating them.

106
00:06:14.590 --> 00:06:18.020
And just to show you what the copy/paste
would look like, if I can just doot,

107
00:06:18.020 --> 00:06:19.400
doot, doot, doot, doot.

108
00:06:19.400 --> 00:06:23.350
And then I have to change these variable
names cuz they can't both exist.

109
00:06:23.350 --> 00:06:27.380
And then I gotta start scrolling,
and then man, that's a lot.

110
00:06:27.380 --> 00:06:30.605
I just got lost, scared,
I'm thinking about running away.

111
00:06:30.605 --> 00:06:32.560
[LAUGH] Screaming right now.

112
00:06:32.560 --> 00:06:33.705
So we don't wanna do that.

113
00:06:33.705 --> 00:06:40.310
We want some kind of pattern that will
allow us to kinda spit these out.

114
00:06:40.310 --> 00:06:42.100
I need to produce cars.

115
00:06:43.130 --> 00:06:46.795
If I think in the real world,
cars are produced in a factory.

116
00:06:46.795 --> 00:06:49.780
I wonder if I can simulate a factory.

117
00:06:49.780 --> 00:06:53.530
So a factory builds something and
spits it out.

118
00:06:53.530 --> 00:06:55.270
That sounds a little bit like a function.

119
00:06:55.270 --> 00:06:56.280
Does that sound like a function?

120
00:06:56.280 --> 00:06:57.870
It does.
I think I remember the term,

121
00:06:57.870 --> 00:06:58.770
function factory.

122
00:06:58.770 --> 00:06:59.870
Yeah.
From a previous episode.

123
00:06:59.870 --> 00:07:03.250
Yeah.
So, let's build a car factory.

124
00:07:03.250 --> 00:07:04.870
And, be very, very careful.

125
00:07:04.870 --> 00:07:09.519
I'm doing a very simplistic view of a
factory, it's just for thought processes.

126
00:07:09.519 --> 00:07:14.412
You will see a factory pattern that
people recommend that is way more complex

127
00:07:14.412 --> 00:07:19.229
than this but we wanna think about this
as this is a function that is building

128
00:07:19.229 --> 00:07:23.700
these objects for us producing them and
handing them over.

129
00:07:23.700 --> 00:07:27.780
So let's use this as our
model of what to do.

130
00:07:29.200 --> 00:07:33.298
So let's create a function and

131
00:07:33.298 --> 00:07:41.930
Let's say createCar.

132
00:07:41.930 --> 00:07:44.710
Gonna be carefull guess
some crazy syntax is there.

133
00:07:44.710 --> 00:07:48.343
Notice I have a pair of my parenthesis,

134
00:07:48.343 --> 00:07:54.077
I have my pair of curly braces,
and now I want to create my car.

135
00:07:54.077 --> 00:08:00.573
Well, if I can just start with an object,
add these properties but

136
00:08:00.573 --> 00:08:05.452
notice, I really I need
this to be customizable.

137
00:08:05.452 --> 00:08:09.326
I don't want to produce just
a single type or make of car or

138
00:08:09.326 --> 00:08:14.091
just a single model from that particular
make or even a single color but

139
00:08:14.091 --> 00:08:18.690
I do want this drive and
stop to perform very similarly.

140
00:08:18.690 --> 00:08:22.170
We have these shared behaviors and
properties that may exist for

141
00:08:22.170 --> 00:08:25.160
a car, like the number of wheels,
typically when I think of car.

142
00:08:25.160 --> 00:08:29.900
It has four wheels,
there are exceptions to that rule.

143
00:08:31.300 --> 00:08:35.850
But for the most part,
they can stop, drive, turn, okay.

144
00:08:35.850 --> 00:08:37.280
But they're not all the same color,

145
00:08:37.280 --> 00:08:42.310
have the same number of doors, have
the same maker, are called the same model.

146
00:08:42.310 --> 00:08:44.440
So we need some customized ability, but

147
00:08:44.440 --> 00:08:47.250
we need to be able to share
some of this information.

148
00:08:47.250 --> 00:08:52.470
So a factory would just produce based
on these customized parameters.

149
00:08:52.470 --> 00:08:57.130
What do I want to customize here, well,
I want to make the model and the color.

150
00:08:57.130 --> 00:09:02.010
So dysfunction,
which is I'm gonna serve as our factory,

151
00:09:02.010 --> 00:09:06.800
it's just gonna pump out new cars
is gonna take make, model, and

152
00:09:06.800 --> 00:09:12.180
color as an argument or a series

153
00:09:12.180 --> 00:09:16.800
of arguments that I'm gonna use to build
up new cars each time and spit them out.

154
00:09:18.430 --> 00:09:20.160
So, I'm gonna start
with an empty template.

155
00:09:22.770 --> 00:09:27.169
And I can use var car here because
this is in a different scope and

156
00:09:27.169 --> 00:09:31.320
I know how to local scoped car
versus a globally scoped car.

157
00:09:31.320 --> 00:09:34.970
And let's just move this down
a little bit, so we can see.

158
00:09:34.970 --> 00:09:39.400
So, I'm starting empty and now I'm
gonna start layering on properties and

159
00:09:39.400 --> 00:09:40.430
behaviors.

160
00:09:40.430 --> 00:09:43.980
You can think of it almost like
building the perfect sandwich.

161
00:09:43.980 --> 00:09:46.360
Now you're just layering on,
I need a little bit of mayo,

162
00:09:46.360 --> 00:09:49.560
a little bit of cheese,
a little bit of whatever your meat or

163
00:09:49.560 --> 00:09:53.650
non meat, meat of choice is and
I'm just layering that on there.

164
00:09:53.650 --> 00:09:58.140
Now, sandwiches don't have a lot of
behaviors other than get eaten or

165
00:09:58.140 --> 00:10:00.690
possibly get thrown away if you drop it or

166
00:10:00.690 --> 00:10:04.170
something but we can think of
layering on properties like that.

167
00:10:04.170 --> 00:10:06.520
So, I'm starting with this this template.

168
00:10:06.520 --> 00:10:09.360
And I'm going to say for the car,

169
00:10:09.360 --> 00:10:14.530
I want the make to be
the make that's passed in.

170
00:10:14.530 --> 00:10:20.530
Now, I'm actually going to change
this name here, to arg make just for

171
00:10:20.530 --> 00:10:24.220
this one,
to show these are different things.

172
00:10:26.400 --> 00:10:28.930
So, this is the argument for make.

173
00:10:28.930 --> 00:10:32.770
So, the cars make is going to be
whatever is passed in for this value.

174
00:10:33.900 --> 00:10:38.741
Like that wanna say that car
model is the model passed in and

175
00:10:38.741 --> 00:10:43.910
the car.colour is the color
that is passed in.

176
00:10:43.910 --> 00:10:48.300
So, I'm starting to my cheese

00:26:00.011 --> 00:26:02.565
And that is being called to
the exact same drive method.

412
00:26:02.565 --> 00:26:07.100
So I get a little bit lighter weight
objects with the same amount of behavior.

413
00:26:07.100 --> 00:26:11.995
So those are the three methods for
creating objects, the object literal,

414
00:26:11.995 --> 00:26:15.970
the factory function and
the constructor with a prototype.

415
00:26:15.970 --> 00:26:19.866
Now, the constructor, as I said,
cannot use the prototype.

416
00:26:19.866 --> 00:26:22.586
It will still have
the dander proto method, but

417
00:26:22.586 --> 00:26:25.870
it will have copies just like
we have within the factory.

418
00:26:25.870 --> 00:26:29.840
So the constructor with the prototype is
kind of a lighter weight implementation.

419
00:26:29.840 --> 00:26:35.219
This is not an exhaustive treatment
of every possible pattern for

420
00:26:35.219 --> 00:26:36.893
creating objects.

421
00:26:36.893 --> 00:26:39.564
Some people are incredibly
opinionated about this.

422
00:26:39.564 --> 00:26:44.247
I recommend that you poke around,
see what makes sense to you and

423
00:26:44.247 --> 00:26:48.252
try to use it in different
contexts to see how it works.

424
00:26:48.252 --> 00:26:49.068
>> All right, Justin.

425
00:26:49.068 --> 00:26:50.601
Fantastic explanations and

426
00:26:50.601 --> 00:26:54.305
demonstrations on working with
object-oriented JavaScript, and

427
00:26:54.305 --> 00:26:58.281
maybe save us from a few of those tears
that you had to go through yourself.

428
00:26:58.281 --> 00:27:00.824
[LAUGH]
>> I hope so.

429
00:27:00.824 --> 00:27:02.529
>> All right, well,
we appreciate that, Justin.

430
00:27:02.529 --> 00:27:04.655
We hope everybody out there
enjoyed watching this one.

431
00:27:04.655 --> 00:27:07.689
Signing off for ITPRO.TV,
I've been your host Mike Rodrick.

432
00:27:07.689 --> 00:27:08.634
>> And I'm Justin Dennison.

433
00:27:08.634 --> 00:27:10.169
>> And we'll see you next time.

434
00:27:10.169 --> 00:27:17.362
[MUSIC]

435
00:27:17.362 --> 00:27:19.355
Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Mike demonstrate working with dates in JavaScript. They compare and contrast the built-in date functions. They also look at several date methods.
episodes.title: Working with Dates
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:01.288
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.288 --> 00:00:06.482
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.482 --> 00:00:08.192
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.192 --> 00:00:12.049
You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:12.049 --> 00:00:15.351
>> Hello, welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

6
00:00:15.351 --> 00:00:17.290
I'm your host, Mike Rodrick.

7
00:00:17.290 --> 00:00:20.090
Today, we're doing our
introduction to JavaScript.

8
00:00:20.090 --> 00:00:24.460
And in this episode, we're gonna be
focusing in and working with dates, right.

9
00:00:24.460 --> 00:00:26.120
Doesn't sound like it's very complex, but

10
00:00:26.120 --> 00:00:29.090
if you've ever done it before you
know sometimes it can trip you up.

11
00:00:29.090 --> 00:00:33.450
So here to make it a little smoother for
us all is Mr Justin Dennison.

12
00:00:33.450 --> 00:00:34.390
Welcome back Justin.

13
00:00:34.390 --> 00:00:35.890
>> Thanks for having me back, Mike.

14
00:00:35.890 --> 00:00:40.830
JavaScript dates, you're like,
well dates, they're just month,

15
00:00:40.830 --> 00:00:43.080
year, day, they're that easy.

16
00:00:43.080 --> 00:00:45.740
But except, they're not.

17
00:00:45.740 --> 00:00:49.350
JavaScript dates are a little
precarious at times,

18
00:00:49.350 --> 00:00:51.950
a little unintuitive if you will.

19
00:00:51.950 --> 00:00:55.740
So I think it's important to see some
of these subtle differences, especially

20
00:00:55.740 --> 00:01:01.380
the way JavaScript the interpreters within
browsers typically handle those dates.

21
00:01:01.380 --> 00:01:03.220
So, what is a date?

22
00:01:03.220 --> 00:01:04.600
How are they represented?

23
00:01:04.600 --> 00:01:05.960
And here's the weirdest thing,

24
00:01:05.960 --> 00:01:10.020
I'm getting ready to say a mouthful
to you, just hold on tight.

25
00:01:10.020 --> 00:01:15.070
A JavaScript date is represented
as the number of milliseconds

26
00:01:15.070 --> 00:01:19.748
since January 1st,
1970 at 12:00 AM UTC time.

27
00:01:19.748 --> 00:01:20.597
>> Wait, say that again.

28
00:01:20.597 --> 00:01:21.292
>> [SOUND] Yeah, all right.

29
00:01:21.292 --> 00:01:21.847
>> [LAUGH]
>> So

30
00:01:21.847 --> 00:01:25.210
one more time because I just
got out of breath saying it.

31
00:01:25.210 --> 00:01:28.980
It is the number of milliseconds
since January first 1970,

32
00:01:28.980 --> 00:01:34.340
at zero z, or 12 AM UTC time.

33
00:01:35.440 --> 00:01:36.820
That is crazy.

34
00:01:36.820 --> 00:01:39.980
Now.
that's not how we think of time.

35
00:01:39.980 --> 00:01:45.090
Today is January 1st, or August 6th.

36
00:01:45.090 --> 00:01:52.100
Well, dates they get weird, because all
of those are based on a reference time.

37
00:01:52.100 --> 00:01:57.920
And we had to pick a reference time
in order to get reliable comparisons.

38
00:01:57.920 --> 00:01:59.760
Now, that's where those
milliseconds really come in.

39
00:02:00.840 --> 00:02:06.200
But at the same time, it makes it hard for
individuals to think about,

40
00:02:06.200 --> 00:02:11.140
like I don't think of well, it's been
exactly 3600 milliseconds since yesterday.

41
00:02:11.140 --> 00:02:15.450
And, if you think that way,
then this is gonna be spectacular.

42
00:02:15.450 --> 00:02:20.510
But if you don't, there are some helper
methods, provided by JavaScript.

43
00:02:20.510 --> 00:02:22.720
But they're not so well named.

44
00:02:22.720 --> 00:02:27.720
But before we worry about all those
manipulations of milliseconds since

45
00:02:27.720 --> 00:02:31.105
January 1st 1970, also know as
the epoch as I've heard it called.

46
00:02:31.105 --> 00:02:32.950
>> [LAUGH]
>> I don't know if that's ubiquitous

47
00:02:32.950 --> 00:02:37.690
terminology but a lot of dates
are represented as that way.

48
00:02:37.690 --> 00:02:40.640
But you have to be careful, in some
other languages I know that they'll

49
00:02:40.640 --> 00:02:45.000
use seconds instead of milliseconds so
you have powers of ten differences.

50
00:02:46.530 --> 00:02:50.700
So but that's not the case in Java Script,
Java Script is no seconds all the way.

51
00:02:50.700 --> 00:02:52.570
Well, why would I use dates?

52
00:02:52.570 --> 00:02:54.540
Well, if I sign up for

53
00:02:54.540 --> 00:02:58.680
any type of user accounts,
there should typically log by dates.

54
00:02:58.680 --> 00:03:01.780
If I order something online,
I'm going to have a date that is order,

55
00:03:01.780 --> 00:03:03.300
the date that is ship.

56
00:03:03.300 --> 00:03:09.140
And just keeping that in tow is really
easy with dates if I know how to use them.

57
00:03:09.140 --> 00:03:14.300
So I think it's best if we drill down,
see they're created, used and manipulated.

58
00:03:14.300 --> 00:03:19.170
In that way, we can relieve
the confusion that can occur with dates.

59
00:03:19.170 --> 00:03:22.420
So let's go ahead and
hop into the browser here and

60
00:03:22.420 --> 00:03:27.355
get started with our project as always
we're gonna open that index html file.

61
00:03:27.355 --> 00:03:34.820
That is best use for
entry into the app.js.

62
00:03:34.820 --> 00:03:36.390
Make sure you're opining the correct one.

63
00:03:36.390 --> 00:03:39.080
And then I'm gonna open
the chrome deft tools.

64
00:03:39.080 --> 00:03:41.290
And remember I used
a keyboard shortcut there.

65

We can go to more tools, developer tools.

66
00:03:44.580 --> 00:03:49.130
And I just have my console open so

67
00:03:49.130 --> 00:03:52.220
I'm going to hop in to my text editor and

68
00:03:52.220 --> 00:03:53.020
Add project folder.

69
00:03:54.760 --> 00:03:59.300
And we need to play
around with some dates.

70
00:03:59.300 --> 00:04:00.680
So I have dates here.

71
00:04:00.680 --> 00:04:02.120
My ab.js is empty.

72
00:04:03.280 --> 00:04:05.370
But it will not be very shortly.

73
00:04:05.370 --> 00:04:07.510
So, how do I make a date?

74
00:04:09.820 --> 00:04:13.430
Well, luckily,
its a little easier then sometimes those

75
00:04:13.430 --> 00:04:14.620
interpersonal-
>> [LAUGH]

76
00:04:14.620 --> 00:04:15.170
>> Asking for

77
00:04:15.170 --> 00:04:19.640
dates, but
it is not always the easiest thing.

78
00:04:19.640 --> 00:04:24.320
So job script comes with
a built in date function.

79
00:04:24.320 --> 00:04:26.300
We have to be really careful.

80
00:04:26.300 --> 00:04:28.010
I can do two one of two things.

81
00:04:28.010 --> 00:04:34.540
I can say var date = Date(); and

82
00:04:34.540 --> 00:04:38.140
notice that just a function
that's called with no parameters,

83
00:04:38.140 --> 00:04:45.550
there's nothing in there or
I can say anotherDate = new Date().

84
00:04:45.550 --> 00:04:48.480
And we just want to compare these two.

85
00:04:48.480 --> 00:04:50.987
So, I'm gonna say date, and.

86
00:04:52.957 --> 00:04:55.070
That is not how you spell another.

87
00:04:56.080 --> 00:04:56.750
Another date.

88
00:04:56.750 --> 00:04:57.760
Let's go and see.

89

And notice both of these

00:05:03.600 --> 00:05:05.910
They don't look any different.

91
00:05:05.910 --> 00:05:09.040
I'm going to stay in
the Java Script console here and

92
00:05:09.040 --> 00:05:14.000
show you that in fact, if I'm not

93
00:05:14.000 --> 00:05:16.370
I have the string representation.

94
00:05:16.370 --> 00:05:19.920
If I say new date or date,

00:05:19.920 --> 00:05:25.510
2017 at 9:48:22 GMT,
which is east coast time.

96
00:05:26.580 --> 00:05:31.180
But, what happens if I do the exact

97
00:05:31.180 --> 00:05:34.080
Notice that this shows as a string.

98
00:05:34.080 --> 00:05:35.540
That's that date object.

99
00:05:35.540 --> 00:05:36.540
Just date=Date().

100
00:05:36.540 --> 00:05:39.460
This is a string representation.

101
00:05:39.460 --> 00:05:42.740
When I console.log,
that makes it the black text.

102
00:05:42.740 --> 00:05:44.670
But if I say new date.

103
00:05:47.340 --> 00:05:49.120
That's kinda weird.

104
00:05:49.120 --> 00:05:51.260
It's not represented as that string.

105
00:05:52.580 --> 00:05:54.530
Well what is this?

106
00:05:54.530 --> 00:05:59.400
In fact when I say date I get the string

107
00:05:59.400 --> 00:06:01.470
It is no longer a date object.

108
00:06:01.470 --> 00:06:06.592
When I say new Date, I get
a manipulatable, whew, that's a mouthful.

109
00:06:06.592 --> 00:06:09.215
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] A date that I can manipulate

110
00:06:09.215 --> 00:06:11.300
using methods with on the date.

111
00:06:12.840 --> 00:06:17.430
So be very careful about
those nuance differences and

112
00:06:17.430 --> 00:06:20.460
those can cause some issues because we
have two different types effectively.

113
00:06:20.460 --> 00:06:23.410
We have a string representing
the actual date or

114
00:06:23.410 --> 00:06:28.800
we think of this like a calendar date or
I have a date object which is

115
00:06:28.800 --> 00:06:31.750
behind the scenes those number of
milliseconds since January 1st.

116
00:06:33.040 --> 00:06:38.950
Now, I recommend taking a look at
the documentation provided by MDN or

117
00:06:38.950 --> 00:06:40.120
other various resources.

118
00:06:40.120 --> 00:06:41.030
I like MDN.

119
00:06:42.580 --> 00:06:46.530
So let's go and
hop into there and take a look.

120
00:06:46.530 --> 00:06:49.210
There's the data JavaScript object.

121
00:06:49.210 --> 00:06:52.660
And notice I have several

122
00:06:54.370 --> 00:06:56.210
I have a new date, which we just saw,

123
00:06:56.210 --> 00:07:00.270
and that will give you the right now,
what happened right now.

124
00:07:00.270 --> 00:07:01.650
I created a new date, it's right now.

125
00:07:02.760 --> 00:07:06.230
If we go back to
the JavaScript console and

126
00:07:06.230 --> 00:07:11.990
I type new date again,
you will notice that this is changing.

127
00:07:11.990 --> 00:07:13.000
When I type new date,

128
00:07:13.000 --> 00:07:16.850
I'm getting a date that is
representative of at this very moment.

129
00:07:18.290 --> 00:07:19.870
Again, at that very moment.

130
00:07:19.870 --> 00:07:21.360
It's already in the past.

131
00:07:21.360 --> 00:07:23.200
So be very careful about that.

132
00:07:23.200 --> 00:07:25.170
You want right now.

133
00:07:25.170 --> 00:07:25.950
You just call a new data.

134
00:07:27.590 --> 00:07:29.970
However, if we look in the documentation,

135
00:07:29.970 --> 00:07:32.660
there are several other
ways to create dates.

136
00:07:34.470 --> 00:07:39.550
I'm going to skip over this

137
00:07:39.550 --> 00:07:43.974
if you know the number of milliseconds
that has occurred since January 1st, 1970.

138
00:07:45.195 --> 00:07:46.943
Then you can use that, more power to you.

139
00:07:46.943 --> 00:07:49.006
>> Wait your watch
doesn't have that option?

140
00:07:49.006 --> 00:07:53.311
>> I am at a loss for words.

141
00:07:53.311 --> 00:07:57.059
>> [LAUGH]
>> Your watch has that option,

142
00:07:57.059 --> 00:07:57.898
that's great.

143
00:07:57.898 --> 00:08:02.773
Use that, but I don't think that's
very friendly to individuals And

144
00:08:02.773 --> 00:08:06.750
it's not a great way to
conceptually think about dates.

145
00:08:07.810 --> 00:08:12.120
But we are gonna use this date string,
and then the year,

146
00:08:12.120 --> 00:08:15.300
month, date, hour, minute,
second, so on and so forth.

147
00:08:16.580 --> 00:08:18.630
So, how do we use that?

148
00:08:18.630 --> 00:08:26.290
Currently, I'm just going to comment this
out and let's get another date in here.

149
00:08:26.290 --> 00:08:28.960
So, I need a new date.

150
00:08:28.960 --> 00:08:33.160
And we can provide a string
representation of these dates.

151
00:08:33.160 --> 00:08:35.991
Now just to make sure I don't mess up,

152
00:08:35.991 --> 00:08:40.949
I have some pre-formatted ones here,

153
00:08:44.022 --> 00:08:47.830
So here we go, take off the CapsLocks.

154
00:08:47.830 --> 00:08:52.070
And notice that that is month, day,

155
00:08:52.070 --> 00:08:56.360
year, hour, minute, seconds,
that is the representation.

156
00:08:56.360 --> 00:09:00.410
Let's see what that
actually prints out here.

157
00:09:00.410 --> 00:09:04.400
And sadly, dates have this weird behavior
where when you print them out and

158
00:09:04.400 --> 00:09:12.950
manipulate, they tend to want to go to
strings within the console so be careful.

159
00:09:14.570 --> 00:09:18.160
Friday, January 21st,
2011 well, that's great.

160
00:09:18.160 --> 00:09:23.800
Now, anytime we're using this within
the console from our ab.js but

161
00:09:23.800 --> 00:09:27.650
it will be available to use, so you may
see me play around with that a little bit.

162
00:09:27.650 --> 00:09:31.400
Just because dates are a little
finicky in how they're represented.

163
00:09:32.890 --> 00:09:37.870
Now, I have to be really
careful about these strings.

164
00:09:37.870 --> 00:09:40.640
These strings only available, or

165
00:09:40.640 --> 00:09:46.320
excuse me, are only consistent
if given certain patterns.

166
00:09:46.320 --> 00:09:49.270
This pattern is acceptable,
another pattern is.

167
00:09:52.170 --> 00:09:57.080
I really should pick better variable
names for these demonstrations.

168
00:09:57.080 --> 00:10:02.340
Another pattern is year as four digits,
month

169
00:10:06.020 --> 00:10:08.390
and then I have day and then a T.

170
00:10:09.510 --> 00:10:14.900
And then 05 so the fit hour 24, 13.

171
00:10:14.900 --> 00:10:20.400
Notice, it's very similar to this
one except I have year month day.

172
00:10:20.400 --> 00:10:22.830
T hour, minutes, seconds.

173
00:10:22.830 --> 00:10:25.370
And that's an International standard for
dates.

174
00:10:25.370 --> 00:10:28.450
I think it's iso 8601.

175
00:10:28.450 --> 00:10:30.480
Could be careful,
I wouldn't quote me on that.

176
00:10:30.480 --> 00:10:34.480
But if you wanna look up iso date
standards, this is one of those.

177
00:10:35.730 --> 00:10:38.970
So, these two formats are very
consistent within browsers.

178
00:10:40.160 --> 00:10:47.779
And just to show you, We should get this
exact representation April 1st 2004 and

179
00:10:47.779 --> 00:10:53.010
00:24, well that hour looks
a little different, you may have

180
00:10:53.010 --> 00:10:59.067
noticed these other ones and that's
because this is represented as UTC time,

181
00:10:59.067 --> 00:11:03.960
at the longitude zero, so
it all sets for our basic local time.

182
00:11:05.040 --> 00:11:09.210
So notice I put 5,
well it's offset by minus 5,

183
00:11:09.210 --> 00:11:11.230
because we are in Eastern standard time.

184
00:11:12.440 --> 00:11:17.530
So be very careful about that, because
those can cause you to be from I'm gonna

185
00:11:17.530 --> 00:11:23.090
ship it on this day, but
you're handling it for time zones.

186
00:11:23.090 --> 00:11:26.240
It may be off by a day as
the date representation.

187
00:11:27.650 --> 00:11:30.920
Now, I say these formats
are very important and

188
00:11:30.920 --> 00:11:37.400
that's because in Chrome I can actually
get away with not being so rigid.

189
00:11:37.400 --> 00:11:41.540
But I've tried this in
several other browsers and

190
00:11:41.540 --> 00:11:45.280
most of that time they just say no.

191
00:11:45.280 --> 00:11:52.200
>> So I can say something like this,
3-23-2001.

192
00:11:52.200 --> 00:11:58.060
It works in Chrome to its best, but
notice it makes some assumptions.

193
00:11:58.060 --> 00:12:01.840
It's assuming that I want
zeros everywhere else.

194
00:12:01.840 --> 00:12:05.560
I've tried this in Safari and Firefox.

195
00:12:05.560 --> 00:12:09.759
Safari actually says this is invalid,
don't do this.

196
00:12:09.759 --> 00:12:14.310
So please do look at the documentation,
observe what those patterns are.

197
00:12:14.310 --> 00:12:16.730
These are the two most common ones.

198
00:12:16.730 --> 00:12:20.540
Because if you don't, you may get
inconsistent experiences for your user,

199
00:12:20.540 --> 00:12:21.360
and that's bad.

200
00:12:21.360 --> 00:12:22.960
You don't want that.

201
00:12:22.960 --> 00:12:25.930
And you don't want inconsistent
experiences as a developer,

202
00:12:25.930 --> 00:12:32.270
because it's really hard to go, well this
should work, but it's an invalid date.

203
00:12:32.270 --> 00:12:35.540
And then it doesn't work and
now I'm chasing bugs, and

204
00:12:35.540 --> 00:12:37.430
you don't want to be doing that.

205
00:12:37.430 --> 00:12:41.720
So I can use these format strings but
in addition to that I can make,

206
00:12:43.180 --> 00:12:47.540
I'm choosing really original
names now Mike, date2.

207
00:12:47.540 --> 00:12:53.248
I can also go year as a number,

208
00:12:53.248 --> 00:12:59.140
month, and day.

209
00:12:59.140 --> 00:13:05.070
And I can leave it at that,
this will actually work, as we can see.
